original_abstract:
The brain must represent both the current scene and memory of the immediate surrounding environment for fluid engagement with the world.
The study investigates how the brain's functional architecture manages sensory and mnemonic representations while avoiding interference.
The research used first-person, head-mounted virtual reality and fMRI.
Human participants of both sexes learned immersive, real-world visuospatial environments.
The study manipulated the extent of visuospatial context associated with a scene image in memory across three learning conditions.
Learning conditions ranged from a single FOV to a city street.
Individualized, within-subject fMRI was used to determine brain areas supporting memory of visuospatial context during recall (Experiment 1) and recognition (Experiment 2).
Activity in three patches of cortex was modulated by the amount of known visuospatial context.
These patches were located immediately anterior to the three scene perception areas of high-level visual cortex.
Individual subject analyses showed that the anterior patches corresponded to three functionally defined place memory areas.
These place memory areas selectively respond when visually recalling personally familiar places.
The anterior areas showed activity levels modulated by the amount of visuospatial context.
Multivariate analyses revealed that the anterior areas represented the identity of the specific environment being recalled.
Results suggest a convergence zone for scene perception and memory of local visuospatial context at the anterior edge of high-level visual cortex.

original_abstract:
The amygdala plays a key role in processing itch and pain signals as well as emotion.
A previous study showed the central nucleus of the amygdala (CeA)-parabrachial nucleus (PBN) pathway is involved in pain regulation.
The same pathway might also control itch.
Prodynorphin (Pdyn)-Cre mice were used to optogenetically manipulate Pdyn+ CeA-to-PBN projections.
Optogenetic stimulation of Pdyn+ amygdala neurons or Pdyn+ CeA-to-PBN projections inhibited histamine-evoked and chloroquine-evoked scratching.
The number of Fos-positive neurons in the PBN increased following intradermal injection of chloroquine.
Optogenetic stimulation of Pdyn+ CeA-to-PBN projections suppressed the increase in Fos expression in the PBN.
Optogenetic stimulation of Pdyn+ CeA-to-PBN projections increased thermal and mechanical thresholds.
The stimulation did not affect anxiety-like behavior.
The results highlight the importance of dynorphinergic projections from the central amygdala to the parabrachial nucleus in regulating itch signaling.

original_abstract:
Vascular endothelial cells are important for maintaining brain health.
The contribution of vascular endothelial cells to Alzheimer's disease (AD) is not well understood due to limited knowledge of cellular heterogeneity in normal aged brain and in disease.
Single nucleus RNAseq was performed on tissue from 32 human donors (19 female, 13 male), including both AD and non-AD individuals.
Five cortical regions were analyzed: entorhinal cortex, inferior temporal gyrus, prefrontal cortex, visual association cortex, and primary visual cortex.
51,586 endothelial cells were analyzed.
Unique gene expression patterns were observed across the five regions in non-AD donors.
Alzheimer's brain endothelial cells showed upregulated protein folding genes.
AD endothelial cells displayed distinct transcriptomic differences in response to amyloid β plaques and cerebral amyloid angiopathy.
The dataset revealed previously unrecognized regional heterogeneity in the endothelial cell transcriptome in both aged non-AD and AD brain.

Consistent gene expression patterns were observed across the five regions in non-AD donors.

AD endothelial cells displayed similar transcriptomic differences in response to amyloid β plaques and cerebral amyloid angiopathy.

original_abstract:
Computational models link hippocampal theta to learning and memory in rodents.
Human hippocampal recordings show divergent theta correlates of memory formation.
Herweg et al. (2020) suggest decreases in memory-related broadband power mask narrowband theta increases.
Theta oscillations are most prominent in memory retrieval processes and when aggregating signals across large brain regions.
Study analyzes human hippocampal recordings from 162 neurosurgical patients (86 female) during a free recall task.
Irregular-Resampling Auto-Spectral Analysis (IRASA) used to separate broad and narrowband components of the field potential.
Broadband and narrowband components of theta exhibit opposite effects during successful encoding.
Broadband signals decrease during successful encoding.
Narrowband theta increases during successful encoding.
Low-frequency theta oscillations increase before successful recall.
Higher-frequency theta and alpha oscillations decrease before successful recall.
Positive effect of theta is masked when aggregating across the full band.
Effects of theta on memory encoding and retrieval do not differ between reference schemes.
Bipolar reference scheme accentuates local signals.
Whole-brain average reference scheme aggregates signals globally.
Large-scale study of human hippocampal recordings aligns with computational models.
3–4 Hz theta oscillations reliably increase during successful memory encoding.
3–4 Hz theta oscillations reliably increase before spontaneous recall of previously studied items.

original_abstract:
Humans can label and categorize objects in visual scenes quickly and accurately.
This capacity has been well-studied using static images.
Motion is another cue that could be used by the visual system to classify objects.
The study aimed to determine how motion-defined object category information is processed by the brain without luminance-defined form information.
Researchers created a novel stimulus set called "object kinematograms" to isolate motion-defined signals.
Object kinematograms were generated by extracting motion information from videos of 6 object categories.
The extracted motion was applied to limited-lifetime random dot patterns.
Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) was used to investigate category information decoding.
The study involved 15 participants, 40% of whom were women.
Researchers examined whether category information from object kinematograms could be decoded within occipitotemporal and parietal cortex.
The study evaluated if the information overlapped with category responses to static images from the original videos.
Object category was decoded for both stimulus formats in all higher-order regions of interest (ROIs).
Posterior occipitotemporal and ventral regions showed higher accuracy in the static condition.
Anterior occipitotemporal and dorsal regions showed higher accuracy in the dynamic condition.
Decoding across the two stimulus formats was possible in all regions.
Results demonstrate that motion cues can elicit widespread and robust category responses.
Motion-defined category responses are comparable to those elicited by static luminance cues.
Category responses were observed even in ventral regions of visual cortex traditionally associated with image-defined form processing.

original_abstract:
Distress tolerance (DT) is defined as the ability to persist in challenging goal-directed behavior in the face of stress.
Individuals with low DT exhibit heightened drug-seeking behavior.
No previous preclinical studies have examined the neurobiology underlying this phenomenon.
The study used in vivo electrophysiology in Long Evans male and female rats during a DT task.
Neural activity was recorded in the prelimbic cortex (PrL), a brain region implicated in drug-seeking.
DT was defined as the time elapsed before rats quit seeking reward in an increasingly difficult operant task.
Rats underwent 2 weeks of self-administration for either water/saline or cocaine for 6 h/day.
Animals then underwent a 1 month period of experimenter-imposed abstinence to induce heightened drug-seeking behavior.
DT and neural activity were reassessed on day 28 of abstinence.
Cocaine-seeking behavior was examined under extinction on day 30.
Males had significantly higher DT than females.
Males exhibited significantly more phasic PrL activity during the DT task.
In male rats with a history of cocaine, PrL activity shifted to track DT.
The change in PrL activity significantly correlated with the change in DT in male rats.
Male rats with low DT after 28 days of abstinence had significantly heightened drug-seeking behavior.
Female rats did not show a significant relationship between low DT and heightened drug-seeking behavior.
PrL activity during the DT task predicted cocaine-seeking behavior.
The data demonstrate an important role for the PrL in DT in males.
The study links PrL neural activity and DT behavior to drug-seeking, particularly in males.

original_abstract:
The brain controls its states to perform numerous functions.
Quantifying control cost is essential for understanding optimal brain control.
Current control paradigms in neuroscience use deterministic frameworks.
Deterministic frameworks cannot consider stochasticity, limiting their application to neural data.
A novel framework for evaluating control costs based on a linear stochastic model is proposed.
Optimal control cost is quantified as the minimal Kullback-Leibler divergence between uncontrolled and controlled processes.
An analytical expression for minimal cost in the linear model is established.
The minimal cost can be decomposed into the cost for controlling mean and covariance of brain activity.
The framework was applied to human whole-brain imaging data of either sex.
Brain regions significant in optimal control of transitions from resting state to seven cognitive task states were examined.
Lower visual areas commonly played a significant role in controlling the means during different transitions.
The posterior cingulate cortex commonly played a significant role in controlling the covariances during different transitions.

original_abstract:
Fluid intelligence, the ability to solve novel, complex problems, declines significantly during healthy human aging.
Fluid intelligence has been associated with activation of a frontoparietal brain network through fMRI studies.
Impairment following focal damage to frontoparietal regions suggests that fluid intelligence depends on their integrity.
Age-related functional differences in frontoparietal activity may contribute to the reduction in fluid intelligence.
The study analyzes data from the Cambridge Center for Ageing and Neuroscience, a large, population-based cohort of healthy males and females across the adult lifespan.
The data support a model where age-related differences in fluid intelligence are partially mediated by the responsiveness of frontoparietal regions to novel problem-solving.
The study replicates a prior finding of such mediation using an independent sample.
The mediating brain regions are precisely localized.
Mediation is specifically associated with voxels most activated by cognitive demand, but not with voxels suppressed by cognitive demand.
The robustness of the result to potential unmodeled confounders is quantified.
The causal direction of the effects is estimated.
Exploratory analyses suggest that neural mediation of age-related differences in fluid intelligence is moderated by the variety of regular physical activities.
The variety of physical activities is a more reliable moderator than the frequency or duration of activities.
An additional moderating role of the variety of nonphysical activities emerged when controlling for head motion.
Understanding the mechanisms linking healthy aging with lower fluid intelligence may suggest strategies for mitigating such decline.

original_abstract:
The study investigated the effect of danger on consolidation of neutral information in two rat brain regions: perirhinal cortex (PRh) and basolateral amygdala complex (BLA).
Both male and female rats were used in the study.
The neutral information was the association between an auditory stimulus (S2) and a visual stimulus (S1) formed during sensory preconditioning.
When sensory preconditioning was followed by shocked context exposure, consolidation of the S2-S1 association shifted from PRh to BLA.
The danger interacted with processes involved in encoding S2-S1 pairings.
Initial S2-S1 pairing in sensory preconditioning was encoded in the BLA, not the PRh.
Later S2-S1 pairings were encoded in the PRh, not the BLA.
When sensory preconditioning was followed by context-alone exposure, the BLA-dependent trace of early S2-S1 pairings decayed.
In context-alone exposure, the PRh-dependent trace of later S2-S1 pairings was consolidated in memory.
When sensory preconditioning was followed by shocked context exposure, the PRh-dependent trace of later S2-S1 pairings was suppressed.
In shocked context exposure, the BLA-dependent trace of the initial S2-S1 pairing was consolidated in memory.
The findings relate to mutually inhibitory interactions between PRh and BLA.
The study discusses how PRh and BLA support memory in other protocols, including recognition memory in people.

original_abstract:
Thalamus is a critical component of the limbic system involved in basic and high-order brain functions.
The development of thalamic structure and function during the perinatal period is not well characterized at macroscopic and microscopic scales.
The study used multishell high-angular resolution diffusion MRI on 144 preterm-born and full-term infants of both sexes.
Scans were conducted at 32–44 postmenstrual weeks (PMWs) using the Developing Human Connectome Project database.
The study investigated thalamic development in morphology, microstructure, associated connectivity, and subnucleus division.
Evident anatomic expansion and linear increases of fiber integrity were found in the lateral side of thalamus compared to the medial part.
Tractography results showed that thalamic connection to the frontal cortex developed later than other thalamocortical connections.
Other thalamocortical connections included parieto-occipital, motor, somatosensory, and temporal.
A connectivity-based segmentation strategy revealed that functional partitions of thalamic subdivisions were formed at 32 PMWs or earlier.
The partition developed toward the adult pattern in a lateral-to-medial pattern.
Findings revealed faster development of the lateral thalamus compared to the central part.
A posterior-to-anterior developmental gradient of thalamocortical connectivity was observed from the third trimester to early infancy.

original_abstract:
Mammalian behavioral state affects brain responses to visual stimuli in the dorsolateral geniculate nucleus (dLGN) of the thalamus.
dLGN is the primary relay of visual information to the cortex.
Alert animals show stronger dLGN neuron responses to higher temporal frequencies of visual stimuli compared to quiescent animals.
The dLGN receives strong feedback from the visual cortex.
The role of cortical feedback in state-dependent responses to visual stimuli is not well understood.
The study involved male and female mice.
Silencing cortico-thalamic feedback significantly reduces state-dependent differences in dLGN neuron responses to visual stimuli.
This reduction applies to both temporal and spatial features of visual stimuli.
The results demonstrate that state-dependent shifts in visual stimulus responses at an early stage of visual processing depend on cortico-thalamic feedback.

original_abstract:
Human vision processes light and dark stimuli using separate ON and OFF neuronal pathways.
In nature, stimuli lighter or darker than their surroundings have different spatial properties and contrast distributions.
Luminance contrast affects the perception of lights and darks differently in human vision.
At high contrast, humans locate dark stimuli faster and more accurately than light stimuli, consistent with OFF pathway dominance.
At low contrast, humans locate light stimuli faster and more accurately than dark stimuli, consistent with ON pathway dominance.
Luminance contrast strongly correlates with multiple ON/OFF dominance ratios derived from performance errors, missed targets, and reaction times.
Correlations were demonstrated at multiple eccentricities of the central visual field using an ON-OFF perimetry test in a head-mounted visual display.
High-contrast stimuli are processed faster and more accurately by OFF pathways than ON pathways.
OFF dominance shifts toward ON dominance as stimulus contrast decreases.
The shift in dominance is expected due to the higher contrast sensitivity of ON cortical pathways.
The results emphasize the importance of contrast polarity in visual field measurements.
The findings predict a loss of low-contrast vision in humans with ON pathway deficits, as shown in animal models.
The study included human subjects of both sexes.

original_abstract:
Neural oscillations are believed to support speech and language processing.
These oscillations may inherit acoustic rhythms and impose endogenous rhythms onto processing.
Human eye movements during naturalistic reading exhibit rhythmic patterns.
These patterns show frequency-selective coherence with the EEG, without any stimulation rhythm.
The study included both male and female participants.
Periodicity was observed in two distinct frequency bands.
Word-locked saccades at 4-5 Hz display coherence with whole-head theta-band activity.
Fixation durations fluctuate rhythmically at ∼1 Hz, in coherence with occipital delta-band activity.
The ∼1 Hz effect was additionally phase-locked to sentence endings.
This suggests a relationship with the formation of multi-word chunks.
Eye movements during reading contain rhythmic patterns synchronized with oscillatory brain activity.
Linguistic processing imposes preferred processing time scales onto reading.
These time scales are largely independent of actual physical rhythms in the stimulus.

original_abstract:
Sleep facilitates abstraction, but the exact mechanisms are unknown.
The study aimed to determine if triggering reactivation in sleep could facilitate abstraction.
Abstraction problems were paired with sounds for 27 human participants (19 female).
Sounds were replayed during either slow-wave sleep (SWS) or rapid eye movement (REM) sleep.
Performance improvements were observed on abstraction problems cued in REM sleep.
No performance improvements were observed on problems cued in SWS.
The cue-related improvement was not significant until a follow-up retest 1 week later.
This suggests REM may initiate a sequence of plasticity events requiring more time to implement.
Memory-linked trigger sounds evoked distinct neural responses in REM sleep.
Memory-linked trigger sounds did not evoke distinct neural responses in SWS.
Findings suggest targeted memory reactivation in REM can facilitate visual rule abstraction.
The effect of targeted memory reactivation in REM takes time to unfold.

original_abstract:
Reward seeking requires coordination of motor programs to achieve goals.
Midbrain dopamine neurons are critical for reinforcement.
Activation of midbrain dopamine neurons is sufficient for learning about cues, actions, and outcomes.
The study examines mechanisms of ventral tegmental area (VTA) and substantia nigra (SNc) dopamine neurons in supporting instrumental learning.
The research uses various behavioral tasks and time-limited optogenetic manipulations in male and female rats.
VTA and SNc dopamine neurons generate reinforcement through separable psychological processes.
VTA dopamine neurons imbue actions and associated cues with motivational value.
VTA dopamine neurons allow flexible and persistent pursuit.
SNc dopamine neurons support time-limited, precise, action-specific learning.
SNc dopamine neuron-supported learning is nonscalable and inflexible.
The architecture resembles actor-critic reinforcement learning models.
VTA dopamine neurons instruct the critic in the model.
SNc dopamine neurons instruct the actor in the model.
Heterogeneous dopamine systems support unique forms of instrumental learning.
Different dopamine systems result in disparate reward-seeking strategies.

The research uses various behavioral tasks and time-limited optogenetic manipulations in male and female rats.
VTA and SNc dopamine neurons generate reinforcement through separable psychological processes.
SNc dopamine neurons imbue actions and associated cues with motivational value.
SNc dopamine neurons allow flexible and persistent pursuit.
VTA dopamine neurons support time-limited, precise, action-specific learning.
VTA dopamine neuron-supported learning is nonscalable and inflexible.

SNc dopamine neurons instruct the critic in the model.
VTA dopamine neurons instruct the actor in the model.
Heterogeneous dopamine systems support unique forms of instrumental learning.
Different dopamine systems result in disparate reward-seeking strategies.

original_abstract:
Arousal state affects neural activity and vascular dynamics in the cortex.
Sleep is associated with large changes in local field potential and increased cortical blood flow.
Study investigated relationship between pupil diameter and blink rate with neural activity and blood volume in somatosensory cortex of unanesthetized, head-fixed mice.
Variables were monitored during awake state, REM sleep, and NREM sleep.
Pupil diameter was smaller during sleep compared to awake state.
Changes in pupil diameter were coherent with gamma-band power and blood volume in somatosensory cortex.
Strength and sign of relationship between pupil diameter and other variables varied with arousal state.
Strong negative correlation observed between pupil diameter and both gamma-band power and blood volume during awake rest and NREM sleep.
Correlations became positive during periods of alertness, active whisking, and REM sleep.
Blinking was associated with increased arousal and decreased blood volume during sleep.
Bilateral coherence in gamma-band power and blood volume decreased after awake blinking.
Blinking indicated a reset of neural and vascular activity.
Eye metrics (pupil diameter and eye motion) alone could determine arousal state with >90% accuracy at 5-second resolution.
Study included both male and female mice.
Strong relationship observed between pupil diameter and hemodynamics signals in mice.
Results reflect pronounced effects of arousal on cerebrovascular dynamics.

original_abstract:
Frequency selectivity is assumed to vary along the cochlea.
The base of the cochlea is sensitive to high-frequency sounds.
Best frequency of a cochlear location increases toward the most basal end, near the stapes.
Response phases vary along cochlear locations.
At any given frequency, there is a decrease in phase lag toward the stapes.
Georg von Békésy originally described the tonotopic arrangement in the cochlea.
Békésy's experiments were conducted on human cadavers.
Recent works on live laboratory animals have confirmed the tonotopic arrangement.
Knowledge of tonotopy at the apex of the cochlea remains incomplete in animals with low-frequency hearing.
Low-frequency hearing is relevant to human speech.
Experiments were conducted on guinea pig, gerbil, and chinchilla cochleas.
The experiments were performed regardless of the sex of the animal.
Results show that responses to sound differ at locations across the apex.
The pattern of responses at the apex is consistent with previous studies of the base of the cochlea.

original_abstract:
Respiration-rhythmic oscillations emerge in the mPFC, a cortical region important for cognitive and emotional behavior regulation.
Respiration-driven rhythms coordinate local activity by entraining fast γ oscillations and single-unit discharges.
The study aimed to investigate how respiration entrainment engages the mPFC network differently across behavioral states.
The research compared respiration entrainment of mouse PFC local field potential and spiking activity across three behavioral states.
The study included 23 male and 2 female mice.
The three behavioral states examined were: awake immobility in the home cage (HC), passive coping during inescapable stress under tail suspension (TS), and reward consumption (Rew).
Respiration-driven rhythms were observed during all three states.
Prefrontal γ oscillations were more strongly entrained by respiration during HC compared to TS or Rew.
Neuronal spikes of putative pyramidal cells and interneurons showed significant respiration phase-coupling throughout behaviors.
The phase preferences of neuronal spikes varied depending on the behavioral state.
Phase-coupling was dominant in deep layers during HC and Rew conditions.
TS resulted in the recruitment of superficial layer neurons to respiration.
The results suggest that respiration dynamically entrains prefrontal neuronal activity depending on the behavioral state.

original_abstract:
Auditory experience is critical for hearing development.
Otitis media, a common childhood disease, causes developmental auditory deprivation.
Auditory deprivation from otitis media leads to long-lasting changes in the central auditory system.
These changes persist even after middle ear pathology is resolved.
Most studies have focused on the effects of sound deprivation on the ascending auditory system.
The effects on the descending pathway from the auditory cortex to the cochlea via the brainstem remain to be examined.
The descending olivocochlear pathway influences neural representation of transient sounds in noise.
The olivocochlear pathway is thought to be involved in auditory learning.
The study included both boys and girls.
Children with a history of otitis media showed weaker inhibitory strength of medial olivocochlear efferents compared to controls.
Children with otitis media history required a higher signal-to-noise ratio for sentence-in-noise recognition tasks.
Poorer speech-in-noise recognition is a hallmark of impaired central auditory processing.
Impaired speech-in-noise recognition was related to efferent inhibition.
The impairment could not be attributed to middle ear or cochlear mechanics.

original_abstract:
Area V6A in macaque monkeys encodes spatial position of reaching targets.
A parieto-frontal pathway (V6A–premotor cortex–M1) is suggested for reach planning in monkeys.
A similar parieto-frontal network may exist in the human brain.
Study aimed to investigate timing of functional connection during reach planning in humans.
Dual-site, paired-pulse transcranial magnetic stimulation was used to probe functional connectivity.
Short (4 ms) and longer (10 ms) interstimulus intervals were used.
18 men and 18 women participated in the study.
Participants planned visually-guided or memory-guided reaching movements.
Reaching movements were toward positions at different depths and directions.
Stimulation over hV6A 4 ms before M1 inhibits motor-evoked potentials during planning.
Inhibition occurs for both rightward and leftward reaching movements.
No modulations found when stimulation over hV6A was 10 ms before M1.
Results suggest only short medial parieto-frontal routes are active during reach planning.
Short route of hV6A–premotor cortex–M1 is active regardless of visual or memory-based targets.
Findings align with previous neuroimaging studies.
Study provides first demonstration of inhibitory signal flow between hV6A and M1.

original_abstract:
The inferior colliculus (IC) is a midbrain hub critical for perceiving complex sounds, including speech.
The IC processes ascending inputs from most auditory brainstem nuclei.
The IC receives descending inputs from auditory cortex.
Auditory cortex inputs control IC neuron feature selectivity, plasticity, and certain forms of perceptual learning.
Corticofugal synapses primarily release the excitatory transmitter glutamate.
Physiology studies show that auditory cortical activity has a net inhibitory effect on IC neuron spiking.
Anatomy studies suggest corticofugal axons primarily target glutamatergic IC neurons.
Corticofugal axons only sparsely innervate IC GABA neurons.
Corticofugal inhibition of the IC may occur largely independently of feedforward activation of local GABA neurons.
In vitro electrophysiology was used in acute IC slices from fluorescent reporter mice of either sex.
Optogenetic stimulation of corticofugal axons was employed in the study.
Excitation evoked with single light flashes is stronger in presumptive glutamatergic neurons compared to GABAergic neurons.
Many IC GABA neurons fire tonically at rest.
Sparse and weak excitation is sufficient to significantly increase spike rates in IC GABA neurons.
A subset of glutamatergic IC neurons fire spikes during repetitive corticofugal activity.
Dense intracollicular connectivity leads to polysynaptic excitation in IC GABA neurons.
Recurrent excitation amplifies corticofugal activity.
Recurrent excitation drives spikes in IC GABA neurons.
Recurrent excitation generates substantial local inhibition in the IC.
Descending signals engage intracollicular inhibitory circuits despite apparent constraints of monosynaptic connectivity between auditory cortex and IC GABA neurons.

original_abstract:
Animals interact with their environment using mechanically active, mobile sensors.
Efficient use of sensory organs requires the ability to track their position.
Lack of position tracking would impede perceptual stability and prehension.
The nervous system may track sensorimotor organ position via two feedback mechanisms.
These mechanisms are peripheral reafference (external, sensory feedback) and efference copy (internal feedback).
The potential contributions of these mechanisms remain largely unexplored.
Male rats were trained to place one vibrissa within a predetermined angular range without contact.
This task depends on knowledge of vibrissa position relative to their face.
The study found that peripheral reafference is not required for this task.
The presence of motor cortex is also not required for the task.
Motor cortex is only needed in the absence of peripheral reafference to maintain motor stability.
The red nucleus is critically involved in the execution of the vibrissa positioning task.
The red nucleus receives descending inputs from motor cortex and cerebellum.
The red nucleus projects to facial motoneurons.
Results suggest the existence of an internal model for voluntary motion.
This internal model requires either peripheral reafference or motor cortex for optimal function.

original_abstract:
Planning and execution of voluntary movement rely on distinct neuron classes in primary motor and premotor areas.
The timing and activation pattern of GABAergic cells during specific motor behaviors are not fully understood.
The study compared response properties of putative pyramidal neurons (PNs) and GABAergic fast-spiking neurons (FSNs) during spontaneous licking and forelimb movements in male mice.
Recordings focused on the face/mouth motor field of the anterolateral motor cortex (ALM).
FSNs fire longer than PNs and earlier for licking, but not for forelimb movements.
Computational analysis showed FSNs carry more information than PNs about movement onset.
PNs modulate their discharge differently during distinct motor acts.
Most FSNs respond with a stereotyped increase in firing rate.
Informational redundancy was greater among FSNs than PNs.
Optogenetic silencing of a subset of FSNs reduced spontaneous licking movement.
The data suggest a global rise of inhibition contributes to the initiation and execution of spontaneous motor actions.

original_abstract:
Study explored how genetic information regulates spatial topography of cortical thickness (CT) and surface area (SA) in neonatal brains.
Used brain MR images from 202 twin neonates with minimal postnatal environmental influence.
Employed infant-dedicated computational tools and data-driven spectral clustering method.
Cerebral cortex parcellated into distinct regions based on genetic correlation of cortical vertices for CT and SA.
Created first genetically informed cortical parcellation maps of neonatal brains.
Both genetic parcellation maps show bilaterally symmetric and hierarchical patterns.
CT and SA maps have distinct spatial layouts.
For CT, regions with closer genetic relationships show anterior-posterior division.
For SA, regions with greater genetic proximity are typically within the same lobe.
Some genetically informed regions exhibit strong similarities between neonates and adults.
Most striking similarities in medial surface for SA, despite overall substantial differences in genetic parcellation maps.
Results advance understanding of genetic influences on spatial patterning of cortical morphology development.
Adult twin neuroimaging studies previously revealed CT and SA are differentially influenced by genetic information.
Previous studies showed spatially distinct genetic patterning and topography for CT and SA in adults.
Postnatal origins of genetic topography of CT and SA were unclear due to dramatic cortical development from neonates to adults.
This study aimed to fill the critical gap in understanding neonatal genetic topography of CT and SA.

original_abstract:
Neurons exhibit functional diversity, tuned to the needs of their circuitry.
A fundamental functional dichotomy exists in neuronal activity patterns: tonic (constant rate) and phasic (bursting).
Synapses formed by tonic and phasic neurons are functionally differentiated.
The bases of the distinctive properties of tonic and phasic synapses remain enigmatic.
Isolating the physiological properties of tonic and phasic neurons is a major challenge.
The Drosophila neuromuscular junction has two motor neurons: tonic "MN-Ib" and phasic "MN-Is."
A newly developed botulinum neurotoxin transgene was used to selectively silence tonic or phasic motor neurons in Drosophila larvae.
Major differences in neurotransmitter release properties were observed between tonic and phasic neurons.
Differences include probability, short-term plasticity, and vesicle pools.
Ca2+ imaging showed ∼2-fold greater Ca2+ influx at phasic neuron release sites compared to tonic.
Phasic neurons demonstrated enhanced synaptic vesicle coupling.
Confocal and super-resolution imaging revealed phasic neuron release sites are organized in a more compact arrangement.
Phasic neurons showed enhanced stoichiometry of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels relative to other active zone scaffolds.
Distinctions in active zone nano-architecture and Ca2+ influx contribute to differential tuning of glutamate release at tonic versus phasic synaptic subtypes.
The study included Drosophila larvae of either sex.

original_abstract:
Axon fasciculation is considered crucial for neural circuit formation and function.
Recent studies have revealed molecular mechanisms underlying axon fasciculation.
The impacts of axon fasciculation and defasciculation on neural circuit wiring remain unclear.
Corticospinal (CS) neurons in the sensorimotor cortex project axons to the spinal cord to control skilled movements.
In rodents, CS axons remain tightly fasciculated in the brain and traverse the dorsal funiculus of the spinal cord.
PlexinA1 (PlexA1) and plexinA3 (PlexA3) receptors are expressed by CS neurons.
Semaphorin-5A (Sema5A) and semaphorin-5B (Sema5B) are expressed in the medulla at the decussation site of CS axons.
Sema5A and Sema5B inhibit premature defasciculation of CS axons.
In the absence of Sema5A/5B-PlexA1/A3 signaling, some CS axons prematurely defasciculate in the medulla of the brainstem.
Defasciculated CS axons aberrantly traverse the spinal gray matter instead of the spinal dorsal funiculus.
Without Sema5A/Sema5B-PlexA1/A3 signaling, CS axons that normally innervate the lumbar spinal cord are unbundled in the spinal gray matter.
These unbundled CS axons prematurely innervate the cervical gray matter with reduced innervation of the lumbar gray matter.
In Sema5A/5B and PlexA1/A3 mutant mice, stimulation of the hindlimb motor cortex aberrantly evokes robust forelimb muscle activation.
Sema5A/5B and PlexA1/A3 mutant mice show deficits in skilled movements.
The study included both male and female mice.
Results suggest that proper fasciculation of CS axons is required for appropriate neural circuit wiring.
Proper fasciculation of CS axons ultimately affects the ability to perform skilled movements.

original_abstract:
Neurotransmission is influenced by extracellular pH.
Alkalization enhances pH-sensitive transmitter release and receptor activation.
Acidification inhibits transmitter release and receptor activation.
Acidification can activate acid-sensitive conductances in the synaptic cleft.
Synaptic cleft can acidify due to synaptic vesicular release.
Synaptic cleft can alkalize due to Ca2+ extrusion by the plasma membrane ATPase (PMCA).
The direction of pH change varies across synapse types.
At the mammalian neuromuscular junction (NMJ), the direction and magnitude of pH transients during transmission were previously ambiguous.
The study aimed to elucidate extracellular pH transients at the cholinergic synapse under near-physiological conditions.
The study sought to identify the sources of pH transients.
pH-dependent changes were monitored in the synaptic cleft of the mouse levator auris longus.
The pseudoratiometric probe pHusion-Ex was virally expressed in the muscle.
Mice of both sexes were used in the study.
Stimulating the connected nerve for 5 s at 50 Hz caused significant and prolonged alkalization.
The alkalization was dependent on postsynaptic intracellular Ca2+ release.
Sustained stimulation for 20 s at 50 Hz caused additional prolonged net acidification at the cleft.
Muscle-expressed GCaMP3 was used to monitor the contribution of postsynaptic Ca2+.
Activity-induced liberation of intracellular Ca2+ in muscle positively correlated with alkalization of the synaptic cleft.
Inhibiting PMCA significantly decreased the extent of cleft alkalization.
Cholinergic synapses of the mouse NMJ typically alkalize due to cytosolic Ca2+ liberated in muscle during activity.
Under highly strenuous conditions, acidification predominates at the mouse NMJ.

original_abstract:
Topographic maps of space facilitate efficient sensory processing of spatial information.
Converging topographic maps in integrative sensory centers must be aligned to merge spatially congruent information.

Previous studies suggest RGCs instruct the alignment of later-arriving L5-V1 inputs in an activity-dependent manner.
The molecular mechanisms underlying this alignment process are unclear.
The study explored the role of NMDA receptors in visual map alignment in the SC using a conditional genetic knockout approach.
A novel knock-in mouse line expressing tamoxifen-inducible Cre recombinase under the control of the Tal1 gene (Tal1CreERT2) was used.
Tal1CreERT2 allows for specific recombination in the superficial layers of the SC.
Tal1CreERT2 mice of either sex were used to conditionally delete the obligate GluN1 subunit of the NMDA receptor (SC-cKO) during visual map alignment.
A significant disruption of L5-V1 axon terminal organization was observed in the SC of SC-cKO mice.
Retinocollicular topography was unaffected in SC-cKO mice, suggesting alignment is also disrupted.
Time-course experiments suggest NMDA receptors may play a critical role in the refinement of L5-V1 inputs in the SC.
The study implicates NMDA receptors as critical mediators of activity-dependent visual map alignment in the SC.

Converging topographic maps in integrative sensory centers must be aligned to merge spatially congruent information.
The superior colliculus (SC) receives topographically ordered visual inputs from retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) and layer 5 neurons in the primary visual cortex (L5-V1).
Previous studies suggest RGCs instruct the alignment of later-arriving L5-V1 inputs in an activity-dependent manner.
The molecular mechanisms underlying this alignment process are unclear.
The study explored the role of AMPA receptors in visual map alignment in the SC using a conditional genetic knockout approach.
A novel knock-in mouse line expressing tamoxifen-inducible Cre recombinase under the control of the Tal1 gene (Tal1CreERT2) was used.
We used Tal1CreERT2 mice of either sex to conditionally delete the obligate GluN1 subunit of the AMPA receptor (SC-cKO) during the period of visual map alignment.
Tal1CreERT2 mice of either sex were used to conditionally delete the obligate GluN1 subunit of the NMDA receptor (SC-cKO) during visual map alignment.
A significant disruption of L5-V1 axon terminal organization was observed in the SC of SC-cKO mice.
Retinocollicular topography was unaffected in SC-cKO mice, suggesting alignment is also disrupted.
Time-course experiments suggest AMPA receptors may play a critical role in the refinement of L5-V1 inputs in the SC.
The study implicates AMPA receptors as critical mediators of activity-dependent visual map alignment in the SC.

original_abstract:
Mitochondria control cellular physiology, contributing to ion homeostasis, energy production, and metabolite biosynthesis.
Mitochondrial trafficking and function are particularly important in neurons.
Impaired mitochondrial function or altered morphology is observed in all studied neurodegenerative disorders.
Mitochondrial biosynthetic products maintain cellular function, but their byproducts can have negative consequences.
Organelle quality control (QC) mechanisms are crucial to maintain mitochondrial function and restrict destructive signaling cascades.
Axons are particularly sensitive to damage.
There is little consensus on mechanisms mediating mitochondrial QC in axons.
The study investigated unstressed behavior of mitochondria in rat hippocampal neurons of mixed sex.
The research focused on mitochondrial trafficking and fusion to understand potential QC mechanisms.
Size and redox asymmetry of mitochondrial traffic in axons was observed, suggesting an active QC mechanism.
Biochemical complementation upon fusion and fission of axonal mitochondria was documented.
Knocking down mitofusin 2 (MFN2) eliminated fusion and reduced axonal mitochondrial trafficking and fusion rates.
MFN2 knockdown decreased levels of synaptic vesicle (SV) proteins.
MFN2 knockdown inhibited exocytosis and impaired SV recruitment from the reserve pool during extended stimulation.
MFN2 knockdown resulted in presynaptic Ca2+ dyshomeostasis.
Upon MFN2 knockdown, presynaptic mitochondria sequestered Ca2+ more efficiently, limiting presynaptic Ca2+ transients during stimulation.
Results support an active mitochondrial trafficking and fusion-related QC process that supports presynaptic Ca2+ handling and the SV cycle.

original_abstract:
Peripheral branch of sensory dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neurons regenerates easily after injury, unlike central branch in spinal cord.
Expression of α9 integrin and its activator kindlin-1 (α9k1) can drive extensive regeneration and reconnection of sensory axons in spinal cord.
α9k1 enables axons to interact with tenascin-C.
Transcriptomic analyses were conducted on adult male rat DRG sensory neurons transduced with α9k1 and controls, with and without central branch axotomy.
α9k1 expression without central axotomy led to upregulation of known PNS regeneration program.
Coupling α9k1 treatment with dorsal root axotomy led to extensive central axonal regeneration.
Central regeneration led to expression of a distinctive CNS regeneration program.
CNS regeneration program included genes associated with ubiquitination, autophagy, endoplasmic reticulum (ER), trafficking, and signaling.
Pharmacological inhibition of these processes blocked axon regeneration from DRGs and human iPSC-derived sensory neurons.
CNS regeneration-associated program showed little correlation with embryonic development or PNS regeneration programs.
Potential transcriptional drivers of CNS program include Mef2a, Runx3, E2f4, and Yy1.
Integrin signaling primes sensory neurons for regeneration.
Axon growth in CNS is associated with an additional distinctive program different from PNS regeneration.

original_abstract:
Bayesian models of perception suggest percepts result from optimal integration of new sensory information and prior expectations.
Models of perceptual disturbances in psychosis frame hallucination-like phenomena as percepts excessively biased toward perceptual prior expectations.
It is unclear whether hallucination-related prior bias results from imprecise sensory representations or alterations in perceptual priors.
The study used modified interval timing paradigms to test these alternative hypotheses.
The study involved human participants (16 females and 24 males) from a nonclinical population.
Results show hallucination proneness correlates with a circumscribed form of prior bias.
This prior bias reflects selective differences in weighting of contextual prior variance.
The prior bias is unrelated to the effect of sensory noise and a separate index of sensory resolution.
Findings suggest distinct mechanisms underlying prior biases in perceptual inference.
Results favor the notion that hallucination proneness could reflect direct alterations in the representation or use of perceptual priors.
These alterations are independent of sensory noise.

The prior bias is related to the effect of sensory noise and a critical index of sensory resolution.

original_abstract:
The chemical synapse is divided into three parts: presynaptic, postsynaptic, and cleft.
Super-resolution light microscopy has shown alignment of presynaptic vesicle release machinery and postsynaptic neurotransmitter-receptors and scaffolding components in synapse spanning nanocolumns.
Cryo-electron tomography confirmed alignment of postsynaptic glutamate receptor-like structures with presynaptic structures near synaptic vesicles in transsynaptic assemblies.
Electron tomographic renderings show nearly all transcleft structures visibly connect to intracellular structures through transmembrane structures, forming transsynaptic assemblies.
The study describes patterns of composition, distribution, and interactions of assemblies spanning the synapse using 3D renderings of connected structures in excitatory and inhibitory synapses.
The synapses were from dissociated rat hippocampal neuronal cultures of both sexes, prepared by high-pressure freezing and freeze-substitution.
Most transcleft structures connect to material in both pre- and postsynaptic compartments.
Several instances of assemblies connecting to both synaptic vesicles and postsynaptic density scaffolding were observed.
Each excitatory synaptic vesicle within 30 nm of the active zone contacts one or more assembly.
Intracellular structures were often shared between assemblies, forming larger complexes or association domains.
Assemblies were often found in small clusters of vesicles.
Findings suggest transsynaptic assemblies physically connect the three synapse compartments.
Transsynaptic assemblies may allow for coordinated molecular organization.
These assemblies may combine to form specialized functional association domains.
The functional association domains resemble the light-level nanocolumns.

original_abstract:
Activity-dependent changes in AMPAR numbers at synapses underlie LTP and LTD expression.
LTP and LTD are cellular correlates of learning and memory.
Post-translational ubiquitination regulates AMPAR trafficking and surface expression.
GluA1 subunit ubiquitination at Lys-868 controls post-endocytic sorting of receptors into late endosomes for degradation.
GluA1 ubiquitination regulates receptor stability at synapses.
The physiological significance of GluA1 ubiquitination was previously unknown.
Researchers generated mice with a knock-in mutation (K868R) in the major GluA1 ubiquitination site.
The study investigated the role of GluA1 ubiquitination in synaptic plasticity, learning, and memory.
Male mice with the K868R mutation exhibited normal basal synaptic transmission.
These mice showed enhanced LTP.
The mutant mice displayed deficits in LTD.
The mice also exhibited deficits in short-term spatial memory.
Cognitive flexibility was impaired in the mutant mice.
The findings highlight the critical roles of GluA1 ubiquitination in bidirectional synaptic plasticity.
GluA1 ubiquitination is important for cognition in male mice.

original_abstract:
Amyloid β protein (Aβ) and tau are the main proteins implicated in causing Alzheimer's disease (AD).
These proteins are believed to trigger synaptic dysfunction before significant synaptic loss occurs in vulnerable circuits.
Soluble Aβ aggregates from AD brain are recognized as potent synaptotoxins.
Less is known about the synaptotoxicity of soluble tau from AD or other tauopathy patient brains.
Minimally manipulated patient-derived aqueous brain extracts contain more diffusible native forms of these proteins.
The study explores how intracerebral injection of Aβ and tau in aqueous brain extracts affects synaptic plasticity in the CA1 area of male rat hippocampus.
Aqueous extracts of certain AD brains acutely inhibited long-term potentiation (LTP) of synaptic transmission.
The inhibition of LTP required both Aβ and tau.
Tau-containing aqueous extracts from a Pick's disease (PiD) brain also impaired LTP.
Diffusible tau from either AD or PiD brain lowered the threshold for AD brain Aβ to inhibit LTP.
The disruption of LTP persisted for at least 2 weeks after a single injection.
The findings support a critical role for diffusible tau in causing rapid onset, persistent synaptic plasticity deficits.
The results also suggest that diffusible tau promotes Aβ-mediated synaptic dysfunction.

original_abstract:
Early-life stress (ELS) is a major risk factor for psychiatric disorders, especially after additional stress in later life.
Human and animal studies show ELS sensitizes individuals to subsequent stress.
The neurobiological basis of stress sensitization is largely unexplored.
The study hypothesized that ELS-induced stress sensitization would be detectable in neuronal ensembles.
Transgenic mice were used to tag, track, and manipulate experience-activated neurons.
In both male and female mice, ELS-activated neurons in the nucleus accumbens (NAc) were preferentially reactivated by adult stress.
ELS-activated neurons in the medial prefrontal cortex showed less reactivation than those in the NAc.
hM4Dis receptor was expressed in control or ELS-activated neurons of pups.
Chemogenetic inhibition of these neurons during adult stress was performed.
Inhibition of ELS-activated NAc neurons ameliorated social avoidance behavior following chronic social defeat stress in males.
Inhibition of control-tagged neurons did not affect social avoidance behavior.
The study provides evidence that ELS-induced stress hypersensitivity is encoded in corticolimbic neuronal ensembles.

original_abstract:
GABAergic neurons in the external globus pallidus (GPe) form a local synaptic network and fire autonomously.
Most GPe neurons receive continuous inhibitory synaptic input from 1 or 2 other GPe neurons in slice preparations.
The study investigated the effect of this synaptic barrage on firing rate and regularity of GPe neurons in male and female mice using perforated patch recordings.
Silencing parvalbumin-positive (PV+) GPe neurons by activating Archaerhodopsin current increased the firing rate and regularity of PV– neurons.
Silencing Npas1+ GPe neurons with Archaerhodopsin had minimal effects on Npas1– neuron firing.
Blocking spontaneous GABAergic synaptic input with gabazine replicated the effects of silencing PV+ neurons on Npas1+ neuron firing rate and regularity.
Gabazine had similar effects on PV+ neuron firing.
Conductance waveforms for dynamic clamp were constructed based on experimentally measured inhibitory postsynaptic conductance trains from 1 or 2 unitary local connections.
The simulated inhibition reproduced the effects on firing seen in the intact active network in slice preparations.
The number of unitary inputs was increased to match estimates of local network connectivity in vivo.
As few as 5 unitary inputs produced large increases in firing irregularity.
Firing rate was initially reduced, but PV+ neurons exhibited slow spike-frequency adaptation, partially restoring the rate despite sustained inhibition.
The study concludes that the irregular firing pattern of GPe neurons in vivo is largely due to the ongoing local inhibitory synaptic barrage produced by spontaneous firing of other GPe neurons.

original_abstract:
Stress impact on memory formation and expression is well-studied, especially regarding stress hormones.
Less is known about how stress dynamically affects brain circuitry to modulate memory.
Male C57BL6/J mice were used in an auditory fear conditioning model to examine this question.
The study focused on the impact of stress on dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (dmPFC) neurons, which play a role in probabilistic fear memory.
Paraventricular thalamus (PVT) neurons are robustly activated by acute restraining stress.
Elevated PVT activity during probabilistic fear memory expression increases spiking in dmPFC somatostatin neurons.
Increased somatostatin neuron activity suppresses spiking of dmPFC parvalbumin (PV) neurons.
This suppression reverts the usual low fear responses associated with probabilistic fear memory to high fear.
The modulation is dynamic and reversible, allowing the original memory to be preserved and modulated during expression.
Elevated PVT activity during fear conditioning impairs synaptic modifications in dmPFC PV-neurons.
This impairment abolishes the formation of probabilistic fear memory.
PVT functions as a stress sensor to modulate the formation and expression of aversive memory.
PVT modulates memory by tuning inhibitory functions in the prefrontal circuitry.

original_abstract:
The gustatory cortex (GC) in the insular cortex processes taste information for taste-guided behaviors and food intake.
GC activity is influenced by both oral gustatory stimuli and physiological states like hunger.
The specific cell types and molecular mechanisms responsible for GC abilities are unclear.
Glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1) is produced by neurons in the brain.
GLP-1 acts on GLP-1 receptor-expressing (GLP-1R+) neurons in several brain regions.
GLP-1R agonism suppresses homeostatic food intake and dampens the hedonic value of food in these brain regions.
Cells within the GC of mice express Glp1r mRNA.
Ex vivo brain slice recordings show that GC GLP-1R+ neurons are depolarized by the selective GLP-1R agonist, exendin-4.
Chemogenetic stimulation of GLP-1R+ neurons reduces homeostatic food intake.
Pharmacological stimulation of GC-GLP-1Rs also reduces homeostatic food intake.
GLP-1R agonism reduces food intake toward foods with differing fat contents in mice chronically maintained on specific fat content diets.
GC GLP-1R influences may depend on food palatability.
These results provide evidence for a specific cell population in the GC that may play roles in both homeostatic and hedonic food intake.
The study was conducted on mice of both sexes.

original_abstract:
Cognitive demand is thought to modulate pupil size and neural α (8–12 Hz) oscillatory power.
The relationship between these two measures under complex audiovisual-task conditions is unclear.
The study recorded pupil size and neural α power using electroencephalography.
Human participants of both sexes performed a visual multiple object-tracking task and an auditory gap detection task simultaneously.
Difficulties of the two tasks were manipulated independently.
Participants' performance decreased in accuracy and speed with increasing cognitive demand.
Pupil size increased with increasing difficulty for both auditory and visual tasks.
Parietal α power decreased with increasing difficulty in the visual task.
Parietal α power did not change with increasing difficulty in the auditory task.
Trial-by-trial fluctuations in pupil size were negatively correlated with α power, independent of task difficulty.
Difficulty-induced changes in pupil size and α power did not correlate.
The lack of correlation is consistent with their different cognitive-demand sensitivities.
The study demonstrates that neurophysiological indices of cognitive demand and associated effort are multifaceted.
The dynamics of these indices are potentially modality-dependent under complex audiovisual-task conditions.

original_abstract:
Huntington's disease (HD) is an autosomal-dominant neurodegenerative disease.
HD is characterized by progressive motor and cognitive impairments.
No disease-modifying therapies are currently available for HD.
HD pathophysiology involves impairment in glutamatergic neurotransmission.
HD leads to severe striatal neurodegeneration.
The vesicular glutamate transporter-3 (VGLUT3) regulates the striatal network affected by HD.
Current evidence on VGLUT3's role in HD pathophysiology is lacking.
Researchers crossed VGLUT3-deficient mice with a mouse model of HD (zQ175:VGLUT3–/–).
Motor and cognitive functions were assessed from 6 to 15 months of age.
VGLUT3 deletion rescues motor coordination deficits in zQ175 mice.
VGLUT3 deletion rescues short-term memory deficits in zQ175 mice.
The rescue effects were observed in both male and female zQ175 mice.
VGLUT3 deletion rescues neuronal loss in zQ175 mice.
The rescue of neuronal loss is likely via activation of Akt and ERK1/2 in the striatum.
The rescue in neuronal survival is accompanied by a reduction in nuclear mutant huntingtin (mHTT) aggregates.
There is no change in total aggregate levels or microgliosis in zQ175:VGLUT3–/– mice.
VGLUT3 can be a vital contributor to HD pathophysiology despite its limited expression.
VGLUT3 is a viable target for HD therapeutics.

original_abstract:
Heroin addiction has a devastating impact on society, with limited understanding of its neurobiology.
Drug addiction generally involves excessive salience attribution to drug cues and reduced inhibitory control.
Inhibitory control alterations often result in prefrontal cortex (PFC) hypoactivations across various drugs of abuse.
The study used a stop-signal fMRI task to map inhibitory control in 41 individuals with heroin use disorder (iHUDs) and 24 matched healthy controls (HCs).
Both groups showed similar stop-signal response time (SSRT), a classic measure of inhibitory control.
iHUDs exhibited impaired target detection sensitivity compared to HCs.
iHUDs showed lower activity in the right anterior PFC (aPFC) and dorsolateral PFC (dlPFC) during successful versus failed stops.
Lower left dlPFC/supplementary motor area (SMA) activity was associated with slower SSRT specifically in iHUDs.
Lower left aPFC activity correlated with worse target sensitivity across all participants.
In iHUDs, lower left SMA activity during inhibitory control was associated with shorter time since last heroin use.
Lower left aPFC activity in iHUDs was associated with higher severity of dependence.
Results revealed lower perceptual sensitivity and hypoactivations in cognitive control regions (aPFC, dlPFC, SMA) during inhibitory control in iHUDs.
These neurobehavioral deficits were associated with task performance and heroin use severity measures.
The identified inhibitory control deficits may contribute to self-control lapses in heroin addiction.
These deficits could serve as targets for prevention and intervention efforts to enhance recovery in heroin addiction.

Higher left aPFC activity correlated with better target sensitivity across all participants.
In iHUDs, higher left SMA activity during inhibitory control was associated with shorter time since last heroin use.
Higher left aPFC activity in iHUDs was associated with higher severity of dependence.
Results revealed higher perceptual sensitivity and hyperactivations in cognitive control regions (aPFC, dlPFC, SMA) during inhibitory control in iHUDs.
These neurobehavioral deficits were associated with task performance and heroin use severity measures.
The identified inhibitory control deficits may contribute to self-control lapses in heroin addiction.
These deficits could serve as targets for prevention and intervention efforts to enhance recovery in heroin addiction.

original_abstract:
Individuals with autism often show atypical sensory perception.
The neural basis for these perceptual differences is not fully understood.
One proposed mechanism is an imbalance in higher-order feedback inputs to early sensory cortices.
This imbalance may lead to increased focus on local object features over global context.
The study explored this theory by measuring visual evoked potentials during contour integration.
Contour integration processes are largely driven by feedback inputs from higher-order ventral visual stream regions.
The hypothesis was that autistic individuals would have attenuated evoked responses to illusory contours compared to neurotypical controls.
29 autistic and 31 neurotypical children (7-17 years old, both males and females) participated in the study.
Participants passively viewed a series of Kanizsa figure stimuli during electrophysiology acquisition.
Stimuli consisted of four inducers aligned either randomly or to form an illusory square.
Autistic children showed attenuated automatic contour integration over lateral occipital regions compared to neurotypical controls.
Results are discussed in terms of predictive feedback processes on perception of global stimulus features.
The study suggests weakened "priors" may play a role in visual processing anomalies in autism.

original_abstract:
Temporal discounting (TD) is the mental devaluation of delayed rewards.
The role of the hippocampus in TD is unclear due to discrepancies between animal and human studies.
Animals with hippocampal lesions show impaired TD.
Human participants with similar lesions perform normally on classic intertemporal choice tasks.
A possible explanation for this discrepancy is that animal studies involve experiencing delays and rewards, while human studies typically use hypothetical scenarios.
The study tested this hypothesis using amnesic participants with hippocampal lesions (one female, six males).
Participants completed a novel experiential intertemporal choice task using occluded photographs as rewards.
Performance was compared to a classic intertemporal choice task with hypothetical outcomes.
A logistic function was used to model indifference points data.
Participants with hippocampal lesions showed impaired choices in the experiential task.
No impairment was observed in the hypothetical task.
Hippocampal lesions were associated with decreased amplitude of the delay-reward trade-off.
Participants with lesions persistently chose the delayed option despite delay increases.
Results help explain previous discrepancies between animal and human studies.
The hippocampus plays a critical role in temporal discounting when outcomes are experienced in the moment.
The hippocampus may not be critical for temporal discounting with hypothetical outcomes.

original_abstract:
Functional heterogeneity of hippocampal CA3 pyramidal neurons is a key aspect of circuit function.
Study explored effects of long-term cholinergic activity on functional heterogeneity of CA3 pyramidal neurons.
Experiments conducted using organotypic slices from male rat brains.
Application of AChR and mAChR agonists induced robust increases in network activity in the low-gamma range.
Prolonged AChR stimulation for 48 hours uncovered a population of hyperadapting CA3 pyramidal neurons.
Hyperadapting neurons typically fired a single, early action potential in response to current injection.
Hyperadapting neurons were present in control networks but increased dramatically after long-term cholinergic activity.
Hyperadapting neurons were characterized by the presence of a strong M-current.
Hyperadaptation phenotype was abolished by acute application of M-channel antagonists.
Hyperadaptation phenotype was also abolished by reapplication of AChR agonists.
Long-term mAChR activation modulates the intrinsic excitability of a subset of CA3 pyramidal cells.
Study uncovered a highly plastic cohort of neurons sensitive to chronic ACh modulation.
Findings provide evidence for activity-dependent plasticity of functional heterogeneity in the hippocampus.

original_abstract:
The perforant path is the primary cortical excitatory input to the hippocampus.
Entorhinal projections to the dentate gyrus have been extensively studied due to their role in information processing and coding.
Synaptic transmission between individual connected pairs of entorhinal stellate cells and dentate granule cells has not been fully characterized.
Mouse organotypic entorhino-hippocampal tissue cultures were used to study entorhinal cortex (EC) to dentate granule cell (GC) projections.
Whole-cell patch-clamp recordings were used to study EC-GC pairs.
Properties of EC-GC synapses from lateral and medial entorhinal cortex were compared using wild-type mouse cultures.
Differences in short-term plasticity were identified between lateral and medial EC-GC synapses.
The perforant path is severely affected in Alzheimer's disease.
Tissue cultures from amyloid precursor protein (APP)-deficient mice were used to examine APP's role at EC-GC synapses.
APP deficiency altered excitatory neurotransmission at medial perforant path synapses.
Transcriptomic and ultrastructural changes were observed in APP-deficient tissue cultures.
Presynaptic APP deletion through local injection of Cre-expressing adeno-associated viruses in conditional APPflox/flox tissue cultures increased neurotransmission efficacy at perforant path synapses.
Postsynaptic APP deletion did not affect neurotransmission efficacy.
The data suggests a physiological role for presynaptic APP at medial perforant path synapses.
Altered APP processing conditions may adversely affect the physiological role of presynaptic APP at medial perforant path synapses.

original_abstract:
Alcohol use disorder is complex and involves multiple signaling systems across various brain regions.
Previous research indicates that the insular cortex and dynorphin (DYN)/kappa opioid receptor (KOR) systems contribute to excessive alcohol use.
A microcircuit in the medial insular cortex that signals through DYN/KOR was recently identified.
This study explored the role of insula DYN/KOR circuit components on alcohol intake using a long-term intermittent access (IA) procedure.
The research used conditional knock-out strategies and site-directed pharmacology.
Distinct and sex-specific roles for insula DYN and KOR in alcohol drinking and related behavior were discovered.
Insula DYN deletion blocked escalated consumption and decreased overall intake and preference for alcohol in male and female mice.
In male mice, DYN deletion did not impact sucrose intake, indicating the effect was specific to alcohol.
Insula KOR antagonism reduced alcohol intake and preference during the early phase of IA in male mice only.
Alcohol consumption was not affected by insula KOR knockout in either sex.
Long-term IA decreased the intrinsic excitability of DYN and deep layer pyramidal neurons (DLPNs) in the insula of male mice.
IA drove an increase in excitatory synaptic drive in both DYN neurons and DLPNs.
The findings suggest a dynamic interplay between excessive alcohol consumption and insula DYN/KOR microcircuitry.

original_abstract:
Mouse ultrasonic vocalizations (USVs) contain predictable sequential structures similar to bird songs and speech.
Neural representation of USVs in the mouse primary auditory cortex (Au1) has been largely studied with single-syllables or dyads.
Previous studies using USV sequences playback have used randomly selected sequences.
This study uses mutual-information to obtain context-specific natural sequences (NSeqs) of USV syllables.
NSeqs capture the observed predictability in male USVs during different contexts of social interaction with females.
Behavioral and physiological significance of NSeqs over random sequences (RSeqs) were examined.
Female mice without prior male exposure showed higher selectivity for NSeqs behaviorally and at cellular levels.
Cellular selectivity was probed by expression of immediate early gene c-fos in Au1.
Au1 supragranular single-units showed higher selectivity to NSeqs over RSeqs.
Social-experience-driven plasticity in encoding NSeqs and RSeqs was examined in adult females.
Neural selectivities to the same sequences were compared before and after social experience.
Single-units showed enhanced selectivity for NSeqs over RSeqs after social experience.
2-photon Ca2+ imaging revealed social experience dependent changes in selectivity of excitatory and somatostatin-positive inhibitory neurons.
Parvalbumin-positive inhibitory neurons did not show changes in selectivity.
Optogenetics identified somatostatin-positive neurons as a possible mediator of social-experience-driven plasticity.
The study highlights the importance of predictive sequences in mouse USVs.
Mouse USVs are introduced as a promising model to study context-dependent speech-like communications.

original_abstract:
SUDEP has been linked to respiratory dysfunction, but mechanisms are unclear.
Focal and generalized convulsive seizures in epilepsy patients cause prolonged decrease in HCVR.
Study examined Scn1aR1407X/+ (Dravet syndrome) and Scn8aN1768D/+ mice of both sexes.
Convulsive seizures in these mice caused postictal decrease in ventilation and depressed HCVR in some animals.
Mice with severe postictal depression of HCVR also showed transient postictal hypothermia.
Blunted HCVR and abnormal thermoregulation occur with dysfunction of the serotonin system in mice.
Depleting 5-HT with PCPA mimicked seizure-induced hypoventilation in mice.
PCPA partially occluded postictal decrease in HCVR, exacerbated hypothermia, and increased postictal mortality in DS mice.
Pretreatment with 5-HT agonist fenfluramine reduced postictal inhibition of HCVR and hypothermia.
Results suggest seizures cause transient impairment of serotonergic neuron function.
Serotonergic neuron impairment would inhibit respiratory control aspects dependent on 5-HT.
Findings support investigating interictal and/or postictal HCVR as noninvasive biomarkers for high-risk individuals.
Results suggest preventing SUDEP by enhancing postictal 5-HT tone.

Convulsive seizures in these mice caused postictal increase in ventilation and elevated HCVR in some animals.
Mice with severe postictal enhancement of HCVR also showed transient postictal hyperthermia.

PCPA partially occluded postictal increase in HCVR, exacerbated hyperthermia, and increased postictal mortality in DS mice.

Results suggest seizures cause transient impairment of serotonergic neuron function.

original_abstract:
Early-life stress (ELS) induces cognitive deficits during developmental critical periods (CPs).
ELS alters neural circuitry in regions responsible for learning, memory, and attention.
Mechanisms of critical period plasticity are shared by sensory cortices and higher neural regions.
Sensory processing may be vulnerable to ELS.
Perception and auditory cortical (ACx) encoding of temporally-varying sounds mature gradually into adolescence.
There is an extended postnatal window of susceptibility for auditory processing.
A model of ELS was developed in the Mongolian gerbil to study temporal processing effects.
ELS impaired behavioral detection of short gaps in sound in both male and female gerbils.
Short gaps in sound are critical for speech perception.
Reduced neural responses to gaps were observed in auditory cortex, auditory periphery, and auditory brainstem.
ELS degrades the fidelity of sensory representations available to higher regions.
ELS-induced degradation of sensory representations could contribute to known problems with cognition.

original_abstract:
The paraventricular nucleus of the thalamus (PVT) is involved in drug addiction–related behaviors.
Morphine is a widely used opioid for severe pain relief.
Morphine acts via opioid receptors.
The function of opioid receptors in the PVT has not been fully elucidated.
In vitro electrophysiology was used to study neuronal activity and synaptic transmission in the PVT of male and female mice.
Activation of opioid receptors suppresses the firing of PVT neurons in brain slices.
Activation of opioid receptors suppresses inhibitory synaptic transmission of PVT neurons in brain slices.
Chronic morphine exposure reduces the involvement of opioid modulation.
Reduced opioid modulation is likely due to desensitization and internalization of opioid receptors in the PVT.
The opioid system is essential for the modulation of PVT activities.

original_abstract:
Most current neuromodulation methods target the cortex.
Approaches for inducing plasticity in subcortical motor pathways could boost recovery after damage.
The study paired loud acoustic stimulation (LAS) with transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) over the motor cortex in healthy humans.
LAS activates the reticular formation, while TMS activates descending systems, including corticoreticular fibers.
200 paired stimuli were used, with a 50 ms interstimulus interval.
Responses in the contralateral biceps muscle to TMS alone were measured before and after stimulus pairing.
TMS responses were enhanced 10, 20, and 30 minutes after stimulus pairing, indicating LTP induction.
Control experiments using 200 unpaired TMS or LAS showed no long-term changes.
No changes were observed in responses to direct corticospinal stimulation at the medulla level.
No changes were seen in the extent of reaction time shortening by a loud sound (StartReact effect).
Results suggest plasticity did not occur in corticospinal or reticulospinal synapses.
Direct measurements in female monkeys undergoing a similar protocol showed no enhancement of corticospinal volleys.
Results suggest no changes occurred in intracortical connections.
The most likely substrate for plastic changes is an increase in the efficacy of corticoreticular connections.
This new protocol may target different motor circuits compared to other available paradigms.
The study included both male and female participants.

original_abstract:
SSRIs are the most commonly prescribed treatment for major depressive disorder.
The therapeutic mechanisms of SSRIs are poorly understood.
No studies exist on the cellular and subcellular pharmacokinetic properties of SSRIs in living cells.
Researchers studied escitalopram and fluoxetine using new intensity-based, drug-sensing fluorescent reporters.
The reporters were targeted to the plasma membrane, cytoplasm, or endoplasmic reticulum (ER) of cultured neurons and mammalian cell lines.
Chemical detection of drugs within cells and phospholipid membranes was also used.
The drugs reach equilibrium in neuronal cytoplasm and ER at approximately the same concentration as the externally applied solution.
Escitalopram reaches equilibrium with time constants of a few seconds.
Fluoxetine reaches equilibrium with time constants of 200-300 seconds.
The drugs accumulate within lipid membranes by ≥18-fold for escitalopram.
The drugs accumulate within lipid membranes by 180-fold for fluoxetine.
Both drugs leave cytoplasm, lumen, and membranes quickly during washout.
Researchers synthesized membrane-impermeant quaternary amine derivatives of the two SSRIs.
The quaternary derivatives are substantially excluded from membrane, cytoplasm, and ER for >2.4 hours.
The quaternary derivatives inhibit SERT transport-associated currents sixfold less potently for escitalopram derivative.
The quaternary derivatives inhibit SERT transport-associated currents 11-fold less potently for fluoxetine derivative.
The quaternary derivatives provide useful probes for distinguishing compartmentalized SSRI effects.
The measurements are orders of magnitude faster than the therapeutic lag of SSRIs.
The data suggest that SSRI-SERT interactions within organelles or membranes may play roles during therapeutic effects.
The data suggest that SSRI-SERT interactions within organelles or membranes may play roles during antidepressant discontinuation syndrome.

original_abstract:
Sleep loss affects the human brain at multiple levels.
Age-related changes in sleep characteristics indicate reduced sleep quality is common in aging.
Sleep disruption may accelerate the aging process.
The study investigates whether sleep loss causes age-related changes in the brain using a brain age approach.
The study included MRI data from 134 healthy volunteers aged 19-39 years (mean age 25.3, 42 females/92 males).
Data came from five datasets with different sleep conditions.
Total sleep deprivation (>24 hours of wakefulness) increased brain age by 1-2 years across three datasets.
Brain age returned to baseline after one night of recovery sleep.
Changes in brain age after total sleep deprivation were associated with sleep variables during recovery night.
Acute partial sleep restriction (3 hours time-in-bed for one night) did not significantly change brain age.
Chronic partial sleep restriction (5 hours time-in-bed for five continuous nights) did not significantly change brain age.
Findings suggest acute total sleep loss changes brain morphology in an aging-like direction in young participants.
The aging-like changes in brain morphology are reversible with recovery sleep.

original_abstract:
People view social feedback as interconnected with potential impacts on their entire self-concept.
The study presents a network model describing how the brain represents semantic dependency relations among traits.
The model explains how the brain uses this information to maintain positivity and coherence across the self-concept while updating self-views.
Both male and female participants received social feedback during a self-evaluation task while undergoing functional magnetic resonance imaging.
A reinforcement learning model was incorporated within the network structure to model self-belief updating.
Participants learned more quickly from positive feedback than negative feedback.
Participants were less likely to change self-views for traits with more dependencies in the network.
Feedback was back propagated across network relations by participants.
Prior feedback was retrieved based on network similarity to inform ongoing self-views.
Ventromedial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC) activation reflected the constrained updating process.
Positive feedback led to higher vmPFC activation for traits with more dependencies.
Negative feedback led to less vmPFC activation for traits with more dependencies.
vmPFC activation was associated with the novelty of a trait relative to previously self-evaluated traits in the network.
Angular gyrus activation was associated with greater certainty for self-beliefs given the relevance of prior feedback.
The study proposes that neural computations selectively enhance or attenuate social feedback.
These neural computations also retrieve past relevant experiences to guide ongoing self-evaluations.
These processes may support an overall positive and coherent self-concept.
