original_abstract:
Reinforcement learning (RL) models explain animal choices through value assignment and updating based on reward outcomes.
RL models have identified fundamental learning variables and their neuronal implementations.
Canonical RL models do not explain how reward values are constructed from intrinsic reward components like nutrients.
From an ecological perspective, animals should adapt foraging choices to acquire essential nutrients in dynamic environments.
The study investigated how male monkeys adapt choices to obtain preferred nutrient rewards under varying reward probabilities.
Nutrient composition of rewards strongly influenced learning and choices.
Monkeys' preferences for specific nutrients (sugar, fat) affected their adaptation to changing reward probabilities.

original_abstract:

The second experiment was preregistered.

original_abstract:
Effective rehabilitation in Parkinson's disease (PD) is related to brain reorganization, involving cortico–subcortical network restoration and frontoparietal network compensation.
Further neural rehabilitation evidence from a multidimensional perspective is needed.
A study investigated how multidisciplinary intensive rehabilitation treatment affects neurovascular coupling in PD.
31 PD patients (20 female) and 30 healthy controls (17 female) participated in the study.
Participants underwent blood oxygenation level-dependent functional magnetic resonance imaging and arterial spin labeling scans.
Cerebral blood flow (CBF) was used to measure perfusion.
Fractional amplitude of low-frequency fluctuation (fALFF) was used to measure neural activity.
Neurovascular coupling was calculated using global CBF–fALFF correlation and regional CBF/fALFF ratio.
Dynamic causal modeling (DCM) evaluated treatment-related alterations in the strength and directionality of information flow.
Treatment reduced CBF–fALFF correlations.
Altered CBF/fALFF showed increases in the left angular gyrus and right inferior parietal gyrus.
Altered CBF/fALFF showed decreases in the bilateral thalamus and right superior frontal gyrus.
CBF/fALFF alteration in the right superior frontal gyrus correlated with motor improvement.
DCM indicated increased connectivity from the superior frontal gyrus to the inferior parietal gyrus.
DCM indicated decreased connectivity from the thalamus to the inferior parietal gyrus.
Rehabilitation benefits were reflected in a dual mechanism.
Restoration of executive control occurred in the initial phase of motor learning.
Compensation of information integration occurred in the latter phase.
Findings provide multimodal insights into the role of rehabilitation in disease modification.
The dorsolateral superior frontal gyrus was identified as a potential target for noninvasive neuromodulation in PD.

original_abstract:
Glioblastoma is the most common malignant primary brain tumor with poor overall survival.
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the main imaging modality for glioblastoma but has limitations.
The molecular and cellular basis of MR signals is not fully understood.
Researchers established a ground truth-based image analysis platform to coregister MRI and light sheet microscopy (LSM) data.
The platform aligns data to an anatomic reference atlas for quantification of 20 predefined anatomic subregions.
The pipeline includes segmentation and quantification of single myeloid cells in entire LSM datasets.
The method was applied to three preclinical glioma models in male and female mice: GL261, U87MG, and S24.
These models exhibit different key features of human glioma.
Multiparametric MR data was acquired, including T2-weighted sequences, diffusion tensor imaging, T2 and T2* relaxometry.
LSM analysis focused on tumor cell density, microvasculature, and innate immune cell infiltration after tissue clearing.
Correlated analysis revealed differences in quantitative MRI metrics between tumor-bearing and contralateral hemispheres.
LSM identified tumor subregions with different MRI characteristics, indicating tumor heterogeneity.
MRI signatures, defined as unique combinations of different MRI parameters, differed greatly between the models.
Direct correlation of MRI and LSM allows in-depth characterization of preclinical glioma.
The approach can decipher the structural, cellular, and potentially molecular basis of tumoral MRI biomarkers.
The method may be applied to other preclinical brain tumor or neurologic disease models.
Derived MRI signatures could inform image interpretation in clinical settings.

original_abstract:
Neocortical layer 1 (L1) consists of distal dendrites of pyramidal cells and GABAergic interneurons (INs).
L1 receives extensive long-range "top-down" projections.
L1 INs remain poorly understood.
The study systematically examined distinct dominant electrophysiological features of four unique IN subtypes in L1.
The four IN subtypes were previously identified from mice of either gender.
Canopy cells show an irregular firing pattern near rheobase.
Neurogliaform cells are late-spiking and their firing rate accelerates during current injections.
Cells with strong expression of the α7 nicotinic receptor (α7 cells) display onset (rebound) bursting.
Vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) expressing cells exhibit high input resistance, strong adaptation, and irregular firing.
Computational modeling explained these diverse neurophysiological features using an extended exponential-integrate-and-fire neuron model.
The model varied contributions of a slowly inactivating K+ channel, a T-type Ca2+ channel, and a spike-triggered Ca2+-dependent K+ channel.
Irregular firing results from square-wave bursting, as shown through a fast-slow analysis.
Irregular firing is frequently observed in VIP cells due to the interaction between strong adaptation and a slowly inactivating K+ channel.
The VIP and α7 cell models resonate with alpha/theta band input, as revealed through a dynamic gain analysis.

original_abstract:
Brain pH is critical for determining neuronal activity.
Alkalosis increases neuronal excitability.
Acidosis reduces neuronal excitability.
Breathing carbogen (5% CO2/95% O2) reduces seizure susceptibility in animal models and patients.
The molecular mechanisms of seizure protection by carbogen are not fully understood.
Male and female mice exposed to carbogen are fully protected from thermogenic-triggered seizures.

Acid shifts do not alter firing in hippocampal inhibitory interneurons.
Acidification reduced simulated action potential firing in hybrid model neurons expressing NaV1.2 channel.
Acidification had no effect on action potential firing in hybrid model neurons expressing NaV1.1 channel.
Knockdown of Scn2a mRNA in vivo reduced the protective effects of carbogen on seizure susceptibility.
Carbogen-mediated seizure protection and reduced CA1 pyramidal neuron firing were maintained in Asic1a knock-out mice.
Asic1a is ruled out as the underlying molecular target for acid-mediated effects.
Acid-mediated reduction in excitatory neuron firing is mediated, at least partly, through inhibition of NaV1.2 channels.
Inhibitory neuron firing is unaffected by acidification.
The reduction in pyramidal neuron excitability is likely the basis of seizure suppression caused by carbogen-mediated acidification.

original_abstract:
Fast cholinergic neurotransmission is mediated by acetylcholine-gated ion channels.
Excitatory nicotinic acetylcholine receptors play well-established roles in virtually all nervous systems.
Acetylcholine-gated inhibitory channels have been identified in some invertebrate phyla.
The roles of acetylcholine-gated inhibitory channels in the nervous system are less well understood.
Multiple new inhibitory ion channels with diverse ligand activation properties were discovered in Caenorhabditis elegans.
Three channels were identified: LGC-40, LGC-57, and LGC-58, whose primary ligand is choline rather than acetylcholine.
The first evidence of a truly polymodal channel, LGC-39, was found, which is activated by both cholinergic and aminergic ligands.
Single neurons in the hermaphrodite nervous system express both excitatory and inhibitory channels.
The expression of excitatory and inhibitory channels applies not only to acetylcholine but also to other major neurotransmitters.
The study offers new insight into the potential evolutionary benefit of a vast and diverse repertoire of ligand-gated ion channels.
The diverse repertoire of ligand-gated ion channels may generate complexity in an anatomically compact nervous system.

original_abstract:
Older adults exposed to enriched environments (EE) maintain higher cognitive function levels despite compromised brain health markers.
Response speed (RS) is often used as a simple proxy to measure global cognitive function preservation in older adults.
It is unknown which specific selection, decision, and/or motor processes provide the most specific indices of neurocognitive health.
A study using a simple decision task with electroencephalography (EEG) was conducted.
The efficiency of sensory evidence accumulation was found to be a critical determinant of RS preservation in older adults.
The study participants were 63% female and 37% male.
The mitigating influence of EE on age-related RS declines was most pronounced when evidence accumulation rates were shallowest.
Results suggest that cognitive reserve is applicable to neurophysiological markers, not just neuroanatomical indicators of brain aging.
Cognitive reserve allows high EE individuals to better tolerate suboptimal brain health and preserve cognitive function.
EEG metrics of evidence accumulation may index neurocognitive vulnerability of the aging brain.

original_abstract:
Synaptic changes play a major role in memory processes.
Modulation of synaptic responses by brain states in hippocampal networks is poorly understood in basal conditions.
Evoked synaptic responses were recorded at five hippocampal pathways in freely moving male rats.
At the perforant path to dentate gyrus (PP-DG) synapse, responses increase during wakefulness compared with sleep.
At the Schaffer collaterals to CA1 (SC-CA1) synapse, responses increase during non-REM sleep (NREM) compared with other states.
At the fornix to nucleus accumbens synapse (Fx-NAc), responses decreased during REM sleep compared with other states.
Responses at the fornix to medial PFC synapse (Fx-PFC) and fornix to amygdala synapse (Fx-Amy) were weakly modulated by vigilance states.
Extended sleep periods led to synaptic changes at PP-DG and Fx-Amy synapses but not at other synapses.
Synaptic responses were linked to local oscillations.
Synaptic responses were highly correlated between Fx-PFC and Fx-NAc.
Synaptic responses were not highly correlated between Fx-Amy and Fx-PFC/Fx-NAc synapses.
These results reveal synapse-specific modulations that may contribute to memory consolidation during the sleep-wake cycle.

original_abstract:
Reward prediction error (RPE) signals are crucial for reinforcement learning and decision-making.
RPE signals quantify the mismatch between predicted and obtained rewards.
RPE signals are encoded in the neural activity of multiple brain areas, including midbrain dopaminergic neurons, prefrontal cortex, and striatum.
The expression of RPE signals through anatomically and functionally distinct subregions of the striatum is not fully understood.
The study examined the extent of RPE signal representation across different striatal regions.
Local field potentials (LFPs) were recorded in sensorimotor, associative, and limbic striatal territories of two male rhesus monkeys.
The monkeys performed a free-choice probabilistic learning task.
A reinforcement learning model was used to estimate the trial-by-trial evolution of RPE during task performance.
Changes in beta band oscillations (15–35 Hz) after the outcome of the animal's choice are consistent with RPE encoding.
RPE-related signals are more strongly represented in the ventral (limbic) than dorsal (sensorimotor and associative) part of the striatum.
The results suggest a relationship between striatal beta oscillations and the evaluation of outcomes based on RPE signals.
The study highlights a major contribution of the ventral striatum to the updating of learning processes.

original_abstract:
Ethanol tolerance is the first type of behavioral and neural plasticity induced by ethanol intake.
The molecular and circuit bases of ethanol tolerance remain largely unexplored.
Three distinct forms of ethanol tolerance in male Drosophila are characterized: rapid, chronic, and repeated.
Rapid tolerance consists of two short-lived memory-like states: one labile and one consolidated.
Chronic tolerance is induced by continuous exposure and lasts for 2 days.
Chronic tolerance induces ethanol preference.
Chronic tolerance hinders the development of rapid tolerance through histone deacetylase (HDAC) activity.
Chronic tolerance is independent of the immediate early gene Hr38/Nr4a, unlike rapid tolerance.
Chronic tolerance is suppressed by the sirtuin HDAC Sirt1.
Rapid tolerance is enhanced by Sirt1.
Rapid and chronic tolerance map to anatomically distinct regions of the mushroom body learning and memory centers.
Chronic tolerance, like long-term memory, depends on new protein synthesis.
Chronic tolerance induces the kayak/c-fos immediate early gene.
Chronic tolerance depends on CREB signaling outside the mushroom bodies.
Chronic tolerance does not require the Radish GTPase.
Chronic ethanol exposure creates an ethanol-specific memory-like state.
The ethanol-specific memory-like state induced by chronic exposure is molecularly and anatomically different from other forms of ethanol tolerance.

original_abstract:
Activity-dependent plasticity of synapses is believed to be the cellular basis of learning.
Synaptic changes are mediated through local biochemical reactions in synapses and changes in gene transcription in the nucleus.
These changes modulate neuronal circuits and behavior.
The protein kinase C (PKC) family of isozymes is critical for synaptic plasticity.
The role of the novel subfamily of PKC isozymes is largely unknown due to a lack of isozyme-specific tools.
Fluorescence lifetime imaging-fluorescence resonance energy transfer activity sensors were developed to investigate novel PKC isozymes.
The study focused on synaptic plasticity in CA1 pyramidal neurons of mice of either sex.
PKCδ is activated downstream of TrkB and DAG production.
The spatiotemporal nature of PKCδ activation depends on the plasticity stimulation.
In single-spine plasticity, PKCδ is activated primarily in the stimulated spine.
PKCδ is required for local expression of plasticity in single-spine stimulation.
In multispine stimulation, PKCδ activation is long-lasting and spreading.
The activation of PKCδ in multispine stimulation scales with the number of spines stimulated.
PKCδ regulates cAMP response-element binding protein activity.
PKCδ couples spine plasticity to transcription in the nucleus during multispine stimulation.
PKCδ plays a dual functional role in facilitating synaptic plasticity.

original_abstract:
Astrocytes play an indispensable role in the neurovascular unit.
Few studies have investigated the functional impact of astrocyte signaling in cognitive decline and dementia related to vascular pathology.
Diet-mediated induction of hyperhomocysteinemia (HHcy) recapitulates features of vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID).
The study used astrocyte targeting approaches to evaluate astrocyte Ca2+ dysregulation in male and female HHcy diet mice.
Two-photon imaging in awake mice revealed activity-dependent Ca2+ dysregulation in barrel cortex astrocytes under HHcy.
Stimulation of contralateral whiskers elicited larger Ca2+ transients in individual astrocytes of HHcy diet mice compared to control diet mice.
Evoked Ca2+ signaling across astrocyte networks was impaired in HHcy mice.
HHcy was associated with increased activation of the Ca2+/calcineurin-dependent transcription factor NFAT4.
NFAT4 has been linked to the reactive astrocyte phenotype and synapse dysfunction in amyloid and brain injury models.
Targeting the NFAT inhibitor VIVIT to astrocytes using adeno-associated virus vectors reduced GFAP promoter activity in HHcy diet mice.
VIVIT targeting improved functional hyperemia in arterioles and capillaries.
VIVIT expression in astrocytes preserved CA1 synaptic function.
VIVIT expression improved spontaneous alternation performance on the Y maze.
The results demonstrate that aberrant astrocyte signaling can impair cerebral vessel regulation and synaptic regulation.
Aberrant astrocyte signaling may represent a promising drug target for treating VCID, Alzheimer's disease, and other related dementias.

original_abstract:
Comorbidities, including cognitive deficits, often accompany epilepsies as a basal state.
Seizures are rare and transient events in epilepsy.
Neural dynamics supporting cognitive function are likely altered permanently in epilepsy.
The study tests the hypothesis that primitive information processing is altered in the hippocampus and entorhinal cortex in experimental epilepsy.
The experiment was conducted on adult, male Wistar rats.
Information storage and sharing are organized into substates across slow and theta oscillations in both epilepsy and control conditions.
The internal composition and organization of information processing are disrupted in epilepsy.
Epilepsy partially loses brain state selectivity compared to controls.
Information processing in epilepsy shifts towards a regimen of disorder.
The alteration of information processing at the algorithmic level of computation may be a mechanism behind widespread comorbidities in epilepsy.
This alteration occurs at a theoretical intermediate level between structure and function.

original_abstract:
Cortical computations emerge from neuronal dynamics in complex cortical circuits.
Neuronal ensembles are subnetworks with shared functional connectivity that form through experience.
Ensembles were induced in ex vivo cortical circuits from mice using chronic optogenetic stimulation.
A decrease in voltage correlation was observed between stimulated and nonstimulated populations.
Synaptic decoupling occurred between stimulated and nonstimulated populations.
The stimulated population showed a decrease in firing rate during Up-states.
Ensemble-specific changes included decreased intrinsic excitability in the stimulated population.
Connectivity between stimulated and nonstimulated pyramidal neurons decreased.
A spiking neural network model incorporated observed changes in intrinsic excitability and connectivity.
The model showed that changes in both intrinsic excitability and connectivity accounted for decreased firing rate.
Only changes in connectivity accounted for the observed decorrelation in the model.
Findings reveal mechanisms of how chronic patterned stimulation creates ensembles in cortical circuits.
Up-states are a global network-wide phenomenon.
Functionally distinct ensembles can maintain their identity during Up-states through differential firing rates and correlations.

original_abstract:
Language comprehension requires rapid retrieval and integration of contextually appropriate concepts, known as "semantic cognition".
Current neurobiological models of semantic cognition are limited by spatial and temporal restrictions of single-modality neuroimaging and lesion approaches.
The study used fused functional magnetic resonance imaging and electroencephalography analysis in 26 adult humans (15 females).
The research elucidates a temporally and spatially specific neurobiological model for real-time semantic cognition.
Semantic cognition in language comprehension is supported by trade-offs between widespread neural networks over milliseconds.
The study incorporated spatial and temporal characteristics, as well as behavioral measures.
A hippocampal/anterior temporal phonological semantic retrieval network peaks at ~300 ms after the sentence final word.
A frontotemporal thematic semantic network activates at ~400 ms.
A hippocampal memory update network activates at ~500 ms.
An inferior frontal semantic syntactic reappraisal network activates at ~600 ms.
Nodes of the default mode network associated with conceptual coherence activate at ~750 ms.
In typical adults, mediatory relationships among these networks significantly predict language comprehension ability.
The findings provide a conceptual and methodological framework for examining speech and language disorders.
The study has implications for characterizing cognitive processes and clinical populations in other cognitive domains.

original_abstract:
Opioid exposure and withdrawal cause adaptations in brain circuits that may contribute to abuse liability.
Adaptations vary in magnitude and direction following different patterns of opioid exposure.
Few studies have systematically manipulated opioid administration patterns while measuring neurobiological impact.
This study compared cellular and synaptic adaptations in the nucleus accumbens shell caused by continuous morphine exposure versus exposure interrupted by daily naloxone-precipitated withdrawal.
Continuous morphine administration caused psychomotor tolerance.
Psychomotor tolerance was reversed when morphine action continuity was interrupted by naloxone-precipitated withdrawal.
Ex vivo slice electrophysiology was used in female and male mice to investigate how morphine administration patterns altered intrinsic excitability and synaptic plasticity of medium spiny neurons (MSNs).
MSNs expressing D1 or D2 dopamine receptors were studied.
Morphine-evoked adaptations at excitatory synapses were predominantly conserved between administration patterns.
Divergent effects were observed on inhibitory synapses and the balance between excitatory and inhibitory synaptic input.
Continuous morphine administration produced adaptations that dampen D1-MSN output.
D1-MSNs are canonically thought to promote reward-related behaviors.
Interruption of continuous morphine exposure does not dampen D1-MSN functional output to the same extent.
Reduced dampening of D1-MSN output may enhance behavioral responses to subsequent opioid exposure.
Findings support the hypothesis that maintaining continuity of opioid administration could be an effective therapeutic strategy.
Continuous opioid administration may minimize vulnerability to opioid use disorders.

original_abstract:
The study investigates how the brain represents the value of offers in both abstract and concrete ways.
The research examines neuronal responses to risky and safe options in five brain regions of male macaques.
No detectable overlap is found in the neural codes used for risky and safe options, even when they have identical subjective values.
Responses are weakly correlated and occupy distinct (semi-orthogonal) encoding subspaces.
The subspaces are linked through a linear transform of their constituent encodings.
This linking property allows for comparison of dissimilar option types.
The encoding scheme enables brain regions to multiplex decision-related processes.
These regions can encode detailed factors influencing offer value (risky and safety) and directly compare dissimilar offer types.
The results suggest a neuronal basis for the qualitatively different psychological properties of risky and safe options.
The study highlights the power of population geometry to resolve outstanding problems in neural coding.

original_abstract:
The mesolimbic dopamine system is involved in signaling reward-related information and actions generating rewarding outcomes.
This system is typically studied using pavlovian or operant reinforcement paradigms.
Operant paradigms require instrumental action, while pavlovian paradigms do not.
A study was conducted to compare dopamine signals in pavlovian and operant paradigms.
Male rats underwent either pavlovian or operant conditioning.
Dopamine release was measured in the nucleus accumbens during the experiments.
Task conditions were identical except for the operant-lever response requirement.
Both groups released the same quantity of dopamine at the onset of the reward-predictive cue.
Only the operant-conditioning group showed a sustained plateau in dopamine concentration throughout the 5s cue presentation.
This dopamine ramp occurred exclusively before operant actions.
The ramp was unaffected by probabilistic reward delivery.
The ramp was not related to task performance or task acquisition.
The dopamine ramp persisted throughout the 2-week daily behavioral training.
The ramp flexibly increased in duration with longer cue presentation.
The ramp appeared to modulate the initial cue-onset-triggered dopamine release (reward prediction error signal).
Signal amplitude and sustainment diminished when reward timing was made more predictable.
Findings suggest that reward prediction error and action components of dopamine release can be differentiated temporally.
The reward prediction error component is associated with phasic signals.
The action component is associated with ramping/sustained signals.
The action component (ramping signal) depends on the reward prediction error component (phasic signal).
The ramping signal presumably reflects the anticipation or incentivization of appetitive action.
The ramping signal is conceptually akin to motivation.

original_abstract:
Alcohol-related morbidities and mortality are highly prevalent.
Alcohol causes 3 million deaths globally each year in young adults.
Cue-induced alcohol craving is considered a type of aberrant associative learning.
Temporal difference theory models alcohol craving with an expected reward value (ERV).
Harmful alcohol use is associated with increased time spent obtaining and using alcohol.
Harmful alcohol use is also associated with self-neglect.
Self-neglect implies blunted motivational aspects of nonalcohol stimuli.
The study used an instrumental learning task with non-alcohol-related stimuli.
The hypothesis was that encoding of cue signals (ERV) predicting reward delivery would be blunted in binge alcohol drinkers of both sexes.
Another prediction was that ratings of problematic alcohol use would correlate with abnormal ERV signals in the binge drinking group.
Results supported the hypotheses, showing blunted ERV signals in binge drinkers.
The magnitude of ERV signal abnormality correlated with ratings of problematic alcohol use.
Findings imply that motivational aspects of non-alcohol-related stimuli are blunted in binge drinkers.
Better understanding of harmful alcohol use mechanisms can facilitate development of more effective interventions.
Future interventions should aim to decrease the motivational value of alcohol and increase the motivational value of non-alcohol-related stimuli.

original_abstract:
Black and white information is asymmetrically distributed in natural scenes.
Black and white information evokes asymmetric neuronal responses.
Black and white information causes asymmetric perceptions.
Black–white asymmetry is universal and essential in visual information processing.
The neural substrates for black–white asymmetry remain unclear.
The study aimed to disentangle the role of feedforward and recurrent mechanisms in cortical black–white asymmetry.
V1 laminar responses and LGN responses of anesthetized cats of both sexes were recorded.
Black–white asymmetry starts at the input layer of a cortical column.
Black–white asymmetry becomes more pronounced in the output layer.
Distinct dynamics of black–white asymmetry were found between the output layer and the input layer.
Black responses dominate in all layers after stimulus onset.
After stimulus offset, black and white responses are balanced in the input layer.
Black responses still dominate in the output layer after stimulus offset.
The rebound response in the output layer is significantly suppressed compared to the input layer.
The relative suppression strength evoked by white stimuli is notably stronger.
Suppression strength depends on the location within the ON-OFF cortical map.
A model with delayed and polarity-selective cortical suppression explains black–white asymmetry in the output layer.
Prominent recurrent connections were identified by Granger causality analysis.
Interlaminar differences in spatial receptive field varied dynamically.
Findings suggest that feedforward and recurrent mechanisms are dynamically recruited for the generation of black–white asymmetry in V1.

original_abstract:
Fear learning enables identification and anticipation of aversive events and behavioral adaptation.
Associative learning mechanisms involve pairing a neutral conditioned stimulus (CS) with an aversive unconditioned stimulus (US).
Humans also demonstrate verbal fear learning, rapidly changing responses through verbal instructions about CS-US pairings.
Previous research showed verbal instructions about CS-US pairing reversal can override effects of experienced pairings in fear ratings, skin conductance, and fear-potentiated startle.
It was unclear if such instructions could annul learned CS representations in the brain.
A fear reversal paradigm with female and male participants was used with fMRI and representational similarity analysis.
The study aimed to test if verbal instructions fully override experienced CS-US pairings in fear-related brain regions.
Previous research suggested only the right amygdala should show lingering representations of experienced threat ("pavlovian trace").
Unexpectedly, evidence for residual effects of prior CS-US experience was more widespread than anticipated.
Residual effects were found in the amygdala and cortical regions like dorsal anterior cingulate and dorsolateral prefrontal cortex.
This finding provides new insights into the interaction of different fear learning mechanisms.
The results have unexpected consequences for understanding fear learning processes.

original_abstract:
The rod photoreceptor synapse is the first synapse of dim-light vision and one of the most complex in the mammalian CNS.
The synapse consists of a presynaptic ribbon and a single synaptic invagination enclosing several postsynaptic processes.
EM tomography was used to generate high-resolution images of 3-D volumes of the rod synapse from the female domestic cat.
The synaptic ribbon was resolved as a single structure with a single arciform density, indicating one long site of transmitter release.
The postsynaptic processes are organized in a tetrad arrangement of two horizontal cell and two rod bipolar cell processes.
Retinal detachment severely disrupts the organization of the rod synapse.
After 7 days of detachment, rod bipolar dendrites withdraw from most spherules.
Synaptic ribbons fragment and lose their tight association with the presynaptic membrane.
The highly branched telodendria of the horizontal cell axon terminals are lost.
The hilus, the opening through which postsynaptic processes enter the invagination, enlarges after detachment.
Enlargement of the hilus exposes the normally sequestered environment within the invagination to the extracellular space of the outer plexiform layer.
EM tomography provides the most accurate description to date of the complex rod synapse.
The study details changes the rod synapse undergoes during outer segment degeneration.
These changes would be expected to disrupt the flow of information in the rod pathway.

original_abstract:
Study explores effects of virtual interactions on behavior, experience, and neural activity
Functional near-infrared spectroscopy neuroimaging used to scan participants
36 human dyads (72 participants, 36 males, 36 females) were involved in the study
Participants engaged in three naturalistic tasks: problem-solving, creative-innovation, and socio-emotional task
Tasks were performed in either in-person or virtual (Zoom) conditions
Cooperative behavior was coded from audio recordings
Reduced conversational turn-taking behavior observed during virtual condition
Conversational turn-taking associated with positive social interaction metrics
Turn-taking may be an indicator of prosocial interaction
Altered patterns of averaged and dynamic interbrain coherence observed in virtual interactions
Interbrain coherence patterns characteristic of virtual condition associated with reduced turn-taking
Findings can inform design and engineering of future videoconferencing technology

original_abstract:
The dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (dlPFC) consists of multiple anatomically defined regions.
These regions are involved in higher-order cognitive processes, including working memory and selective attention.
The dlPFC is organized in an anterior-posterior global gradient.
Posterior regions track changes in the environment.
Anterior regions support abstract neural representations.
It was unknown if this global gradient results from a smooth gradient spanning regions or an emergent property from functionally distinct regions (areal gradient).
Researchers recorded single neurons in the dlPFC of non-human primates.
The primates were trained to perform a memory-guided saccade task with an interfering distractor.
Researchers analyzed physiological properties of neurons along the anterior-posterior axis.
The physiological properties were best described by an areal gradient.
Population analyses revealed a distributed representation of spatial information across the dlPFC.
The results validate the functional boundaries between anatomically defined dlPFC regions.
The findings highlight the distributed nature of computations underlying working memory across the dlPFC.

original_abstract:
Dopamine agonist therapies used to treat Parkinson's disease can trigger impulse control and/or gambling disorders.
The cognitive and neurobiological mechanisms behind these adverse effects are unknown.
Adding win-paired sound and light cues to the rat gambling task (rGT) potentiates risky decision-making and impulsivity via the dopamine system.
Changing dopaminergic tone has a greater influence on behavior while subjects are learning task contingencies.
Dopamine agonist therapy may potentiate risk-taking by amplifying the behavioral impact of gambling-related cues on novel behavior.
Ropinirole treatment in male rats transiently increased motor impulsivity.
Ropinirole robustly and progressively increased choice of high-risk/high-reward options when administered during acquisition of the cued rGT.
Ropinirole did not increase high-risk/high-reward choices in the uncued rGT.
Early in training, ropinirole increased win-stay behavior after large unlikely wins on the cued rGT.
The increased win-stay behavior is indicative of enhanced model-free learning.
Enhanced model-free learning mediated the drug's effect on later risk preference.
Ex vivo cFos imaging showed that chronic ropinirole suppressed the activity of dopaminergic midbrain neurons.
The addition of win-paired cues also suppressed the activity of dopaminergic midbrain neurons.
The ratio of midbrain:prefrontal cFos+ neurons was lower in animals with suboptimal choice patterns.
The ratio of midbrain:prefrontal cFos+ neurons tended to predict risk preference across all rats.
Network analyses suggested that ropinirole induced decoupling of the dopaminergic cells of the VTA and nucleus accumbens.
The decoupling only occurred when win-paired cues were present.
Frontostriatal activity uninformed by the endogenous dopaminergic teaching signal appeared to perpetuate risky choice.
Ropinirole exaggerated the disconnect between frontostriatal activity and the dopaminergic teaching signal in synergy with reward-paired cues.

original_abstract:
The meaning of words in natural language is highly dependent on context.
Most neuroimaging studies on word meaning use isolated words and sentences with minimal context.
There is a need to determine if previous findings on word meaning apply to natural language processing in the brain.
An fMRI study was conducted with four subjects (two female) reading words in four contextual conditions: narratives, isolated sentences, blocks of semantically similar words, and isolated words.
The study compared signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of evoked brain responses and used voxelwise encoding modeling to compare semantic information representation across conditions.
Four consistent effects of varying context were observed.
Stimuli with more context evoke brain responses with higher SNR across bilateral visual, temporal, parietal, and prefrontal cortices.
Increasing context enhances semantic information representation across bilateral temporal, parietal, and prefrontal cortices at the group level.
In individual subjects, only natural language stimuli consistently evoke widespread representation of semantic information.
Context affects voxel semantic tuning.
Models estimated using stimuli with little context do not generalize well to natural language.
Context has significant effects on neuroimaging data quality and the representation of meaning in the brain.
Neuroimaging studies using stimuli with minimal context may not generalize well to natural language processing.

original_abstract:
Administration of nitric oxide (NO) donor triggers migraine attacks through unknown mechanisms.
Reactive nitroxidative species, including NO and peroxynitrite (PN), are involved in nociceptive sensitization.
Neutralizing PN has antinociceptive effects.
Study investigated PN's contribution to nociceptive responses in two migraine headache models.
Female and male mice were subjected to restraint stress or dural stimulation with interleukin-6.
Hyperalgesic priming was tested using sodium nitroprusside (SNP) or dural pH 7.0.
Periorbital von Frey and grimace responses were measured in both models.
Stress-induced changes in 3-nitrotyrosine (3-NT) expression and trigeminal ganglia (TGs) mitochondrial function were measured.
Neuronal activity of TGs in response to PN generator SIN-1 was recorded.
Effects of PN decomposition catalysts FeTMPyP and FeTPPS, and PN scavenger MnTBAP were tested.

original_abstract:
Exposure to combinations of environmental toxins is increasing in prevalence.
Understanding interactions between environmental toxins is becoming more important for society.
The study examined mechanisms of interaction between polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) and high-amplitude acoustic noise on central auditory processing dysfunction.
PCBs are known to have negative developmental impacts on hearing.
The study investigated whether developmental exposure to PCBs alters sensitivity to other ototoxic exposures later in life.
Male mice were exposed to PCBs in utero and to high-intensity noise as adults.
The study examined impacts on hearing and auditory midbrain organization using two-photon imaging and analysis of oxidative stress mediators.
Developmental exposure to PCBs blocked hearing recovery from acoustic trauma.
Two-photon imaging of the inferior colliculus (IC) showed disruption of tonotopic organization and reduced inhibition in the auditory midbrain.
Expression analysis in the IC revealed reduced GABAergic inhibition in animals with lower capacity to mitigate oxidative stress.
Combined PCBs and noise exposure act nonlinearly to damage hearing.
Hearing damage is associated with synaptic reorganization and reduced capacity to limit oxidative stress.
The study provides a new paradigm for understanding nonlinear interactions between combinations of environmental toxins.

original_abstract:
17β-estradiol (E2) is synthesized in the hippocampus of both sexes and acutely potentiates excitatory synapses in each sex.
Previous research found that mechanisms for initiating E2-induced synaptic potentiation differ between males and females, including molecular signaling.
The study used electrical stimulation and two-photon glutamate uncaging in hippocampal slices from adult male and female rats.
The research investigated whether downstream consequences of distinct molecular signaling remain different between sexes or converge to the same mechanism(s) of potentiation expression.
Synaptic activity is necessary for expression of E2-induced potentiation in females but not males.
Females require calcium-permeable AMPARs (cpAMPARs) to stabilize potentiation, while males do not.
Nonstationary fluctuation analysis of two-photon evoked unitary synaptic currents was performed.
Postsynaptic component of E2-induced potentiation occurs through either an increase in AMPAR conductance or nonconductive properties of AMPARs, but never both at the same synapse.
In females, 76% of synapses were potentiated via increased AMPAR conductance.
In males, 60% of synapses were potentiated via an increase in nonconductive AMPAR properties.
Inhibition of cpAMPARs eliminated E2-induced synaptic potentiation in females.
Some synapses in males were unaffected by cpAMPAR inhibition.
Synapses in males unaffected by cpAMPAR inhibition potentiated exclusively via increased AMPAR nonconductive properties.
The study reveals a sex bias in expression mechanisms of E2-induced synaptic potentiation.
The findings underscore the concept of latent sex differences in mechanisms of synaptic plasticity.
The same outcome in each sex is achieved through distinct underlying mechanisms.

original_abstract:
Everyday experience involves processing both external signals from the environment and internal information from memory.
The brain must fluctuate between states optimized for external vs. internal attention.
The hippocampus may serve as an interface between external and internal attention.
The study focuses on how the hippocampus switches between prioritizing external sensory signals and internal memory-related signals.
Cholinergic basal forebrain input has been identified as important for biasing the hippocampus towards processing external information.
The dorsal attention network (DAN) may aid in allocating attentional resources towards accessing internal information.
The study tested the hypothesis that the basal forebrain and DAN drive the hippocampus towards external and internal attention, respectively.
The study used data from 29 human participants (17 female) who completed 2 attention tasks during fMRI.
One task ("memory-guided") required more internal attention and less external attention than the other ("explicitly instructed") task.
Background functional connectivity between the basal forebrain and hippocampus was stronger during the explicitly instructed task.
DAN-hippocampus background connectivity was stronger during the memory-guided task.
The strength of DAN-hippocampus background connectivity correlated with performance on the memory-guided task but not the explicitly instructed task.
The results provide evidence that the basal forebrain and DAN may modulate the hippocampus to switch between external and internal attention.

original_abstract:
The premotor (PM) and primary motor (M1) cortical areas send voluntary motor commands through multiple neuronal pathways, including the corticorubral projection to the red nucleus (RN).
The specific contributions of M1 and PM to corticorubral projections and changes caused by motor disorders or injuries are not known in nonhuman primates.
The study quantified the density and topography of axonal endings of the corticorubral pathway in RN in intact monkeys and monkeys with cervical spinal cord injury (SCI), Parkinson's disease (PD)-like symptoms, or primary motor cortex injury (MCI).
Twenty adult macaque monkeys of either sex were injected with biotinylated dextran amine anterograde tracer in either PM or M1.
A semiautomated algorithm was developed to detect and count axonal boutons within the magnocellular and parvocellular (pRN) subdivisions of RN.
In intact monkeys, PM and M1 preferentially target the medial part of the ipsilateral pRN, reflecting its somatotopic organization.
PM projection to the ipsilateral pRN is denser than that of M1, consistent with previous observations for corticotectal, corticoreticular, and corticosubthalamic projections.
All three types of motor disorders (SCI, PD, and MCI) resulted in a uniform and strong decrease (near loss) of corticorubral projections from PM and M1.
The RN may contribute to functional recovery after SCI, PD, and MCI by reducing direct cortical influence.
This reduction possibly favors direct access to the final output motor system via emphasis on the direct corticospinal projection.

original_abstract:
Noninvasive electrical stimulation of the human vestibular system is increasingly popular in research and clinical applications.
Common assumptions about neural mechanisms underlying galvanic vestibular stimulation (GVS) have not been directly tested.
The study shows GVS is encoded by VIIIth nerve vestibular afferents with nonlinear dynamics that differ from current models.
GVS produced asymmetric activation of semicircular canal and otolith afferents to onset versus offset and cathode versus anode of applied current.
Asymmetric eye movement responses were observed in three awake-behaving male monkeys.
Computational methods demonstrated that nonlinear neural response dynamics lead to an unexpected directional bias in the net population response.
The study reveals the neural basis of GVS activation in the vestibular system.
Findings establish that neural response dynamics differ markedly from current predictions.
The research advances understanding of how asymmetric activation of the peripheral vestibular system alters vestibular function.
The authors suggest nonlinear encoding is a general feature of neural processing common across different noninvasive electrical stimulation approaches.

original_abstract:
Cyclin-dependent kinase-like 5 (CDKL5) deficiency disorder (CDD) is a severe early-onset epileptic encephalopathy.
CDD is mainly caused by de novo mutations in the X-linked CDKL5 gene.
The study examined synaptic vesicle (SV) recycling in primary hippocampal neurons from Cdkl5 knockout rat males.
A genetically encoded reporter revealed that CDKL5 is selectively required for efficient SV endocytosis.
CDKL5 kinase activity is both necessary and sufficient for optimal SV endocytosis.
Kinase-inactive mutations failed to correct endocytosis in Cdkl5 knockout neurons.
The isolated CDKL5 kinase domain fully restored SV endocytosis kinetics.
CDKL5-mediated phosphorylation of amphiphysin 1, a putative presynaptic target, is not required for CDKL5-dependent control of SV endocytosis.
The findings reveal a key presynaptic role for CDKL5 kinase activity.
The study enhances insight into how CDKL5 dysfunction may culminate in CDD.

original_abstract:
The study compared fMRI BOLD signals between older and younger adults during task performance.
Older adults typically show overactivations in fMRI studies, especially during less demanding tasks.
The neuronal basis of these overactivations is unknown, but they are often thought to be compensatory.
The study involved 23 young adults (20-37 years) and 34 older adults (65-86 years) of both sexes.
Participants were scanned using hybrid positron emission tomography/MRI.
[18F]fluoro-deoxyglucose was used to assess dynamic changes in glucose metabolism as a marker of task-dependent synaptic activity.
Simultaneous fMRI BOLD imaging was also performed.
Participants completed two verbal working memory tasks: an easy maintenance task and a difficult manipulation task.
Both imaging modalities and age groups showed converging activations in attentional, control, and sensorimotor networks for working memory tasks versus rest.
Upregulation of activity in response to increased working memory demand was observed in both modalities and age groups.
Older adults showed task-dependent BOLD overactivations compared to young adults in certain regions.
No corresponding increases in glucose metabolism were found in regions where older adults showed BOLD overactivations.
The study found that task-induced changes in BOLD signal and synaptic activity generally converge.
Overactivations observed with fMRI in older adults were not coupled with increased synaptic activity.
The findings suggest that these overactivations in older adults are not neuronal in origin.

original_abstract:
Parkinson's disease (PD) is characterized by multiple symptoms including olfactory dysfunction.
The underlying mechanisms of olfactory dysfunction in PD remain unclear.
The study explored pathologic changes in the olfactory pathway of transgenic (Tg) mice expressing human A30P mutant α-synuclein (α-syn).
Both male and female α-syn-Tg mice were studied at 6–7 and 12–14 months of age.
These age ranges represent early and late-stages of motor progression, respectively.
α-Syn-Tg mice at late stages exhibited olfactory behavioral deficits.
Olfactory deficits correlated with severe α-syn pathology in projection neurons (PNs) of the olfactory pathway.
Olfactory bulb (OB) neurogenesis was reduced in α-syn-Tg mice.
Reduction in OB granule cells occurred at six to seven months.
Reduction in OB periglomerular cells occurred at 12–14 months.
Both reductions in neurogenesis could contribute to olfactory dysfunction.
Proteomic analyses showed disruption in endocytic and exocytic pathways in the OB during early stages.
Disruption appeared exacerbated at the synaptic terminals when mice developed olfactory deficits at 12–14 months.
α-Syn-Tg mice recapitulate the olfactory functional deficits seen in PD.
Olfactory structures exhibit spatiotemporal disparities for vulnerability to α-syn pathology.
α-Syn pathology is restricted to projection neurons in the olfactory pathway.
Neurogenesis in adult α-syn-Tg mice is reduced in the OB.
Synaptic endocytosis and exocytosis defects in the OB may further explain olfactory deficits.

original_abstract:
Endolysosomal defects in neurons are central to the pathogenesis of prion and other neurodegenerative disorders.
Prion oligomers traffic through the multivesicular body (MVB) and are routed for degradation in lysosomes or for release in exosomes.
The impact of prions on proteostatic pathways is unclear.
Prion-affected human and mouse brain showed a marked reduction in Hrs and STAM1 (ESCRT-0).
ESCRT-0 routes ubiquitinated membrane proteins from early endosomes into MVBs.
Conditional knockout mice (male and female) with Hrs deleted from neurons, astrocytes, or microglia were prion-challenged.
Neuronal Hrs-depleted mice showed a shortened survival and acceleration in synaptic derangements.
Astrocytic or microglial Hrs-depleted mice did not show these effects.
Synaptic derangements included accumulation of ubiquitinated proteins, deregulation of phosphorylated AMPA and metabotropic glutamate receptors, and altered synaptic structure.
These derangements occurred later in prion-infected control mice.
Neuronal Hrs (nHrs) depletion increased surface levels of the cellular prion protein, PrPC.
Increased PrPC may contribute to rapidly advancing disease through neurotoxic signaling.
Reduced Hrs in prion-affected brain hampers ubiquitinated protein clearance at the synapse.
Reduced Hrs exacerbates postsynaptic glutamate receptor deregulation.
Reduced Hrs accelerates neurodegeneration.

original_abstract:
Astrocytes have complex structural, molecular, and physiological properties.
Astrocytes form specialized microenvironments supporting circuit-specific functions in the CNS.
Immature mouse cortical astrocytes were transplanted into the developing cortex of male and female mice.
Integration, maturation, and survival of transplanted astrocytes were assessed.
Within days, transplanted astrocytes developed typical cortical astrocyte morphologies, territories, and tiling behavior.
At 35-47 days post-transplantation, astrocytes appeared morphologically mature.
Transplanted astrocytes expressed EAAT2/GLT1 levels similar to nontransplanted astrocytes.
Transplanted astrocytes supported excitatory/inhibitory presynaptic terminals within their territories.
Transplanted astrocytes displayed normal Ca2+ events.
Initially, transplanted astrocytes showed reduced expression of aquaporin 4 (AQP4) at endfeet.
Transplanted astrocytes initially showed elevated expression of EAAT1/GLAST.
AQP4 and EAAT1/GLAST expression normalized by 110 days and one year post-transplantation, respectively.
Cortical astrocytes were transplanted into the developing cerebellum to understand regional support for integration and maturation.
Transplanted cortical astrocytes interlaced with Bergmann glia in the cerebellar molecular layer.
Transplanted astrocytes retained cortical astrocytic features in the cerebellum.
Retained features included higher levels of EAAT2/GLT1 and lower levels of EAAT1/GLAST.
Transplanted astrocytes did not express the AMPAR subunit GluA1 in the cerebellum.
Immature cortical astrocytes integrate, mature, and survive for more than one year following transplantation.
Transplanted astrocytes retain cortical astrocytic properties.
Astrocytic transplantation can be used to investigate cell-autonomous and non-cell-autonomous mechanisms in astrocytic development and diversity.
Astrocytic transplantation can help determine optimal timing for cellular delivery or replacement in regenerative medicine.

original_abstract:
The brain integrates information across multiple sensory systems to maintain stable head and body posture during everyday activities.
The study examined how the primate vestibular system contributes to head posture control, both independently and in combination with visual input.
Single motor unit activity in splenius capitis and sternocleidomastoid muscles was recorded in rhesus monkeys during yaw rotations up to 20 Hz in darkness.
Splenius capitis motor unit responses increased with frequency up to 16 Hz in normal animals.
Motor unit responses were absent following bilateral peripheral vestibular loss.
The correspondence between visual and vestibular cues of self-motion was experimentally controlled.
Visual information did not influence motor unit responses in normal animals.
Visual information did not substitute for absent vestibular feedback following bilateral peripheral vestibular loss.
Low-frequency responses were attenuated when low- and high-frequency self-motion were experienced concurrently.
Vestibular-evoked responses were enhanced by increased autonomic arousal, quantified via pupil size.
The study establishes the vestibular system's contribution to head posture control across the dynamic motion range of everyday activities.
The findings reveal how vestibular, visual, and autonomic inputs are integrated for postural control.

original_abstract:
Gain-of-function pathogenic variants in KCNQ2 (KV7.2) and KCNQ3 (KV7.3) potassium channels cause hyperexcitability disorders like epilepsy and autism spectrum disorders.
The cellular mechanisms of how these variants impair forebrain function are unclear.
The R201C variant in KCNQ2 has opposite effects on the excitability of two types of mouse pyramidal neurons.
R201C causes hyperexcitability in layer 2/3 (L2/3) pyramidal neurons.
R201C causes hypoexcitability in CA1 pyramidal neurons.
The homologous R231C variant in KCNQ3 leads to hyperexcitability in L2/3 pyramidal neurons.
R231C in KCNQ3 also leads to hypoexcitability in CA1 pyramidal neurons.
The effects of KCNQ3 gain of function on excitability are specific to superficial CA1 pyramidal neurons.
These findings reveal a new level of complexity in the function of KCNQ2 and KCNQ3 channels in the forebrain.
The study provides a framework for understanding the effects of gain-of-function variants and potassium channels in the brain.
The study was conducted on mouse pyramidal neurons of either sex.

original_abstract:

The axon initial segment (AIS) maintains neuronal polarity and is the site of action potential generation.
In adult neurons, GABA hyperpolarizes dendrites but depolarizes axons.
The AIS exhibits properties of both mature axons and dendrites regarding GABAergic signaling.
GABAergic properties at the AIS evolve over an extended period during periadolescent development.
The study explored how developmental changes in GABAergic signaling affect action potential initiation.

original_abstract:
Pulsatile release of GnRH from hypothalamic neurons triggers anterior pituitary gonadotropin secretion in vertebrates.
Gonadotropins activate steroidogenesis, and steroids typically exert homeostatic negative feedback on GnRH release.
Long-term episodic firing patterns of GnRH neurons in brain slices resemble pulsatile GnRH and LH release in vivo.
The relationship between GnRH neuron firing and release, and the influence of gonadal feedback on this relationship, are not known.
The study combined fast-scan cyclic voltammetry and patch-clamp techniques to measure neuropeptide release and action potential firing simultaneously.
Experiments were conducted on brain slice preparations from male mice.
GnRH release increased with higher frequency spontaneous firing up to a plateau point.
Further increases in firing rate beyond the plateau did not elicit additional release.
Kisspeptin, a potent GnRH neuron activator via Gq-coupled signaling, triggered GnRH release before increasing firing rate.
This effect was observed whether kisspeptin was globally perfused or locally applied.
Increasing the number of spikes in an applied burst template increased GnRH release.
Orchidectomized mice showed higher sensitivity to increased action potential number compared to sham-operated mice.
Ca2+ currents triggered by burst templates were increased in GnRH neurons of orchidectomized mice.
Results suggest removal of gonadal feedback increases the efficacy of stimulus-secretion coupling mechanisms.
This phenomenon may extend to other steroid-sensitive regions of the brain.

original_abstract:
Synaptic vesicle (SV) endocytosis is crucial for maintaining neurotransmission.
Synaptotagmin-11 (Syt11) is a non-Ca2+-binding Syt associated with brain diseases.
Syt11 inhibits neuronal endocytosis.
Syt11 deficiency accelerates SV endocytosis and vesicle recycling under sustained stimulation.
Syt11 deficiency leads to abnormal membrane partition of synaptic proteins in mouse hippocampal boutons.
Syt11 binds directly to endophilin A1 (EndoA1) in a Ca2+-independent manner with high affinity.
EndoA1 is a membrane curvature sensor and endocytic protein recruiter.
EndoA1-knockdown reverses Syt11-knockout phenotype.
EndoA1 is identified as a main inhibitory target of Syt11 during SV endocytosis.
The N-terminus of EndoA1 and the C2B domain of Syt11 are responsible for their interaction.
A peptide (amino acids 314-336) derived from Syt11 C2B blocks Syt11-EndoA1 binding in vitro and in vivo.
The peptide inhibits SV endocytosis in wild-type hippocampal neurons but not in EndoA1-knockdown neurons.
Intracellular application of the peptide in mouse calyx of Held terminals hampers both fast and slow SV endocytosis at physiological temperature.
Syt11 ensures precision of protein retrieval during SV endocytosis by inhibiting EndoA1 function at neuronal terminals.
The study was conducted on mouse hippocampal boutons and calyx of Held terminals of either sex.

original_abstract:
The composition of voltage-gated Ca2+ channel (Cav) subtypes that gate action potential (AP)-evoked release changes during the development of mammalian CNS synapses.
Cav2.2 and Cav2.3 lose their function in gating-evoked release during postnatal synapse maturation.
In mature boutons, Cav2.1 currents provide the almost exclusive trigger for evoked release.
Cav2.3 currents are required for the induction of presynaptic long-term potentiation in mature boutons.
The functional significance of Cav2.2 in mature boutons remained elusive, although they remain present at active zones and contribute significantly to presynaptic Ca2+ influx.
The study addressed the functional significance of Cav2.2 and Cav2.3 at mature parallel-fiber (PF) to Purkinje neuron synapses of mice of either sex.
These synapses exhibit the corresponding developmental Cav subtype changes in gating release.
Two hypotheses were addressed: Cav2.2 and Cav2.3 are involved in triggering spontaneous glutamate release, and they are engaged in vesicle recruitment during repetitive evoked release.
Spontaneous miniature release was found to be Ca2+ dependent.
Experiments with Cav subtype-specific blockers excluded the spontaneous opening of Cavs as the Ca2+ source for spontaneous glutamate release.
Neither Cav2.2 nor Cav2.3 controls spontaneous release from PF boutons.
Vesicle recruitment during brief bursts of APs was independent of Ca2+ influx through Cav2.2 and Cav2.3.
Cav2.2 currents significantly boosted vesicle recruitment during sustained high-frequency synaptic transmission.
Cav2.3 currents did not boost vesicle recruitment during sustained high-frequency synaptic transmission.
In mature PF boutons, Cav2.2 channels are specifically required to sustain synaptic transmission during prolonged neuronal activity.

original_abstract:
Peripheral nerve injury often results in long-lasting motor behavioral deficits and reorganization of spinal motor circuitry.
These effects do not reverse even after nerve regeneration.
Stretch areflexia and gait ataxia emerge from factors including degeneration of Ia–motoneuron synapses.
Evidence suggests nerve injury induces synapse degeneration via immune responses.
The hypothesis was that suppressing inflammatory responses would preserve Ia–motoneuron connectivity and aid in restoring normal function.
The anti-inflammatory agent minocycline was administered to male and female rats following peripheral nerve axotomy.
Ia–motoneuron synaptic connectivity was assessed structurally and functionally at different time points.
Minocycline treatment overcame the physical loss of Ia contacts on motoneurons typically lost after axotomy.
Synaptic preservation was necessary but not sufficient for functional recovery.
Functional decline was still observed as smaller than normal stretch-evoked synaptic potentials at Ia–motoneuron connections.
The stretch reflex remained absent despite minocycline treatment.
Findings demonstrate a limited capacity of minocycline to rescue normal sensorimotor behavior.
The study illustrates that structural preservation of synaptic connectivity does not ensure normal synaptic function.

original_abstract:
Microglia are the resident immune cells of the CNS.
Microglia sense neuronal activity and regulate physiological brain functions.
Microglia are implicated in brain diseases associated with alterations in neural excitability and plasticity.
Experimental and therapeutic approaches to modulate microglia function in a brain region-specific manner have not been established.
The study tested the effects of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) on microglia-mediated synaptic plasticity.
rTMS is a clinically used noninvasive brain stimulation technique.
10 Hz electromagnetic stimulation triggered the release of plasticity-promoting cytokines from microglia in mouse organotypic brain tissue cultures of both sexes.
No significant changes in microglial morphology or microglia dynamics were observed.
Substitution of tumor necrosis factor α (TNFα) and interleukin 6 (IL6) preserved synaptic plasticity induced by 10 Hz stimulation in the absence of microglia.
In vivo depletion of microglia abolished rTMS-induced changes in neurotransmission in the mPFC of anesthetized mice of both sexes.
The study concludes that rTMS affects neural excitability and plasticity by modulating the release of cytokines from microglia.

original_abstract:
Age-related hearing loss (presbyacusis) is a common degenerative disorder affecting communication and quality of life for older adults.
Multiple pathophysiologic manifestations and cellular/molecular alterations are linked to presbyacusis.
Initial events and causal factors of presbyacusis are not clearly established.
Transcriptome comparisons in a mouse model revealed early pathophysiological alterations in the stria vascularis (SV).
These alterations are associated with increased macrophage activation and inflammaging.
Structure-function correlation analyses in mice showed age-dependent increase in macrophage activation in the SV is associated with declining auditory sensitivity.
High-resolution imaging analysis of mouse and human cochleas supports the hypothesis that aberrant macrophage activity contributes to age-dependent strial dysfunction, cochlear pathology, and hearing loss.
Transcriptomic analysis of age-dependent changes in mouse cochlear macrophage gene expression further supports this hypothesis.
The study highlights the SV as a primary site of age-related cochlear degeneration.
Aberrant macrophage activity and dysregulation of the immune system are identified as early indicators of age-related cochlear pathology and hearing loss.
Novel imaging methods described in the study provide a means to analyze human temporal bones in a previously unfeasible way.
These new imaging methods represent a significant new tool for otopathological evaluation.

original_abstract:
Cortical neurons are produced in a temporally regulated sequence from apical progenitors during development.
Neurons can be produced directly or indirectly through intermediate basal progenitors.
The balance between apical and basal progenitors is critical for producing the proper number and types of neurons.
Understanding the cellular and molecular cues controlling this equilibrium is important.
The study addresses the role of CDC25B phosphatase, a cell cycle regulator, in this process.
Deleting CDC25B in apical progenitors leads to a transient increase in TBR1+ neuron production at the expense of TBR2+ basal progenitors in developing mouse neocortex of both sexes.
The phenotype is associated with lengthening of the G2 phase of the cell cycle.
Total cell cycle length remains unaffected.
In utero electroporation and cortical slice cultures demonstrate that the defect in TBR2+ basal progenitor production requires interaction with CDK1.
The defect is caused by G2 phase lengthening in CDC25B mutants.
The study identifies a new role for CDC25B in direct versus indirect neurogenesis at early stages of cortical development.
The study also identifies a role for G2 phase length in direct versus indirect neurogenesis at early stages of cortical development.

original_abstract:
ELOVL4 mediates biosynthesis of very long chain-fatty acids (VLC-FA; ≥28 carbons).
Mutations in ELOVL4 result in spinocerebellar ataxia-34 (SCA34).
A rat model of human SCA34 was generated by knock-in of c.736T>G, p.W246G mutation in the Elovl4 gene.
Homozygous W246G mutant ELOVL4 rats (MUT) showed early-onset gait disturbance and impaired synaptic transmission and plasticity.
Patch-clamp recordings from Purkinje cells identified impaired synaptic mechanisms.
Miniature EPSC (mEPSC) frequency is reduced in MUT rats with no change in amplitude, suggesting a presynaptic defect.
Miniature IPSC (mIPSC) frequency and amplitude are increased in MUT Purkinje cells.
Paired-pulse ratio is reduced at parallel fiber-Purkinje cell (PF-PC) synapses.
Paired-pulse ratio is increased at climbing fiber-Purkinje cell (CF-PC) synapses in MUT rats.
Changes in paired-pulse ratio suggest opposite changes in release probability at PF-PC and CF-PC synapses.
Exaggerated persistence of EPSC amplitude at CF-PC and PF-PC synapses in MUT cerebellum suggests a larger readily releasable pool (RRP).
Dendritic spine density is reduced in MUT Purkinje cells.
Results uncover novel mechanisms of action of VLC-FA at cerebellar synapses.
Findings elucidate the synaptic dysfunction underlying SCA34 pathology.

original_abstract:
The cerebral cortex development involves multiple steps, including dendritic and axonal outgrowth and synaptic formation and maturation.
Dysregulation of these processes can lead to improper neuronal connectivity and neurodevelopmental disorders.
γ-Protocadherins (γ-Pcdhs) are a family of 22 cell adhesion molecules with shared C-terminal cytoplasmic domains.
γ-Pcdhs are involved in neuronal survival, dendrite arborization, and synapse development.
The roles of individual γ-Pcdh family members are not fully understood.
γ-Pcdh-C3 isoform (γC3) interacts with Axin1, a Wnt-pathway scaffold protein, via its unique "variable" cytoplasmic domain (VCD).
γC3 and Axin1 interaction is confirmed in the cortex in vivo.
Mice lacking γC3 show disrupted Axin1 localization to synaptic fractions.
γC3 knock-out mice do not exhibit obvious changes in dendritic spine density or morphology.
γC3 knock-out mice show severely decreased dendritic complexity of cortical pyramidal neurons.
The decreased dendritic complexity is not observed in mouse lines lacking other γ-Pcdh isoforms.
γC3 promotes dendritic arborization through an Axin1-dependent mechanism mediated by its VCD.
The study identifies a novel mechanism by which γC3 uniquely regulates cortical circuitry formation.
Both male and female mice were used in the study.
Cultured cortical neurons from both male and female mice were used for knock-out and rescue experiments.

original_abstract:
Saccades are a fundamental part of natural vision.
Saccades interrupt fixations of the visual gaze and rapidly shift the retinal image.
Saccades can cause activation or suppression of different retinal ganglion cells.
The effect of saccades on visual information encoding in different ganglion cell types is largely unknown.
Researchers recorded spiking responses to saccade-like shifts of luminance gratings from ganglion cells in isolated marmoset retinas.
The study investigated how cell activity depended on the combination of presaccadic and postsaccadic images.
All identified cell types (On and Off parasol, midget, and Large Off cells) displayed distinct response patterns.
Cells showed sensitivity to presaccadic or postsaccadic images or combinations thereof.
Off parasol and Large Off cells showed sensitivity to image changes across the transition.
On cells did not show sensitivity to image changes across the transition.
Stimulus sensitivity of On cells could be explained based on responses to step changes in light intensity.
Off cells, particularly parasol and Large Off cells, seem to be affected by additional interactions not triggered during simple light-intensity flashes.
Ganglion cells in the primate retina are sensitive to different combinations of presaccadic and postsaccadic visual stimuli.
This sensitivity contributes to the functional diversity of retinal output signals.
The findings reveal asymmetries between On and Off pathways.
The study provides evidence of signal processing beyond what is triggered by isolated steps in light intensity.

original_abstract:
The hypothalamic melanocortin system is involved in sensing stored energy and communicating this information throughout the brain.
The system includes first-order AgRP and POMC neurons in the hypothalamic arcuate nucleus and downstream neurons containing MC3R and MC4R.
The function of downstream MC4R neurons is well-characterized, but the identity and function of MC3R-containing neurons are poorly understood.
The study used neuroanatomical and circuit manipulation approaches in male and female mice.
A novel pathway linking hypothalamic melanocortin neurons to MC3R neurons in the paraventricular thalamus (PVT) was identified.
PVT MC3R neurons are innervated by hypothalamic AgRP and POMC neurons.
PVT MC3R neurons are activated by anorexigenic and aversive stimuli.
Chemogenetic activation of PVT MC3R neurons increases anxiety-related behavior and reduces feeding in hungry mice.
Inhibition of PVT MC3R neurons reduces anxiety-related behavior.
PVT MC3R neurons are positioned as important cellular substrates linking energy status with neural circuitry regulating anxiety-related behavior.
PVT MC3R neurons represent a promising potential target for diseases at the intersection of metabolism and anxiety-related behavior, such as anorexia nervosa.

original_abstract:
Slow-wave sleep and spindle coupling support memory consolidation.
In old age, slow-wave sleep duration and coupling events decrease.
Deterioration of coupling hierarchy predicts memory loss and brain atrophy.
Study investigates slow wave-spindle coupling dynamics using frontocentral EEG.
Large sample of 340 participants (237 females, 103 males) aged 15-83 years.
Spindles gradually shift from being driven by slow waves to driving slow waves with age.
This shift reverses the coupling hierarchy typically seen in younger brains.
Reversal is stronger at lower slow-wave frequencies.
Reversal begins around midlife (age 40-48 years).
Reversed hierarchy is established between 56-83 years of age.
Coupling strength remains unaffected by age.
In older adults, deteriorating coupling is associated with blood plasma GFAP levels.
GFAP is a marker for astrocyte activation.
Data-driven models suggest decreased sleep time and higher age lead to fewer coupling events.
Fewer coupling events are paralleled by increased astrocyte activation.
Astrocyte activation is associated with a backshift of coupling hierarchy toward a "younger" status.
Astrocyte activation is also associated with increased coupling occurrence and strength.
This association potentially suggests compensatory processes.
Changes in coupling hierarchy occur gradually starting at midlife.
There exists a sizable window of opportunity for early interventions.
Early interventions could counteract undesirable trajectories associated with neurodegeneration.

original_abstract:
Eutherian mammals have chromosomal sex determination with XY males and XX females.
Transgenic mice and humans with sex chromosome trisomy (SCT) show direct sex chromosome dosage (SCD) effects on regional brain anatomy.
A formal test for cross-species conservation of SCD effects was lacking.
A harmonized framework for comparative structural neuroimaging was developed.
The framework was applied to profile SCD effects on regional brain anatomy in humans and mice.
Groups with SCT (XXY and XYY) were contrasted against XY controls.
Total brain size was significantly altered by SCT in humans but not in mice.
XXY decreased total brain size in humans, while XYY increased it.
Humans showed robust and spatially convergent effects of XXY and XYY on regional brain volume when controlling for global volume differences.
Mice did not show robust or spatially convergent effects of XXY and XYY on regional brain volume.
Mice exhibited subtle effects of XXY and XYY on regional volume.
There was no general spatial convergence in SCT effects within mice or between species.
Several brain regions showed overlapping effects of XXY and XYY within and between species.
Cerebellar, parietal, and orbitofrontal cortex were identified as high priority targets for future research.
The study introduced a generalizable framework for comparative neuroimaging in humans and mice.
The framework was applied to compare SCD effects on the mammalian brain through SCT.

original_abstract:
Thermoregulatory behavior in homeothermic animals is innate and defends body core temperature.
Central mechanisms of autonomous thermoregulation are better understood than those of behavioral thermoregulation.
The lateral parabrachial nucleus (LPB) mediates cutaneous thermosensory afferent signaling for thermoregulation.
The study investigated the roles of ascending thermosensory pathways from the LPB in avoidance behavior from innocuous heat and cold in male rats.
Neuronal tracing revealed two segregated groups of LPB neurons: LPB→MnPO neurons and LPB→CeA neurons.
LPB→MnPO neurons include separate subgroups activated by heat or cold exposure.
LPB→CeA neurons were only activated by cold exposure.
LPB→MnPO transmission mediates heat avoidance.
LPB→CeA transmission contributes to cold avoidance.
Skin cooling-evoked thermogenesis in brown adipose tissue requires both LPB→MnPO and LPB→CeA neurons.
The findings provide a novel insight into the central mechanism of autonomous thermoregulation.
The study reveals an important framework of central thermosensory afferent pathways.
These pathways coordinate behavioral and autonomous thermoregulation.
The pathways also generate emotions of thermal comfort and discomfort that drive thermoregulatory behavior.

original_abstract:
Stress disorders impair sleep and quality of life, but their pathomechanisms are unknown.
Prolactin-releasing peptide (PrRP) is a stress mediator hypothesized to be involved in the development of stress disorders.
PrRP is produced by medullary A1/A2 noradrenaline (NA) cells and non-NA cells in the hypothalamic dorsomedial nucleus.
PrRP and PrRP-NA cells innervate melanin-concentrating hormone (MCH) producing neurons in the dorsolateral hypothalamus (DLH) in male rats.
MCH neurons regulate sleep and affective states.
PrRP hyperpolarizes MCH neurons and enhances NA-induced hyperpolarization ex vivo.
Intracerebroventricular PrRP injection reduces REM sleep-active MCH cells after sleep deprivation.
Sleep deprivation upregulates PrRP expression in the dorsomedial nucleus.
REM sleep rebound downregulates PrRP expression in the dorsomedial nucleus.
Impaired coping with sustained stress is associated with PrRP cell overactivation in learned helplessness paradigm and after peripheral inflammation.
Stress-related impaired coping is also associated with PrRP protein and receptor depletion in the DLH.
Stress-related impaired coping is linked to dysregulation of MCH expression.
Exposure to stress during the PrRP-insensitive period leads to increased passive coping with stress.
Normal PrRP signaling appears to protect animals against stress-related disorders.
PrRP signaling in the DLH is an important component of PrRP's action, possibly mediated by MCH neurons.
PrRP receptors are downregulated in the DLH of human suicidal victims.
Stress-related mental disorders are the leading cause of suicide.
These findings may have particular translational relevance for understanding and treating stress-related disorders.

original_abstract:
The medial temporal lobe structures are hierarchically organized and crucial for episodic memory function.
Evidence suggests dissociable information processing pathways exist throughout these structures, including in the medial and lateral entorhinal cortex.
Cortical layers provide an additional dimension of dissociation in information processing.
Layer 2 neurons in the entorhinal cortex provide the primary input to the hippocampus.
Deeper layers of the entorhinal cortex primarily receive output from the hippocampus.
Novel high-resolution T2-prepared functional MRI methods were used to mitigate susceptibility artifacts.
These methods provided uniform sensitivity across the medial and lateral entorhinal cortex.
Healthy human subjects (age 25-33 years, mean age 28.2 ± 3.3 years, 4 female) participated in a memory task.
Subjects showed differential functional activation in the superficial and deep layers of the entorhinal cortex.
Superficial layers were associated with task-related encoding conditions.
Deep layers were associated with task-related retrieval conditions.
The methods offer an approach to probe layer-specific activation in normal cognition.
The methods can also be used to investigate conditions contributing to memory impairment.
