original_abstract:
Deep neural networks (DNNs) are promising models for human object recognition in the cortex.
DNNs explain a significant portion of variance in neural data, but agreement with brain representational dynamics is not perfect.
The study aims to identify representational features unaccounted for in neural time series data.
Data was collected from multiple areas of the ventral stream using source-reconstructed magnetoencephalography in human participants (9 females, 6 males).
The study focuses on visuo-semantic models' ability to explain variance beyond DNNs alone.
Visuo-semantic models consist of human-generated labels of object features and categories.
A gradual reversal in the relative importance of DNN versus visuo-semantic features is observed as ventral-stream object representations unfold.
Lower-level visual areas are better explained by DNN features starting at 66 ms after stimulus onset.
Higher-level cortical dynamics are best accounted for by visuo-semantic features starting at 146 ms after stimulus onset.
Object parts and basic categories drive the advantage of visuo-semantic features over DNNs.
A significant component of variance unexplained by DNNs in higher-level cortical dynamics is structured.
This unexplained variance can be explained by readily nameable aspects of the objects.
Current DNNs fail to fully capture dynamic representations in higher-level human visual cortex.
The study suggests a path toward more accurate models of ventral-stream computations.

original_abstract:
fMRI was used to compare motor and tactile finger representations in the precentral and postcentral gyrus of 25 five-fingered participants.
Multivoxel pattern and connectivity analyses showed distinct motor and tactile finger representations in both precentral and postcentral gyrus.
These representations integrate finger-specific motor and tactile information.
Representational similarity analysis revealed that perceived hand structure better described motor and tactile finger representations than actual hand anatomy or functional models.
A polydactyly individual with a six-fingered hand and superior manipulation abilities was also studied.
For the polydactyly individual, perceived hand model best described tactile representations in both precentral and postcentral gyrus.
Finger kinematics better described motor representations in the precentral gyrus of the polydactyly individual.
In subjects with standard hand anatomy, sensorimotor representations of the five fingers converge toward a model of perceived hand anatomy.
This perceived hand model deviates from the real hand structure.
The perceived hand model represents the best synthesis between functional and structural features of the hand.

original_abstract:
Material properties determine how objects can be used.
Real-life experience forms strong expectations about object behavior under force.
Expectations modulate perceptual processes.
The study aimed to investigate how expectation influences temporal dynamics of cortical visual analysis for objects and materials.
Time-resolved EEG decoding was used in a violation-of-expectation paradigm.
Objects fell to the ground and deformed in expected or unexpected ways.
The study included 25 male and female participants.
Objects and materials were represented rapidly and in a temporally sustained fashion.
Objects exhibiting unexpected material behaviors were more successfully decoded within 190 ms after impact.
Increased decoding success might indicate additional processing demands when expectations are unmet.
General signals of expectation fulfillment were found within the first 150 ms after impact.
These signals generalized across specific objects and materials.
Results provide insights into the temporal neural processing cascade underlying real-world material behavior analysis.
Cortical signals progress from a general signature of expectation fulfillment toward increased processing of unexpected material behaviors.

original_abstract:
Neurons in the primary visual cortex (V1) receive excitation and inhibition from distinct parallel pathways processing lightness (ON) and darkness (OFF).
V1 neurons generally respond more strongly to dark than light stimuli.
This "dark-dominance" is consistent with the prevalence of darker regions in natural images and human psychophysics.
The study aimed to understand whether dark-dominance results from more excitation from the OFF pathway or more inhibition from the ON pathway.
Researchers recorded electrophysiological responses of individual simple-type V1 neurons to natural image stimuli.
Biologically inspired convolutional neural networks were trained to predict the neurons' responses.
A sample of 71 neurons in anesthetized, paralyzed cats of either sex was analyzed.
The neurons' responses were found to be more driven by dark than light stimuli, confirming previous findings.
The study revealed that the asymmetry is primarily due to slower inhibition to dark stimuli rather than stronger excitation from the thalamocortical OFF pathway.
Dark-dominant neurons were found to have faster responses than light-dominant neurons.
Dark-dominance was observed to occur only in the early latencies of neurons' responses.
Neurons that are strongly dark-dominated tend to be less orientation-selective.
This novel approach provides new insights into the dark-dominance phenomenon.
The study opens avenues to address new questions about excitatory and inhibitory integration in cortical neurons.

original_abstract:
Optimal feedback control theory guides studies on how the motor system handles task redundancy.
The theory predicts that kinematic errors shouldn't be corrected if the behavioral goal can still be achieved.
Human studies show the motor system can integrate visual and proprioceptive feedback with goal redundancy within 90 ms and 70 ms, respectively.
Four male Macaca mulatta monkeys were trained to reach for either a narrow square or a wide, spatially redundant rectangle.
Monkeys showed greater trial-by-trial variability when reaching for the wide goal, consistent with exploiting goal redundancy.
Visual feedback of the hand was randomly jumped during trials.
Monkeys corrected for the jump when reaching for the narrow goal.
Monkeys largely ignored the jump when reaching for the wide goal.
Mechanical loads were applied to the monkeys' arms in separate experiments.
Similar corrective responses based on goal shape were observed with mechanical loads.
Muscle activity reflecting different corrective responses was detected for visual perturbations starting at ~90 ms.
Muscle activity reflecting different corrective responses was detected for mechanical perturbations starting at ~70 ms.
Rapid motor responses in macaques can exploit goal redundancy similar to humans.
This creates a paradigm to study the neural basis of goal-directed motor action and motor redundancy.

original_abstract:
Visual attention is influenced by past experiences.
Behavioral research has shown that expectations about distractor locations in search arrays are implicitly learned.
Expected distractors become less interfering.
The neural mechanism supporting this form of statistical learning is not well understood.
Magnetoencephalography (MEG) was used to measure human brain activity.
The study aimed to test if proactive mechanisms are involved in statistical learning of distractor locations.
Rapid invisible frequency tagging (RIFT) was used to assess neural excitability in early visual cortex.
Posterior alpha band activity (8–12 Hz) was concurrently investigated.
Male and female human participants performed a visual search task.
The task occasionally presented a target alongside a color-singleton distractor.
Distracting stimuli were presented with different probabilities across the two hemifields, unknown to participants.
RIFT analysis showed reduced neural excitability in early visual cortex during the prestimulus interval.
Reduced excitability was observed at retinotopic locations associated with higher distractor probabilities.
No evidence of expectation-driven distractor suppression was found in alpha band activity.
Findings indicate that proactive mechanisms of attention are involved in predictive distractor suppression.
These mechanisms are associated with altered neural excitability in early visual cortex.
RIFT and alpha band activity may subtend different and possibly independent attentional mechanisms.

original_abstract:
Cholecystokinin (CCK) enables excitatory circuit long-term potentiation (LTP).
The study investigated CCK's involvement in enhancing inhibitory synapses.
Activation of GABA neurons suppressed neuronal responses to auditory stimuli in mice of both sexes.
High-frequency laser stimulation (HFLS) of GABAergic neurons potentiated this suppression.
HFLS of CCK interneurons induced LTP of their inhibition toward pyramidal neurons.
This potentiation was abolished in CCK knock-out mice.
The potentiation remained intact in mice with both CCK1R and 2R knockout of both sexes.
Bioinformatics analysis, cell-based assays, and histology examinations identified a novel CCK receptor, GPR173.
GPR173 is proposed as CCK3R, mediating the relationship between cortical CCK interneuron signaling and inhibitory LTP in mice of either sex.
GPR173 might be a promising therapeutic target for brain disorders related to excitation and inhibition imbalance in the cortex.

original_abstract:
Neural evidence suggests the human brain has separate systems for scene categorization and visually guided navigation.
The parahippocampal place area is associated with scene categorization.
The occipital place area is associated with visually guided navigation.
Behavioral data could provide stronger support for the two-scene-systems hypothesis.
A study was conducted to test scene categorization and visually guided navigation abilities.
The study included 131 typically developing children aged 4-9 years.
The study also included 46 adults with Williams syndrome.
Williams syndrome is a developmental disorder with impairment in "action" tasks but relative sparing in "perception" tasks for object processing.
The study found that visually guided navigation develops later than scene categorization.
Adults with Williams syndrome were impaired in visually guided navigation compared to mental age-matched children.
Adults with Williams syndrome were not impaired in scene categorization compared to mental age-matched children.
These findings provide the first developmental and neuropsychological evidence for dissociable cognitive systems for recognizing places and navigating through them.

original_abstract:
Reward-seeking behavior is often initiated by environmental cues signaling reward availability.
Cue reactivity and reward-seeking behavior can become maladaptive.
Understanding neural circuits involved in assigning appetitive value to rewarding cues and actions is important.
Ventral pallidum (VP) neurons contribute to cue-elicited reward-seeking behavior.
VP neurons have heterogeneous responses in a discriminative stimulus (DS) task.
The specific VP neuronal subtypes and output pathways encoding distinct aspects of the DS task are unknown.
Researchers used an intersectional viral approach with fiber photometry to record calcium activity in VP GABAergic (VP GABA) neurons.
The study was conducted on male and female rats as they learned and performed the DS task.
VP GABA neurons are excited by reward-predictive cues but not neutral cues.
The response of VP GABA neurons to reward-predictive cues develops over time.
The cue-evoked response predicts reward-seeking behavior.
Inhibiting VP GABA activity during cue presentation decreases reward-seeking behavior.
Increased VP GABA calcium activity was observed at the time of expected reward delivery.
The increased calcium activity occurred even on trials when reward was omitted.
Findings suggest VP GABA neurons encode reward expectation.
Calcium activity in VP GABA neurons encodes the vigor of cue-elicited reward seeking.

original_abstract:
Epileptic brains are characterized by spontaneous seizures and interictal epileptiform discharges (IEDs).
Basic patterns of mesoscale brain activity outside seizures and IEDs are often disrupted in epileptic brains.
The study aimed to quantify differences in interictal brain activity between epileptic and healthy individuals.
The research sought to identify features of interictal activity that influence seizure occurrence in a genetic mouse model of childhood epilepsy.
Neural activity across the dorsal cortex was monitored using widefield Ca2+ imaging in mice.
The study included mice of both sexes expressing a human Kcnt1 variant (Kcnt1m/m) and wild-type controls (WT).
Ca2+ signals during seizures and interictal periods were classified based on spatiotemporal features.
52 spontaneous seizures were identified in the study.
Seizures emerged and propagated within a consistent set of susceptible cortical areas.
Seizures were predicted by a concentration of total cortical activity within the emergence zone.
Similar events were detected in Kcnt1m/m and WT mice outside of seizures and IEDs.
The spatial structure of interictal activity was similar between Kcnt1m/m and WT mice.
The rate of events whose spatial profile overlapped with seizure and IED emergence zones was increased in Kcnt1m/m mice.
The characteristic global intensity of cortical activity in individual Kcnt1m/m mice predicted their epileptic activity burden.
Cortical areas with excessive interictal activity are vulnerable to seizures.
Epilepsy is not an inevitable outcome of increased interictal activity.
Global scaling of cortical activity intensity below levels found in healthy brains may provide a natural mechanism of seizure protection.

The rate of events whose spatial profile overlapped with seizure and IED emergence zones was decreased in Kcnt1m/m mice.
The characteristic global intensity of cortical activity in individual Kcnt1m/m mice predicted their epileptic activity burden.
Cortical areas with insufficient interictal activity are vulnerable to seizures.
Epilepsy is not an inevitable outcome of increased interictal activity.
Global scaling of cortical activity intensity above levels found in healthy brains may provide a natural mechanism of seizure protection.

original_abstract:
Astrocytes are key cellular regulators in the brain.
The basolateral amygdala (BLA) is involved in fear memory processing.
Most research has focused on neuronal mechanisms, neglecting astrocytes.
Astrocytes have been implicated in learning and memory.
The study used in vivo fiber photometry in C57BL/6J male mice.
Researchers recorded from amygdalar astrocytes during fear learning, recall, and extinction.
BLA astrocytes responded robustly to foot shock during acquisition.
Astrocyte activity remained elevated across days compared to unshocked control animals.
Increased astrocyte activity persisted throughout extinction.
Astrocytes responded to the initiation and termination of freezing bouts during contextual fear conditioning and recall.
The behavior-locked pattern of astrocyte activity did not persist throughout extinction sessions.
Astrocytes did not display these changes while exploring a novel context.
The observations are specific to the original fear-associated environment.
Chemogenetic inhibition of fear ensembles in the BLA did not affect freezing behavior or astrocytic calcium dynamics.
The study presents a real-time role for amygdalar astrocytes in fear processing.
The research provides new insight into the emerging role of astrocytes in cognition and behavior.

original_abstract:
NMDA receptors (NMDARs) are ionotropic glutamate receptors crucial for excitatory neurotransmission.
Surface NMDAR numbers and subtypes are regulated through externalization, internalization, and lateral diffusion.
Novel anti-GFP nanobodies were conjugated to quantum dots QD525 and QD605 (nanoGFP-QD525 and nanoGFP-QD605).
These probes were compared to a larger probe: rabbit anti-GFP IgG with secondary IgG conjugated to QD605 (antiGFP-QD605).
The study targeted yellow fluorescent protein-tagged GluN1 subunits in rat hippocampal neurons.
NanoGFP-based probes allowed faster lateral diffusion of NMDARs with increased median diffusion coefficient (D) values.
Synaptic regions were marked using thresholded tdTomato-Homer1c signals.
Nanoprobe-based D values increased sharply at distances over 100 nm from the synaptic edge.
AntiGFP-QD605 probe D values remained unchanged up to 400 nm from the synaptic edge.
NanoGFP-QD605 probe was used to study GFP-GluN2A, GFP-GluN2B, and GFP-GluN3A subunits in hippocampal neurons.
Subunit-dependent differences were detected in synaptic localization, D value, synaptic residence time, and synaptic-extrasynaptic exchange rate.
The applicability of nanoGFP-QD605 probe was confirmed for studying synaptic NMDAR distribution differences.
Results were compared to data obtained using nanoGFPs conjugated to organic fluorophores.
Universal point accumulation imaging in nanoscale topography and direct stochastic optical reconstruction microscopy were used for comparison.

original_abstract:
Microstimulation can modulate individual neuron activity to affect behavior.
Effects of stimulation on neuronal spiking are complex and poorly understood.
Understanding stimulation effects is challenging in the human brain due to sparse and heterogeneous neuron response properties.
Study used microelectrode arrays in the human anterior temporal lobe.
6 participants were involved in the study (3 female).
Researchers examined spiking responses of individual neurons to microstimulation.
Microstimulation was delivered through multiple distinct stimulation sites.
Individual neurons can be driven with excitation or inhibition using different stimulation sites.
Findings suggest an approach for direct control of spiking activity at the single-neuron level.
Spiking responses are inhibitory in neurons close to the stimulation site.
Excitatory responses are more spatially distributed.
Data demonstrates that spiking responses of individual neurons can be reliably identified in human cortex.
Data shows that spiking responses of individual neurons can be manipulated in human cortex.

original_abstract:
Cognition and brain structure significantly mature from adolescence to adulthood.
Model-based (MB) control increases across development, mediated by cognitive abilities.
The study aimed to identify brain structural correlates of age-related increases in MB control.
The study also examined how age-related increases in MB control are influenced by motivational context.
A human developmental sample of 103 participants (ages 12-50, 55 males, 48 females) was used.
Participants completed structural MRI and a task to capture MB control.
The task included reward and punishment blocks to manipulate motivational context.
An additional choice test assessed learning from positive versus negative feedback.
The study replicated the finding that age-dependent increase in MB control is mediated by cognitive abilities.
Gray matter density (GMD) in the parietal cortex mediates the increase of MB control with age.
Motivational context did not relate to age-related changes in MB control.
Learning from positive feedback improved with age.
Negative feedback learning showed no age effects.
Age-related increase in positive feedback learning was mediated by reduced GMD in parietal, medial, and dorsolateral prefrontal cortex.
Brain maturation, reflected in lower GMD, may lead to more efficient brain organization.
Brain maturation might be a key developmental step toward age-related increases in planning and value-based choice.

original_abstract:
The infralimbic cortex (IL) mediates ongoing inhibition of cocaine seeking after self-administration and extinction training in rats.
IL projections to the nucleus accumbens shell (NAshell) are specifically involved in this inhibition.
IL activity immediately following an unreinforced lever press is critical for encoding extinction contingencies.
The study aimed to determine if extinction encoding requires activity in IL outputs to NAshell and amygdala.
A closed-loop optogenetic approach was used in female and male Sprague Dawley rats.
IL–NAshell or IL–amygdala activity was silenced following an unreinforced lever press during extinction training.
Optical illumination (20 s) was given either immediately after a lever press or following a 20 s delay.
Immediate IL–NAshell inhibition increased lever pressing during extinction training.
Immediate IL–NAshell inhibition impaired retention of extinction learning in subsequent sessions without optical inhibition.
Immediate IL–amygdala inhibition also impaired extinction retention during sessions without inhibition.
Delayed IL–NAshell and IL–amygdala inhibition had no effect on extinction learning.
Critical encoding of extinction learning does not require activity in these pathways beyond the initial 20 s post-lever press period.
Results suggest a larger network extending from IL to NAshell and amygdala is involved in encoding extinction contingencies following cocaine self-administration.

original_abstract:
Visuospatial attention has been studied extensively for its behavioral consequences and neural underpinnings.
The Posner paradigm demonstrates that spatially informative cues improve visual perception compared to noninformative cues.
Lateralized α amplitude modulation during attention shifts was thought to account for perceptual gain.
Recent studies on spontaneous prestimulus α amplitude fluctuations have challenged this idea.
Spontaneous prestimulus α amplitude fluctuations were linked to subjective perception of stimulus occurrence.
Objective accuracy was better predicted by α oscillation frequency, with faster prestimulus α frequency associated with better performance.
The study used an informative cue before lateralized stimulus presentation in male and female humans.
The predictive cue modulated both preparatory α amplitude and α frequency in a retinotopic manner.
The cue significantly impacted subjective performance measures (metacognitive abilities) and objective performance gain.
α amplitude directly accounted for confidence levels.
Ipsilateral synchronization and contralateral desynchronization coded for high-confidence responses.
Contralateral α amplitude selectively predicted interindividual differences in metacognitive abilities.
α amplitude anticipated decision strategy rather than perceptual sensitivity, possibly via excitability modulations.
Higher perceptual accuracy was associated with faster contralateral α frequency within and across participants.
Faster α frequency likely implements higher sampling at the attended location.
The findings provide new insights into the neural mechanisms of attention control and its perceptual consequences.

original_abstract:
Hippocampus is crucial for retrieval of contextual memories.
Activation of a subpopulation of neurons in dorsal CA1 (dCA1) of hippocampus is required for memory retrieval.
Hippocampal neurons exhibit distinct patterns of response during memory retrieval.
Relation between activity patterns of individual neurons or ensembles and memory retrieval has been unclear.
Study used in vivo microendoscope calcium imaging to record neuronal activity in dCA1 of male and female mice.
A portion of dCA1 neurons increased responses to learned context after contextual fear conditioning (FC).
Overall increase in neuronal population response compared to simple context exposure.
Increased response was specific to conditioned context and disappeared in neutral context.
Magnitude of increase in neuronal responses was proportional to memory strength during retrieval.
Increases in activity preferentially occurred during putative sharp wave ripple events.
Activity increases were not simply due to animal's movement and immobility.
At ensemble level, synchronous cell activity patterns were associated with memory retrieval.
When activity patterns were more similar between conditioned and neutral context, animals displayed proportionally more similar levels of freezing.
Results indicate that increase in responses of individual neurons in dCA1 is critically involved in representing contextual memory recall.
Results suggest that synchronous cell activity patterns in dCA1 neuronal network are critically involved in representing contextual memory recall.

original_abstract:
The amygdalar anterior basolateral nucleus (BLa) is crucial for emotional behaviors.
BLa receives dense cholinergic projections from the basal forebrain.
Cholinergic signaling in BLa regulates neuronal activity and modulates afferent glutamatergic inputs.
Previous studies used cholinergic agonists or prolonged optogenetic stimulation, which may not reflect physiological acetylcholine release.
The study used electrophysiology and optogenetics in male and female mouse brain slices.
The research examined cholinergic regulation of afferent BLa input from cortex and midline thalamic nuclei.
Phasic ACh release had a biphasic effect on cortical input transmission.
Rapid nicotinic receptor-mediated facilitation was followed by slower mAChR-mediated depression.
Sustained ACh elevation suppressed glutamatergic transmission through mAChRs only at cortical input.
Suppression was not observed at midline thalamic nuclei inputs to BLa.
The mAChR agonist muscarine more potently suppressed transmission at inputs from prelimbic cortex than thalamus.
Muscarinic inhibition at prelimbic cortex input required presynaptic M4 mAChRs.
Muscarinic inhibition at thalamic input depended on M3 mAChR-mediated stimulation of retrograde endocannabinoid signaling.
Muscarinic inhibition at both pathways was frequency-dependent, allowing only high-frequency activity to pass.
The findings demonstrate complex cholinergic regulation of afferent input to BLa.
The cholinergic regulation is pathway-specific and frequency-dependent.

original_abstract:
Extracellular ATP acts as a "danger" molecule at high levels under pathologic conditions through purinergic receptors, including P2X7R.
P2X7R endogenous activation is associated with neurodevelopmental disorders.
The function of P2X7R during early embryonic stages is largely unclear.
The study aimed to determine P2X7R's role in regulating neuronal outgrowth.
Sholl analysis was performed on dendritic branches of primary hippocampal neurons and acute hippocampal slices.
Samples were taken from wild-type mice and mice with genetic deficiency or pharmacological blockade of P2X7R.
A maternal immune activation (MIA)-induced schizophrenia model was used for further morphologic investigations.
MIA-induced behavioral deficits were studied in young adult female and male mice.
Genetic deficiency or pharmacological blockade of P2X7R led to branching deficits under physiological conditions.
Pathologic activation of P2X7R caused dendritic outgrowth deficits in primary neurons from wild-type mice.
P2X7R KO mice exposed to MIA did not show dendritic outgrowth deficits.
Only MIA-exposed wild-type mice displayed schizophrenia-like behavioral and cognitive deficits.
P2X7R has different roles in the development of hippocampal dendritic arborization under physiological and pathologic conditions.

original_abstract:
Social deficits and dopaminergic midbrain-striato-frontal circuit dysregulations are transdiagnostic symptoms in psychiatric disorders.
Animal models indicate interactions between dopamine (DA) and renin-angiotensin system (RAS) may modulate learning and reward-related processes.
The study examined behavioral and neural effects of losartan (an Angiotensin II type 1 receptor antagonist) on social reward and punishment processing in humans.
A preregistered randomized double-blind placebo-controlled between-subject pharmacological design was used.
The study combined the design with a social incentive delay (SID) functional MRI (fMRI) paradigm.
Subjects could avoid social punishment or gain social reward during the paradigm.
Healthy volunteers received either a single 50 mg dose of losartan (n=43, 17 female) or placebo (n=44, 20 female).
Reaction times (RTs) and emotional ratings were evaluated as behavioral outcomes.
Activation and functional connectivity were evaluated as neural outcomes.
Losartan modulated reaction time and arousal differences between social punishment and social reward compared to placebo.
Losartan enhanced motivational salience of social rewards, accompanied by stronger ventral striatum-prefrontal connectivity during reward anticipation.
Losartan increased the reward-neutral difference in the ventral tegmental area (VTA).
Losartan attenuated VTA-associated connectivity with bilateral insula in response to punishment during the outcome phase.
Losartan modulated approach-avoidance motivation and emotional salience during social punishment versus social reward.
The modulation occurred via distinct core nodes of the midbrain-striato-frontal circuits.
Findings document a modulatory role of the renin-angiotensin system in these circuits and associated social processes.
Results suggest the renin-angiotensin system as a promising treatment target to alleviate social dysregulations.

original_abstract:
Distributed cortical regions show differential responses to visual objects from different domains varying by animacy (e.g., animals vs tools).
It is unclear whether this organization principle applies to subcortical structures.
The study combined multiple fMRI activation experiments, including two main experiments and six validation datasets.
Experiment 1 included 12 females and 9 males.
Experiment 2 included 10 females and 10 males.
The study used resting-state functional connectivity and task-based dynamic causal modeling analysis in human subjects.
Visual processing of animal and tool images elicited different response patterns in the pulvinar.
Tool-related responses showed robust left lateralization in the pulvinar.
Animal-related responses showed distinct, bilateral clusters with a rightward tendency in the pulvinar.
Domain-preferring activity distribution in the pulvinar was associated with the magnitude of intrinsic connections to corresponding domain-preferring cortical regions.
The pulvinar-to-right-amygdala path showed a one-way shortcut supporting animal perception.
The modulation connection from pulvinar to parietal showed an advantage for tool perception.
The results incorporate subcortical regions into the object processing network.
The findings suggest that domain organization is an overarching principle across various brain processing stages.

original_abstract:
Ventral subiculum (vSUB) is the main output region of ventral hippocampus (vHIPP).
vSUB sends major projections to nucleus accumbens medial shell (NAcMS).
Hyperactivity of the vSUB-NAcMS circuit is associated with substance use disorders.
Modulation of vSUB activity alters drug seeking and drug reinstatement behavior in rodents.
Cell type-specific connectivity and synaptic transmission properties of the vSUB-NAcMS circuit have not been directly examined before.
Previous studies focused on total vHIPP output to NAcMS without distinguishing vSUB from other subregions like ventral CA1 (vCA1).
Ex vivo electrophysiology was used to characterize the vSUB-NAcMS circuit in male and female mice.
vSUB output shows a functional connectivity bias for dopamine receptor type-2 (D2R) expressing medium spiny neurons (MSNs).
vSUB-D1R and vSUB-D2R MSN synapses contain calcium-permeable AMPA receptors in drug-naive mice.
Cocaine exposure selectively induces plasticity at vSUB-D2R synapses.
vSUB synapses are functionally distinct from vCA1 output to NAcMS.
vCA1 output recapitulated synaptic properties previously ascribed to vHIPP.
The study highlights the need to consider individual subregions of vHIPP in substance use disorders.
This research is a first step in understanding how the vSUB-NAcMS circuit contributes to substance use disorder etiologies.

original_abstract:
Cognitive control is the ability to adapt behavior flexibly in a goal-directed manner when habit is insufficient.
Control can be categorized based on timescale (present–future) and medium (external–internal).
The frontoparietal network (FPN) and cingulo-opercular network (CON) are involved in control, but their functions and interactions are not fully understood.
An fMRI study was conducted on humans (male and female) using a task that manipulated control across timescales and mediums.
The CON was found to have two separable subnetworks mirroring the FPN.
The rostral/ventral CON subnetwork is sensitive to future-oriented control involving internal representations.
The caudal/dorsal CON subnetwork is sensitive to present-oriented control involving external representations.
CON activation was particularly strong during transitions into and out of specific control demands compared to the FPN.
Each CON subnetwork's relationship to behavior was mediated by a respective FPN subnetwork.
The data suggest that the CON motivates the FPN, which then drives behavior.
Within the CON, the dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (dmPFC) mediated the relationship between the anterior insula and FPN.
The dmPFC appears to act as a crucial link between the CON and FPN.
The study concludes that parallel CON–FPN subnetworks mediate controlled behaviors at distinct timescales and mediums.

The vmPFC appears to act as a crucial link between the CON and FPN.
The study concludes that parallel CON–FPN subnetworks mediate controlled behaviors at distinct timescales and mediums.

original_abstract:
Sensory stimuli can trigger an orienting reflex in animals, causing them to move their head to position sensors.
Orienting responses may be important for evaluating stimuli that require action.
The dynamics of orienting responses in goal-directed actions are not well understood.
The study used mice of either sex to investigate orienting responses during a signaled avoidance action.
The conditioned stimulus (CS) evoked a fast head movement with rotational and translational components.
The orienting response varied based on the animal's behavioral and brain states set by task contingencies.
Larger CS-evoked orienting responses were associated with high-intensity auditory stimuli.
Larger responses were also linked to failures in producing appropriate signaled actions.
Uncertain or demanding situations and the animal's ability to cope affected the size of orienting responses.
The superior colliculus was confirmed to control and code the direction of spontaneous exploratory orienting movements.
Superior colliculus activity correlated with CS-evoked orienting responses.
Optogenetic inhibition or excitation of the superior colliculus potentiated CS-evoked orienting responses.
CS-evoked orienting responses are likely generated downstream in the medulla.
These responses may be useful for assessing behavioral and related brain states.
State-dependent modulation of orienting responses may involve the superior colliculus.

original_abstract:
Dynamic adaptation is an error-driven process of adjusting planned motor actions to changes in task dynamics.
Adapted motor plans are consolidated into memories that contribute to better performance on re-exposure.
Consolidation begins within 15 minutes following training.
Consolidation can be measured via changes in resting state functional connectivity (rsFC).
For dynamic adaptation, rsFC has not been previously quantified on a 15-minute timescale.
The relationship between rsFC and adaptative behavior has not been previously established for dynamic adaptation.
The study used an fMRI-compatible robot called the MR-SoftWrist.
The study aimed to quantify rsFC specific to dynamic adaptation of wrist movements and subsequent memory formation.
Participants were a mixed-sex cohort of humans.
fMRI was acquired during a motor execution task and a dynamic adaptation task to localize brain networks of interest.
rsFC was quantified within these networks in three 10-minute windows occurring immediately before and after each task.
Behavioral retention was assessed the next day.
A mixed model of rsFC was used to identify changes in rsFC with task performance.
Linear regression was used to identify the relationship between rsFC and behavior.
Following the dynamic adaptation task, rsFC increased within the cortico-cerebellar network.
rsFC decreased interhemispherically within the cortical sensorimotor network after the dynamic adaptation task.
Increases within the cortico-cerebellar network were specific to dynamic adaptation.
Cortico-cerebellar network increases were associated with behavioral measures of adaptation and retention.
The cortico-cerebellar network has a functional role in consolidation.
Decreases in rsFC within the cortical sensorimotor network were associated with motor control processes independent from adaptation and retention.

original_abstract:
The ability to quickly recognize and understand social interactions is important.
This ability relies on deciphering multiple information sources, such as perceiving body information and inferring intentions.
The brain basis of this ability in adults has been characterized in recent studies.
The developmental underpinnings of this ability are largely unknown.
fMRI was used to investigate sources of social information supporting superior temporal sulcus responses to interactive biological motion.
Interactive biological motion was represented by two interacting point-light human figures.
The study included human participants of either sex at different developmental intervals.
Children show supportive functional connectivity with key nodes of the mentalizing network.
Adults show stronger reliance on regions associated with body processing.
Adults also show stronger reliance on regions associated with dynamic social interaction and biological motion processing.
Adults are suggested to use efficient action-intention understanding via body and biological motion information.
Children show a stronger reliance on hidden mental state inferences.
Children's reliance on mental state inferences may be a potential means of learning to better understand others' interactive behavior.

original_abstract:
Mammalian sleep is regulated by a homeostatic process.
This process increases sleep drive and intensity based on prior wake time.
Sleep homeostasis was traditionally thought to be solely a product of neurons.
Recent findings show that glial astrocytes also modulate this process.
The precise role of astrocytes in sleep drive accumulation and discharge is unknown.
Researchers investigated this question using designer receptors exclusively activated by designer drugs (DREADDs).
The study focused on selectively activating basal forebrain (BF) astrocytes in male and female mice.
DREADD activation of the Gq-protein-coupled pathway in BF astrocytes was used.
This activation produced long and continuous periods of wakefulness.
Paradoxically, these periods did not cause the expected homeostatic response to sleep loss.
Expected responses would typically include increases in sleep time or intensity.
Further investigations showed this was not due to indirect effects of the DREADD-activating ligand.
Findings suggest that the need for sleep is not only driven by wakefulness itself.
Specific neuronal-glial circuits that are differentially activated in wakefulness also drive sleep need.

original_abstract:
The study reanalyzed motion selectivity in area MT of three macaque monkeys (two males, one female) using random-dot stimuli instead of spot stimuli.
No differences were found in the number of neurons tuned to centrifugal versus centripetal motion.
Centrifugally tuned neurons showed stronger tuning than centripetally tuned neurons.
The stronger tuning of centrifugal neurons was attributed to heightened suppression of responses to centripetal motion.
Modeling suggests that intensified suppression accounts for superior detection performance for weak centripetal motion stimuli.
Fisher information analysis shows that population sensitivity to motion direction in peripheral vision corresponds well with retinal motion statistics during forward locomotion.
Results challenge the long-held notion of overrepresentation of centrifugal motion in area MT.
The interplay of logarithmic Gaussian receptive fields and spot stimuli may explain the previously documented overrepresentation of centrifugal motion.
Findings reconcile a previously found discrepancy between MT activity and human behavior.
Results highlight the proficiency of peripheral MT neurons in encoding motion direction efficiently.
The study challenges the idea that overrepresentation of centrifugal motion provides an efficient coding strategy for optic flow processing.
Previous overrepresentation was thought to compromise the detection of approaching objects, which is essential for survival.

original_abstract:
SYNGAP1 haploinsufficiency in humans causes severe neurodevelopmental disorders.
These disorders include intellectual disability, autism, epilepsy, and sensory processing deficits.
The circuit mechanisms underlying these disorders are not well understood.
In mice, decreased SynGAP levels lead to cognitive deficits by affecting excitatory glutamatergic connections.
SynGAP also plays a crucial role in the development and function of GABAergic inhibitory interneurons.
The extent to which SYNGAP1 expression in inhibitory interneurons affects cortical circuit function and behavior is uncertain.
Cortical neuron activity has not been measured simultaneously with behavior in previous studies.
Researchers recorded from layer 2/3 neurons in the primary whisker somatosensory cortex (wS1) of mice during a whisker tactile detection task.
Mice with interneuron-specific SYNGAP1 haploinsufficiency showed learning deficits.
These deficits included heightened behavioral responses without relevant sensory input.
The mice also exhibited premature responses to unrelated sensory stimuli not associated with reward.
Behavioral deficits were accompanied by specific circuit abnormalities within wS1.
Interneuron-specific SYNGAP1 haploinsufficiency increased detrimental neuronal correlations related to task performance.
It also enhanced responses to irrelevant sensory stimuli unrelated to reward acquisition.
Reduction of SynGAP in inhibitory interneurons impairs sensory representation in the primary sensory cortex.
This impairment occurs by disrupting neuronal correlations.
The disruption likely contributes to cognitive deficits observed in mice with pan-neuronal SYNGAP1 haploinsufficiency.

original_abstract:
Cerebral creatine deficiency syndrome (CCDS) is an inborn error of metabolism.
CCDS is characterized by intellectual delays, seizures, and autistic-like behavior.
The role of endogenously synthesized creatine on CNS development and function is poorly understood.
Magnetic resonance spectroscopy of adult mouse brains revealed creatine synthesis depends on guanidinoacetate methyltransferase (GAMT) expression.
A mouse line with a knock-in GFP was generated to identify Gamt-expressed cells and study Gamt's effects on postnatal CNS development.
Gamt is expressed in mature oligodendrocytes during active myelination in the developing postnatal CNS.
Homozygous deletion of Gamt resulted in reduced mature oligodendrocytes and delayed myelination in the corpus callosum.
Absence of endogenous creatine altered AMPK signaling in the brain.
Creatine deficiency reduced brain creatine kinase expression in cortical neurons.
Lack of endogenous creatine showed signs of axonal damage.
Experimental demyelination in mice with conditional deletion of Gamt in oligodendrocyte lineage cells resulted in delayed oligodendrocyte maturation and myelin coverage in lesions.
Creatine and cyclocreatine supplementation can enhance remyelination after demyelination.
Endogenously synthesized creatine controls the bioenergetic demand for timely oligodendrocyte maturation during postnatal CNS development.
Delayed myelination and altered CNS energetics from disrupted creatine synthesis may contribute to conditions like CCDS.

original_abstract:
Many people sleep less than recommended without experiencing daytime sleepiness.
Prevailing views suggest short sleep increases risk of lower brain health and cognitive function.
Chronic mild sleep deprivation could cause undetected sleep debt, negatively affecting cognitive function and brain health.
Some individuals may have less sleep need and be more resistant to negative effects of sleep loss.
The study investigated this using cross-sectional and longitudinal samples from 47,029 participants of both sexes, aged 20-89 years.
Data came from the Lifebrain consortium, Human Connectome project (HCP), and UK Biobank (UKB).
The study included measures of self-reported sleep, 51,295 brain MRIs, and cognitive tests.
740 participants reported sleeping <6 hours without experiencing daytime sleepiness or sleep problems.
These short sleepers showed significantly larger regional brain volumes compared to other groups.
Short sleepers with daytime sleepiness and sleep problems numbered 1,742.
Participants sleeping the recommended 7-8 hours numbered 3,886.
Both groups of short sleepers showed slightly lower general cognitive function (GCA), 0.16 and 0.19 standard deviations respectively.
Analyses using accelerometer-estimated sleep duration confirmed the findings.
Associations remained after controlling for body mass index, depression symptoms, income, and education.
Results suggest some people can cope with less sleep without obvious negative associations with brain morphometry.
Sleepiness and sleep problems may be more related to brain structural differences than sleep duration.
The slightly lower performance on tests of general cognitive abilities warrants closer examination in natural settings.

original_abstract:
Recent research has focused on parent-child neural similarity using fMRI.
There is a need for more research on how this similarity affects children's emotional adjustment.
No previous studies have explored contextual factors moderating the link between parent-child neural similarity and children's developmental outcomes.
The study involved 32 parent-youth dyads.
Parents had a mean age of 43.53 years and were 72% female.
Children had a mean age of 11.69 years and were 41% female.
Participants watched an emotion-evoking animated film during fMRI scanning.
Researchers quantified the similarity in emotion network interactions with other brain regions between parents and children.
The study examined how parent-child neural similarity is associated with children's emotional adjustment.
The moderating role of family cohesion was considered in the analysis.
Higher parent-child similarity in functional connectivity patterns during movie viewing was associated with better emotional adjustment in youth.
Better emotional adjustment included less negative affect, lower anxiety, and greater ego resilience.
The associations between neural similarity and emotional adjustment were significant only in families with higher cohesion.
No significant associations were found in families with lower cohesion.
The findings advance understanding of neural mechanisms underlying how children thrive by being in sync with their parents.
The study provides novel empirical evidence that the effects of parent-child neural concordance on children's development are contextually dependent.

original_abstract:
Age-related impairments in value representations and updating during decision-making and reward-based learning are often linked to attenuation in the catecholamine system.
The study aimed to investigate the extent to which age-related declines in norepinephrine (NE) functioning affect reward-based decision-making in humans.
A probabilistic decision-making task was conducted, and a Q-learning model was applied to investigate participants' anticipatory values and value sensitivities.
Task-related pupil dilations and locus coeruleus (LC) magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) contrast were assessed in younger and older adults.
Younger adults' (N = 42, 22 males) pupil dilations negatively correlated with anticipatory values in both choice and feedback phases, indicating uncertainty about outcome probabilities.
Older adults (N = 41, 27 males) showed smaller uncertainty-evoked pupil dilations, suggesting age-related impairments in value estimation and updating.
In both age groups, participants with larger uncertainty-evoked pupil dilation exhibited higher value sensitivity, as reflected in the β parameter of the reinforcement Q-learning model.
Older adults (N = 34, 29 males) showed a lower LC-MRI contrast compared to younger adults (N = 25, 15 males).
The LC-MRI contrast positively correlated with value sensitivity only in older adults, not in younger adults.
Task-related pupillary responses can reflect age-related deficits in value estimation and updating during reward-based decision-making.
LC-MRI contrast evidence showed age-related decline of the LC structure in modulating value representations during reward-based learning.

original_abstract:
Repeated exposure to a stimulus results in reduced neural response, or repetition suppression, in brain regions processing that stimulus.
Rapid accommodation to repetition is thought to underlie learning, stimulus selectivity, and strengthening of perceptual expectations.
Reduced sensitivity to repetition has been identified in several neurodevelopmental, learning, and psychiatric disorders, including autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
ASD is characterized by challenges in social communication and repetitive behaviors and restricted interests.
Reduced ability to exploit or learn from repetition in ASD is hypothesized to contribute to sensory hypersensitivities.
This parallels theories claiming ASD individuals have difficulty using environmental regularities to facilitate behavior.
The study used fMRI to assess repetition suppression in autistic and neurotypical human adults (females and males).
The assessment covered two modalities (vision, audition) and four stimulus categories (faces, objects, printed words, and spoken words).
ASD individuals showed domain-specific reductions in repetition suppression for face stimuli only.
No reductions were observed for objects, printed words, or spoken words.
Reduced repetition suppression for faces was associated with greater challenges in social communication in ASD.
The study found altered functional connectivity between atypically adapting cortical regions and higher-order face recognition regions in ASD.
Microstructural differences in related white matter tracts were observed in ASD.
The results suggest fundamental neural mechanisms and system-wide circuits are selectively altered for face processing in ASD.
The findings enhance understanding of how disruptions in forming stable face representations may relate to higher-order social communication processes.

original_abstract:
Perceptual decisions require the brain to acquire and incorporate environmental evidence samples.
Neural circuits processing sensory information and forming decisions are well-understood.
Mechanisms linking sensory processing and decision-making circuits are less known.
Monkeys of both sexes were trained to make difficult decisions about visual motion direction.
The experiment required trial-by-trial control of functional connectivity.
Two conditions were used: motion appearing at different locations, and two motion patches with only one being informative.
Neurons in the parietal cortex produced brief oscillations in firing rate when routing was established.
Oscillations occurred upon motion display onset when location was unpredictable across trials.
Oscillations also occurred upon attention cue onset indicating the informative patch location.
No oscillation was observed when stimulus location was fixed across trials.
The oscillation is interpreted as a manifestation of the mechanism establishing the source and destination of flexibly routed information.
The oscillation is not interpreted as the transmission of information itself.

original_abstract:
The human brain can learn and use probabilistic associations between stimuli to predict future events.
Previous studies have shown how perceptual relationships are used to predict sensory inputs.
Relational knowledge often involves concepts rather than percepts.
This study investigated if and how sensory responses to visual input are modulated by predictions from conceptual associations.
Participants were exposed to arbitrary word-word pairs repeatedly, creating expectations of the second word.
In a subsequent session, participants were shown novel word-picture pairs while undergoing fMRI.
All word-picture pairs were equally likely, but half conformed to previously formed conceptual associations.
Results showed suppressed sensory responses in the ventral visual stream to pictures corresponding to previously expected words.
This suggests learned conceptual associations were used to generate sensory predictions that modulated picture processing.
The modulations were tuning-specific, selectively suppressing neural populations tuned toward the expected input.
Recently acquired conceptual priors are generalized across domains.
The sensory brain uses these priors to generate category-specific predictions.
This process facilitates the processing of expected visual input.
The study included participants of both sexes.
fMRI BOLD responses were measured during the experiment.
The ventral visual stream, including early visual cortex, showed suppressed sensory responses.

original_abstract:
Binary classification involves sorting items into two classes by setting a boundary.
Recent history can bias binary classification.
Repulsive bias is a common form of this bias.
Repulsive bias is the tendency to sort an item into the class opposite to its preceding items.
Two contending sources of repulsive bias are sensory-adaptation and boundary-updating.
No neural support had previously been provided for either source.
The study explored human brains of both men and women using fMRI.

original_abstract:
Sentence meaning depends on how words combine, not just individual words.
Brain mechanisms for semantic composition are poorly understood.
Two hypotheses are introduced to understand the neural vector code of semantic composition.
Hypothesis 1: Intrinsic dimensionality of neural representations increases as a sentence unfolds.
Hypothesis 2: Progressive integration is reflected in ramping and sentence-final signals.
A dataset of normal and jabberwocky sentences was designed to test these predictions.
11 human participants (5 men, 6 women) were monitored with MEG and intracranial EEG.
Deep language models were also used in the study.
Representational dimensionality was higher for meaningful sentences than jabberwocky in both models and electrophysiological data.
Multivariate decoding of normal versus jabberwocky revealed three dynamic patterns.
Pattern 1: Phasic pattern following each word, peaking in temporal and parietal areas.
Pattern 2: Ramping pattern in bilateral inferior and middle frontal gyri.
Pattern 3: Sentence-final pattern in left superior frontal gyrus and right orbitofrontal cortex.
Results provide insight into the neural geometry of semantic integration.
Findings constrain the search for a neural code of linguistic composition.

original_abstract:
Humans form and retrieve event files during goal-directed behavior.
Event files are conjunctive representations linking context-specific information about stimuli, associated actions, and expected outcomes.
Automatic formation and retrieval of event files can facilitate efficient action selection.
Recent behavioral work suggests event files may adversely affect future behavior when action requirements change between task contexts.
A study was conducted to directly test this hypothesis using a method for measuring neural representations of context-specific stimulus-action conjunctions.
35 male and female adult humans participated in a task switching paradigm while undergoing EEG recordings.
The study replicated previous behavioral findings, showing significant reaction time costs when action requirements changed between spaced repetitions of the same task.
Researchers combined multivariate pattern analysis and representational similarity analysis of EEG recordings with linear mixed-effects modeling of trial-to-trial behavior.
The magnitude of the behavioral cost was directly proportional to the strength of the conjunctive representation formed during the most recent previous exposure to the same task.
This confirms that the formation of conjunctive representations of specific task contexts, stimuli, and actions in the brain can adversely affect future behavior.
The findings demonstrate the potential of neural decoding of complex task set representations for predicting behavior beyond the current trial.

original_abstract:
Fast gamma oscillations are generated in the retina and transmitted to the cortex via the LGN.
These oscillations are thought to carry information about stimulus size and continuity.
The hypothesis is based mainly on studies conducted under anesthesia.
The validity of this hypothesis under more naturalistic conditions is unclear.
Multielectrode recordings of spiking activity were conducted in the retina and LGN of male and female cats.
Visually driven gamma oscillations are absent in awake states.
Gamma oscillations are highly dependent on halothane or isoflurane anesthesia.
Under ketamine anesthesia, responses were nonoscillatory, similar to the awake condition.
Response entrainment to the monitor refresh was commonly observed up to 120 Hz.
Halothane-induced gamma oscillatory responses superseded the monitor refresh entrainment.
Retinal gamma oscillations are contingent on halothane anesthesia.
Gamma oscillations are absent in the awake cat.
These oscillations should be considered artifactual.
Gamma oscillations likely play no functional role in vision.

original_abstract:
Neurons must meet core molecular, cellular, and temporal requirements for correct synapse formation and functional circuits.
It is unclear if all neurons use the same organizational mechanisms for synaptic connections and maturation due to neuronal diversity.
It is unknown if neurons in the same sensory circuit develop on similar timescales and use identical molecular approaches for synapse formation.
The study used the Drosophila antennal lobe (AL) as a model olfactory circuit.
Tissue-specific genetic labeling of active zones was used to analyze synapse formation quantitatively.
The analysis included multiple classes of neurons of both sexes throughout development and adulthood.
Olfactory receptor neurons (ORNs), projection neurons (PNs), and local interneurons (LNs) each have unique time courses of synaptic development, addition, and refinement.
Each neuronal class follows a distinct developmental program.
The study genetically altered neuronal activity in each neuronal subtype to observe effects on synapse number.
Silencing neuronal activity impaired synaptic development in ORNs, PNs, and LNs.
Enhancing neuronal activity influenced synapse formation only in ORNs.
ORNs and LNs showed similar impairment of synaptic development with enhanced activity of GSK-3β kinase.
Neuronal activity and GSK-3β kinase activity may function in a common pathway for ORNs and LNs.
ORNs demonstrated impaired synaptic development with GSK-3β loss-of-function, suggesting additional activity-independent roles.
Requirements for synaptic development are not uniform across all neuronal classes.
Considerable diversity exists in developmental time frames and molecular requirements among neuronal classes.
The findings provide novel insights into synaptic development mechanisms.
The study lays the foundation for future work on determining underlying etiologies of synaptic development.

original_abstract:
Prior knowledge significantly impacts how we perceive the world.
The mechanism of how prior knowledge is maintained in the brain and influences conscious perception is unclear.
The Dalmatian dog illusion is used as a tool to study prior knowledge.
In the Dalmatian dog illusion, the picture is initially perceived as noise but becomes meaningful once prior knowledge is introduced.
The study used pictures with hidden objects as standard stimuli and similar pictures without hidden objects as deviant stimuli.
An oddball paradigm using electroencephalogram (EEG) was employed to investigate neural representation of prior knowledge and its impact on conscious perception.
The study included both male and female human subjects.
After prior knowledge was provided, neural patterns between prestimulus alpha band oscillations and poststimulus EEG activity were significantly more similar for standard stimuli than for deviant stimuli.
Decoding analysis revealed that persistent neural templates were evoked after the introduction of prior knowledge.
These persistent neural templates were similar to those evoked in the early stages of visual processing.
The study suggests that prior knowledge uses alpha band oscillations in a multivariate manner during the prestimulus period.
Prior knowledge induces specific persistent neural templates in the poststimulus period.
These mechanisms enable the conscious perception of hidden objects.

original_abstract:
Our eyes constantly sample the environment, yet our subjective experience of the world remains stable and constant.
Stimulus displacement during or shortly after a saccade often goes unnoticed, a phenomenon called saccadic suppression of displacement.
Despite not noticing displacements, our oculomotor system computes prediction errors and adjusts gaze and future saccadic execution, known as saccadic adaptation.
The study aimed to find a brain signature of the trans-saccadic prediction error that informs the motor system but not explicit perception.
Participants were asked to report whether a visual target was displaced during a saccade while their electroencephalography (EEG) was recorded.
Multivariate pattern analysis was used to differentiate displacements from no displacements, even when participants failed to report the displacement.
Trans-saccadic prediction error was found to be represented in the EEG signal 100 ms after the displacement presentation.
The error signal was mainly detected in occipital and parieto-occipital channels.
The error signal was present even in the absence of explicit perception of the displacement.
Participants included both males and females.

original_abstract:
α-Synuclein plays a key role in Parkinson's disease pathogenesis and related disorders.
Critical interacting partners and molecular mechanisms of α-synuclein neurotoxicity are not fully understood.
The study shows that α-synuclein binds directly to β-spectrin.
A Drosophila model of α-synuclein-related disorders was used, including both males and females.
β-spectrin is demonstrated to be critical for α-synuclein neurotoxicity.
The ankyrin binding domain of β-spectrin is required for α-synuclein binding and neurotoxicity.
Na+/K+ ATPase, a key plasma membrane target of ankyrin, is mislocalized when human α-synuclein is expressed in Drosophila.
Membrane potential is depolarized in α-synuclein transgenic fly brains.
The same pathway was examined in human neurons.
Parkinson's disease patient-derived neurons with α-synuclein locus triplication show disruption of the spectrin cytoskeleton.
These patient-derived neurons also exhibit mislocalization of ankyrin and Na+/K+ ATPase.
Membrane potential depolarization is observed in the patient-derived neurons.
The findings define a specific molecular mechanism by which elevated levels of α-synuclein in Parkinson's disease and related α-synucleinopathies lead to neuronal dysfunction and death.

original_abstract:
Biological neuronal networks are thought to self-organize toward a critical state with stable recruitment dynamics.
In this critical state, individual neurons would statistically activate exactly one further neuron during neuronal avalanches.
This concept conflicts with observed explosive recruitment dynamics in neocortical minicolumns in vivo and neuronal clusters in vitro.
The explosive recruitment dynamics suggest neurons form supercritical local circuits.
Theoretical studies propose that modular networks with a mix of regionally subcritical and supercritical dynamics could create apparently critical dynamics.
This theory potentially resolves the inconsistency between critical and supercritical observations.
The study manipulated the structural self-organization process of cultured rat cortical neurons to test this theory.
Increasing clustering in developing neuronal networks correlated strongly with avalanche size distributions transitioning from supercritical to subcritical activity dynamics.
Moderately clustered networks showed avalanche size distributions approximating a power law, indicating overall critical recruitment.
The study proposes that activity-dependent self-organization can tune inherently supercritical networks toward mesoscale criticality.
This tuning is achieved by creating a modular structure in neuronal networks.

original_abstract:
Dexterous object manipulation relies on information about forces normal and tangential to fingerpads, as well as torque associated with object orientation at grip surfaces.
The study investigated how torque information is encoded by human tactile afferents in fingerpads.
Results were compared to 97 afferents recorded in monkeys (n = 3; 2 females) from a previous study.
Human data included slowly-adapting Type-II (SA-II) afferents, which are absent in monkey glabrous skin.
Torques of different magnitudes (3.5–7.5 mNm) were applied in clockwise and anticlockwise directions to fingerpads of 34 human subjects (19 females).
Torques were superimposed on 2, 3, or 4 N background normal forces.
Unitary recordings were made from fast-adapting Type-I (FA-I, n = 39), slowly-adapting Type-I (SA-I, n = 31), and Type-II (SA-II, n = 13) afferents.
Recordings were made via microelectrodes inserted into the median nerve.
All three afferent types encoded torque magnitude and direction.
Torque sensitivity was higher with smaller normal forces.
SA-I afferent responses to static torque were inferior to dynamic stimuli in humans.
In monkeys, SA-I afferent responses to static torque were superior to dynamic stimuli.
In humans, the inferior static torque response might be compensated by sustained SA-II afferent input.
SA-II afferents can increase or decrease firing rates with direction of rotation.
The discrimination capacity of individual afferents of each type was inferior in humans compared to monkeys.
The inferior discrimination capacity in humans could be due to differences in fingertip tissue compliance and skin friction.

original_abstract:
The Slack channel (KCNT1, Slo2.2) is a sodium-activated and chloride-activated potassium channel.
It regulates heart rate and maintains normal nervous system excitability.
The study aimed to identify sodium-sensitive and chloride-sensitive sites in the channel.
Researchers conducted electrophysical recordings and systematic mutagenesis of cytosolic acidic residues in the rat Slack channel C terminus.
Two potential sodium-binding sites were identified in the C-terminal domain.
The M335A mutant was used to open the Slack channel without cytosolic sodium.
92 negatively charged amino acids were screened.
E373 mutants completely removed sodium sensitivity of the Slack channel.
Several other mutants showed dramatic decreases in sodium sensitivity without abolishing it entirely.
Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations were performed at hundreds of nanoseconds timescale.
MD simulations revealed one or two sodium ions at the E373 position or an acidic pocket of negatively charged residues.
MD simulations also predicted possible chloride interaction sites.
Screening of predicted positively charged residues identified R379 as a chloride interaction site.
The study concludes that E373 site and D863/E865 pocket are two potential sodium-sensitive sites.
R379 is identified as a chloride interaction site in the Slack channel.

original_abstract:
Study focused on understanding how episodic memories for distinct experiences in familiar environments are encoded.
Researchers developed a spatial decision-making task for male rats.
Task involved navigating a multiarm maze to find food reward while avoiding arms with aversive stimuli.
Learning the task induced partial remapping in CA1 place cells.
Researchers identified both remapping and stable cell populations.
Remapping cells were recruited into sharp-wave ripples and associated replay events more than stable cells.
Remapping and stable cells had similar firing rates during maze navigation.
Results suggest recruitment into replay events may be a mechanism for incorporating new contextual information.
This mechanism may integrate new information into previously formed and stabilized spatial representations.
The study builds upon previous research on hippocampal place cell system and memory encoding for distinct places.

original_abstract:
Opioid withdrawal disrupts emotional learning circuits, driving relapse and compulsive drug use.
The mechanisms of how these circuits become disrupted during withdrawal are not well understood.
Amygdala neurons mediate relapse and are highly sensitive to opioids.
The researchers hypothesized that opioid withdrawal would induce adaptations in amygdala neurons, disrupting emotional learning circuit function.
Under normal conditions, synaptic transmission between the basolateral amygdala (BLA) and the main island (Im) of GABAergic intercalated cells (ITCs) is strongly inhibited by endogenous opioids.
The study used patch-clamp electrophysiology in brain slices from male rats.
Opioid withdrawal was found to reduce the ability of endogenous opioids to inhibit neurotransmission.
This reduction is caused by a protein kinase A (PKA)-driven increase in synaptic activity of peptidases.
Reduced peptide control of neurotransmission in the amygdala shifts the excitatory/inhibitory balance of inputs onto accumbens-projecting amygdala cells involved in relapse.
The findings provide new insights into how peptidases control synaptic activity within the amygdala.
Restoring endogenous peptide activity during withdrawal is suggested as a potential approach to mitigate withdrawal-induced disruptions in emotional learning circuits.
This approach may help rescue relapse behaviors exhibited during opioid withdrawal and into abstinence.

original_abstract:
Previous studies show human cerebral cortex folds (sulci) flatten during postnatal development.
Prior research did not examine the relationship between sulcal morphology and cognitive development in individuals.
This study used cross-sectional morphologic neuroimaging data from the lateral prefrontal cortex (LPFC) of 108 participants aged 6-36 years.
The study analyzed 3,672 sulci from the cross-sectional data.
Longitudinal morphologic and behavioral data were collected from 44 child and adolescent participants aged 6-18 years.
The longitudinal study analyzed 2,992 sulci.
Thousands of sulci were manually defined for the study.
LPFC sulcal morphology (depth, surface area, and gray matter thickness) differed between children/adolescents and young adults in cross-sectional analysis.
Only cortical thickness showed differences across childhood and adolescence.
Cortical thickness presented longitudinal changes during childhood and adolescence.
A data-driven approach linked morphology and cognition.
Longitudinal changes in cortical thickness of four left-hemisphere LPFC sulci predicted changes in reasoning performance.
Reasoning is a higher-level cognitive ability that relies on LPFC.
Results suggest sulci may flatten either after this time frame or over a longer period than previously thought.
Findings indicate longitudinal changes in specific LPFC sulci are behaviorally meaningful.
The study provides targeted structures and cortical areas for future neuroimaging studies on cognitive ability development.

original_abstract:
Study aimed to understand how prefrontal networks mediate cognitive control disrupted in schizophrenia.
A variant of the AX continuous performance task was translated for use with two male monkeys.
Neurons in prefrontal cortex (PFC) and parietal cortex were recorded during task performance.
Task involved contextual information from cue stimuli determining responses to subsequent probe stimuli.

Increased cognitive control demand biased contextual information representation toward PFC.
Higher cognitive control demand augmented temporal correlation of task-defined information between the two areas.
Oscillatory dynamics in local field potentials differed between cortical areas.
Local field potentials carried as much task condition information as spike rates.
At the single-neuron level, task-evoked activity patterns were nearly identical between PFC and parietal cortex.
Distinct population dynamics were observed in PFC and parietal cortex.
Results suggest differential contributions of PFC and parietal cortex to cognitive control.

A variant of the AX continuous performance task was translated for use with two male monkeys.
Neurons in prefrontal cortex (PFC) and parietal cortex were recorded during task performance.
Task involved contextual information from cue stimuli determining responses to subsequent probe stimuli.
Parietal neurons encoding behavioral context showed nearly identical activity to prefrontal counterparts.
Neural population switched stimulus preference based on cognitive control demand.
Cues evoked visual responses that appeared first in prefrontal neurons.
Population activity encoding contextual information was stronger and more persistent in parietal cortex.
Increased cognitive control demand biased contextual information representation toward parietal cortex.
Higher cognitive control demand augmented temporal correlation of task-defined information between the two areas.
Oscillatory dynamics in local field potentials differed between cortical areas.
Local field potentials carried as much task condition information as spike rates.
At the single-neuron level, task-evoked activity patterns were nearly identical between PFC and parietal cortex.
Distinct population dynamics were observed in PFC and parietal cortex.
Results suggest differential contributions of PFC and parietal cortex to cognitive control.

original_abstract:
The amplitude envelope of speech is crucial for accurate comprehension.
Neural activity in the theta-delta bands (1-10 Hz) tracks the phase of the speech amplitude envelope during listening.
Two competing mechanisms have been proposed to explain envelope tracking: entrainment of endogenous low-frequency oscillations and evoked responses to acoustic landmarks.
MEG recordings were collected from participants (n = 12, 6 female) while they listened to natural speech.
Two computational models were compared: an oscillatory entrainment model and an evoked response model.
Speech was presented at normal and slowed rates to differentiate between the two models' predictions.
Transient theta phase-locking was observed in regular speech, consistent with both models.
For slow speech, transient theta and delta phase-locking was observed, compatible with the evoked response model but not the oscillatory entrainment model.
Encoding of acoustic edge magnitudes was invariant to contextual speech rate, demonstrating speech rate normalization.
Results suggest that neural phase-locking to the speech envelope is more likely to reflect discrete representation of transient information rather than oscillatory entrainment.

original_abstract:
Relative motion breaks camouflaged targets from same-textured backgrounds, enabling discrimination of motion-defined objects.
Ring (R) neurons are critical components in the Drosophila central complex, involved in visually guided behaviors.
Two-photon calcium imaging with female flies showed that superior R neurons encoded motion-defined bars with high spatial frequency contents.
Upstream superior tuberculo-bulbar (TuBu) neurons transmitted visual signals to superior R neurons via acetylcholine release at synapses.
Blocking TuBu or R neurons impaired tracking performance of the bar, indicating their importance in motion-defined feature encoding.
Low spatial frequency luminance-defined bars evoked consistent excitation in R neurons of the superior bulb.
R neurons in the inferior bulb showed either excited or inhibited responses to low spatial frequency luminance-defined bars.
The distinct response properties to different bar stimuli suggest a functional division between bulb subdomains.
Physiological and behavioral tests with restricted lines indicate R4d neurons play a vital role in tracking motion-defined bars.
The central complex receives motion-defined features via a visual pathway from superior TuBu to R neurons.
Different visual features might be encoded via distinct response patterns at the population level in the central complex.
These encoded visual features drive visually guided behaviors in Drosophila.

original_abstract:
Study conducted on 10 adult cats (5 males, 5 females) before and after lateral mid-thoracic hemisection on the right side of the spinal cord.
Kinematic and electromyography data collected while cats negotiated obstacles of three different heights.
Data collected before hemisection and at weeks 1-2 and 7-8 after hemisection.
Intact cats always cleared obstacles without contact.
At weeks 1-2 post-hemisection, ipsilesional right hindlimb contacted obstacles in ~50% of trials.
Contact triggered stumbling corrective reaction or absent responses (termed "Other").
When complete clearance occurred, exaggerated ipsilesional hindlimb flexion observed with contralesional Left limbs leading.
At weeks 7-8 post-hemisection, proportion of complete clearance increased.
Other responses decreased at weeks 7-8, while stumbling corrective reactions remained relatively unchanged.
Redistribution of weight support observed after hemisection.
Reduced diagonal supports and increased homolateral supports, particularly on the left contralesional side.
Main neural strategy for complete clearance in intact cats was increased knee flexor activation.
Post-hemisection, ipsilesional knee flexor activation remained but was insufficient or more variable as limb approached obstacle.
Intact cats increased speed when stepping over obstacles, which disappeared after hemisection.
Increase in complete clearance over time paralleled recovery of muscle activation patterns or new strategies.
Results suggest partial recovery of anticipatory control through neuroplastic changes in the locomotor control system.

original_abstract:
Activation of the primary motor cortex (M1) is important for skilled movement execution and motor learning.
M1 dysfunction contributes to the pathophysiology of Parkinson's disease (PD).
A common belief in PD research is that midbrain dopamine loss leads to decreased M1 activation by the motor thalamus (Mthal).
This idea had not been experimentally tested prior to this study.
The study found that midbrain dopamine loss altered Mthal input in a laminar- and cell type-specific manner.
Laminar-specific changes in intracortical synaptic transmission were observed.
Frequency-dependent changes in synaptic dynamics were also noted.
The results demonstrate that loss of midbrain dopaminergic neurons alters thalamocortical activation of M1 in both male and female mice.
The study provides new insights into circuit mechanisms for motor cortex dysfunction in a mouse model of PD.
