original_abstract:
The study examined how people align their behaviors and decisions with others' expectations, especially those of higher social status, when being observed.
The research focused on the neural mechanisms underlying increased conformity to social hierarchy under social observation.
A preference rating task was used to investigate how individual preferences for novel stimuli were influenced by others' preferences.
The study manipulated others' social hierarchy and observational context.
Behavioral results showed that participants were more likely to change their preferences to match those of a superior partner in public than in private.
fMRI data revealed distinct contributions of subregions of the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) to increased conformity to social hierarchy under observation.
The ventral mPFC showed increased activity when participants' preferences aligned with those of superior partners, regardless of behavioral manifestation.
The rostral mPFC showed increased activity when conforming to a superior partner and nonconforming to an inferior one, indicating goal-dependent valuation.
The dorsal mPFC showed increased activity in private conditions with a superior partner, but only in those with a higher tendency to conform.
The findings support the hierarchical allostatic regulation model of mPFC function for social valuation.
The results suggest strategic conformity as a way to minimize metabolic costs.
The study included human participants of both sexes.

original_abstract:
Individual differences in delay discounting are associated with general life outcomes, psychopathology, and obesity.
Machine learning was applied to fMRI activity during an intertemporal choice task to develop a functional brain marker of individual differences in delay discounting.
The study involved two datasets: Study 1 (N = 110 male adults) and Study 2 (N = 145 male and female adults).
Training and cross-validating the marker in Study 1 resulted in a significant prediction–outcome correlation (r = 0.49).
The marker generalized to predict individual differences in Study 2 (r = 0.45).
The marker predicted discounting behavior several weeks later.
Out-of-sample responses of the functional brain marker differed significantly between overweight and lean individuals in both studies.
The marker predicted fasting-state blood levels of insulin, c-peptide, and leptin in Study 1.
Discounting behavior itself did not show significant differences between overweight and lean individuals.
Significant predictive weights of the marker were found in cingulate, insula, and frontoparietal areas.
The marker suggests an interplay among regions associated with valuation, conflict processing, and cognitive control.
This functional brain marker is a step toward a generalizable brain model of individual differences in delay discounting.
Future studies can evaluate the marker as a potential transdiagnostic marker of altered decision-making in different clinical and developmental populations.

original_abstract:
Transcutaneous auricular vagus nerve stimulation (taVNS) is proposed to activate the locus ceruleus-noradrenaline (LC-NA) system.
Previous studies have not found consistent modulatory effects of taVNS on LC-NA biomarkers.
Phasic taVNS may modulate LC-NA biomarkers like pupil dilation and alpha oscillations.
It is unclear if these effects extend beyond pure sensory vagal nerve responses.
The potential of the pupillary light reflex as a taVNS biomarker has not been explored previously.
A study was conducted with 29 subjects (16 female, 13 male) using phasic active and sham taVNS.
Subjects performed an emotional Stroop task (EST) and a passive pupil light reflex task (PLRT).
Pupil size and brain activity dynamics were recorded using Magnetoencephalography (MEG) and pupillometry.
Phasic taVNS significantly increased pupil dilation and performance during the EST.
During the PLRT, active taVNS reduced and delayed pupil constriction.
MEG results showed increased frontal-midline theta and alpha power during the EST with taVNS.
Occipital alpha power was reduced during both the EST and PLRT with taVNS.
The study provides evidence that phasic taVNS systematically modulates behavioral, pupillary, and electrophysiological parameters of LC-NA activity during cognitive processing.
The study demonstrates for the first time that the pupillary light reflex can be used as a simple and effective proxy of taVNS efficacy.
These findings have important implications for developing noninvasive neuromodulation interventions for various cognitive and clinical applications.

original_abstract:
REM sleep is crucial for processing emotional memories, including fear memories.
Rhythmic interactions, particularly in the theta band, between the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) and limbic structures are important.
The mechanisms of memory processing at the circuit level are largely unknown.
A biophysically based model was used to investigate how rhythmic interactions lead to fear extinction during REM sleep.
The model included the infralimbic cortex (IL), a part of the mPFC critical for suppressing fear memories.
Theta frequency (4–12 Hz) inputs to an IL cell assembly strengthened connections from IL to amygdala and weakened connections from amygdala to IL.
This resulted in the suppression of fear expression cells for the associated memory.
Lower frequency (4 Hz) theta inputs were effective over a wider range of input strengths.
Inputs at other frequencies were ineffective at causing synaptic changes and did not suppress fear memories.
Under post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) REM sleep conditions, rhythmic activity dissipated.
In PTSD conditions, 4 Hz theta inputs to IL were ineffective.
Higher-frequency (10 Hz) theta inputs to IL in PTSD conditions induced changes similar to 4 Hz inputs under normal REM sleep.
These changes in PTSD conditions still resulted in the suppression of fear expression cells.
The results suggest why PTSD patients may repeatedly experience the same emotionally charged dreams.
The findings suggest potential neuromodulatory therapies for ameliorating PTSD symptoms.

original_abstract:
Unipolar brush cells (UBCs) in the cerebellum and dorsal cochlear nucleus (DCN) convert brief mossy fiber bursts into long-lasting responses.
Cerebellar UBCs exhibit a continuum of temporal responses due to mixed inhibition and graded mGluR1-dependent excitation.
Previous understanding suggested mGluR1 had little contribution to mossy fiber responses in DCN UBCs.
It was thought that DCN had distinct excitatory and inhibitory UBC subtypes.
The study investigated UBC response properties in the DCN of mice using noninvasive cell-attached recordings.
Mice of either sex were used in the study.
A continuum of responses to mossy fiber bursts was observed in DCN UBCs.
Response durations ranged from 100 ms excitation to initial inhibition followed by several seconds of excitation.
Some responses showed inhibition lasting for hundreds of milliseconds.
Pharmacological investigation revealed that excitatory responses are primarily mediated by mGluR1.
UBCs in both DCN and cerebellum rely on mGluR1 and display a continuum of response durations.
The continuum of responses in DCN may allow for more flexible and efficient temporal processing compared to distinct excitatory and inhibitory populations.

original_abstract:
The cerebellar cortex processes sensorimotor information through a feedforward inhibitory (FFI) microcircuit.
This microcircuit connects the granule cell (GC) layer input stage to the Purkinje cell (PC) output stage.
Recent findings show complex behaviors in the GC-molecular layer interneuron (MLI)-PC pathway.
The study used ex vivo patch-clamp recordings of PCs in male mice.
Channelrhodopsin2 was expressed in a subset of mossy fibers (MFs) using a viral-based strategy.
Light-mediated MF activation elicited pairs of excitatory and inhibitory postsynaptic currents in PCs.
Excitation (E) from GCs and inhibition (I) from MLIs reached PCs with a wide range of temporal delays.
Direct GC stimulation resulted in low variability in E/I delays.
MF stimulation often recruited different groups of GCs that trigger E and/or I.
This recruitment expanded PC temporal synaptic integration.
A computational model of the FFI pathway was used to study the effects of temporal expansion.
The model showed that temporal expansion could strongly influence how PCs integrate GC inputs.
Specific E/I delays may help PCs encode specific MF inputs.

original_abstract:
Intraneuronal chloride concentrations in rodents decrease during the first two postnatal weeks.
This decrease causes a shift from depolarizing to hyperpolarizing GABA responses.
The postnatal GABA shift is delayed in rodent models for neurodevelopmental disorders and in human patients.
The impact of a delayed GABA shift on the developing brain is not well understood.
Researchers examined the consequences of a delayed postnatal GABA shift on network development in organotypic hippocampal cultures.
Cultures were made from 6- to 7-day-old mice and treated for 1 week with VU0463271, a specific inhibitor of the chloride exporter KCC2.
VU treatment delayed the GABA shift and kept GABA signaling depolarizing until DIV9.
Structural and functional development of excitatory and inhibitory synapses at DIV9 was not affected by VU treatment.
GABA signaling was inhibitory in both control and VU-treated postnatal slices.
At DIV21, 14 days after VU treatment ended, an increased frequency of spontaneous inhibitory postsynaptic currents was observed in CA1 pyramidal cells.
Excitatory currents were not changed at DIV21.
Synapse numbers and release probability were unaffected.
Dendrite-targeting interneurons in the stratum radiatum had an elevated resting membrane potential.
Pyramidal cells were less excitable compared to control slices.
Results show that depolarizing GABA signaling does not promote synapse formation after P7.
Findings suggest that postnatal intracellular chloride levels indirectly affect membrane properties in a cell-specific manner.

original_abstract:
Visual cognition models assume brain networks predict stimulus contents to aid categorization.
Understanding prediction and categorization at a network level has been challenging.
Researchers used connectivity measures to isolate content-specific communications.
The study involved 11 participants of both sexes.
Participants were cued to spatial location (left vs right) and contents (LSF vs HSF) of a predicted Gabor stimulus.
Participants then categorized the stimulus.
MEG was used to measure neural activity concurrently.
Networks for predicting and categorizing LSF vs HSF contents were reconstructed for each participant.
Predicted contents flexibly propagate top-down from temporal to lateralized occipital cortex.
Propagation depends on task demands and is under prefrontal cortex supervisory control.
Predictions enhance bottom-up LSF vs HSF stimulus representations in lateralized occipital cortex.
Enhanced representations extend from occipital-ventral-parietal to premotor cortex.
Enhanced representations lead to faster categorization behavior.
Content communications represent 55-75% of typical signal-to-signal communications between brain regions.
The study isolates functional networks processing information of cognitive functions.

original_abstract:
The study focuses on the functional topography of the human primary somatosensory cortex hand area.
The research aims to understand whether the 3D structural architecture shows topographic organization.
7 Tesla (7T) magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was used for data collection.
The study quantified layer-specific myelin, iron, and mineralization in relation to population receptive field maps.
Individual finger representations in Brodman area 3b (BA 3b) of human S1 were examined.
The study included female and male younger adults as participants.
A characteristic profile of layer-specific myelin and iron deposition was identified in the BA 3b hand area.
The research found an absence of structural differences between individual fingers.
No low-myelin borders were detected between individual finger representations.
High similarity of 3D microstructure profiles was observed between individual fingers.
Structural differences and borders were detected between the hand and face areas.
The study concludes that the 3D structural architecture of the human hand area is nontopographic.
This nontopographic structure differs from some monkey species.
The findings suggest a high degree of flexibility for functional finger organization.
The results provide a new perspective on human topographic plasticity.

original_abstract:
Corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) regulates neuroendocrine and autonomic function.
CRH mRNA and protein levels are increased in the hypothalamic paraventricular nucleus (PVN) in primary hypertension.
CRHR1 proteins were found in retrogradely labeled PVN presympathetic neurons.
CRHR1 protein levels were higher in the PVN tissue of adult spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs) compared to Wistar–Kyoto (WKY) rats.
CRH induced a greater increase in firing rate of PVN-rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) neurons and sympathoexcitatory response in SHRs than in WKY rats.
The effect of CRH was blocked by NMDA receptor antagonist AP5 and PSD-95 inhibitor Tat-N-dimer.
Blocking CRHRs with astressin or CRHR1 with NBI35965 decreased firing rate of PVN-RVLM neurons and reduced arterial blood pressure (ABP) and renal sympathetic nerve activity (RSNA) in SHRs but not in WKY rats.
Blocking CRHR2 with antisauvagine-30 did not affect firing rate, ABP, or RSNA.
CRHR1 colocalized with NMDARs in PVN presympathetic neurons.
Blocking CRHRs significantly decreased NMDA currents in labeled PVN neurons.
PSD-95-bound CRHR1 and PSD-95-bound GluN2A in the PVN were increased in SHRs.
Upregulation of CRHR1 in the PVN is critically involved in hyperactivity of PVN presympathetic neurons and elevated sympathetic outflow in primary hypertension.

CRH mRNA and protein levels are increased in the hypothalamic paraventricular nucleus (PVN) in primary hypertension.
CRHR1 proteins were found in retrogradely labeled PVN presympathetic neurons.
CRHR1 protein levels were higher in the PVN tissue of adult spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs) compared to Wistar–Kyoto (WKY) rats.
CRH induced a less significant increase in firing rate of PVN-rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) neurons and sympathoexcitatory response in SHRs than in WKY rats.
The effect of CRH was blocked by NMDA receptor antagonist MK-801 and PSD-95 inhibitor Tat-NR2B9c.
Blocking CRHRs with astressin or CRHR1 with NBI35965 moderately decreased firing rate of PVN-RVLM neurons and reduced arterial blood pressure (ABP) and renal sympathetic nerve activity (RSNA) in WKY rats but not in SHRs.
Blocking CRHR2 with Astressin-2B did not affect firing rate, ABP, or RSNA.
CRHR1 colocalized with NMDARs in PVN presympathetic neurons.
Blocking CRHRs significantly decreased NMDA currents in labeled PVN neurons.
PSD-95-bound CRHR1 and PSD-95-bound GluN2A in the PVN were increased in SHRs.
Upregulation of CRHR1 in the PVN is critically involved in hyperactivity of PVN presympathetic neurons and elevated sympathetic outflow in primary hypertension.

original_abstract:
Sign-tracking (ST) rats show enhanced cue sensitivity before drug experience.
ST rats predict greater discrete cue-induced drug seeking compared to goal-tracking or intermediate rats.
Cue-evoked dopamine in the nucleus accumbens (NAc) is a neurobiological signature of sign-tracking behaviors.
Endocannabinoids are critical regulators of the dopamine system.
Endocannabinoids bind to cannabinoid receptor-1 (CB1R) in the ventral tegmental area (VTA) to control cue-evoked striatal dopamine levels.
The study used cell type-specific optogenetics, intra-VTA pharmacology, and fiber photometry.
The hypothesis tested was that VTA CB1R receptor signaling regulates NAc dopamine levels to control sign tracking.
Male and female rats were trained in a Pavlovian lever autoshaping (PLA) task to determine tracking groups.
The effect of VTA → NAc dopamine inhibition was tested.
The VTA → NAc circuit is critical for mediating the vigor of the ST response.
Intra-VTA infusions of rimonabant, a CB1R inverse agonist, during PLA decrease lever and increase food cup approach in sign-trackers.
Fiber photometry was used to measure fluorescent signals from a dopamine sensor, GRABDA (AAV9-hSyn-DA2m).
The effects of intra-VTA rimonabant on NAc dopamine dynamics during autoshaping were tested in female rats.
Intra-VTA rimonabant decreased sign-tracking behaviors.
Decreases in sign-tracking behaviors were associated with increases in NAc shell, but not core, dopamine levels during reward delivery [unconditioned stimulus (US)].
CB1R signaling in the VTA influences the balance between conditioned stimulus-evoked and US-evoked dopamine responses in the NAc shell.
CB1R signaling in the VTA biases behavioral responding to cues in sign-tracking rats.

original_abstract:
Intrinsic neural dynamics occur at multiple timescales during rest.
These timescales progressively increase along visual and somatosensory hierarchies.
Intrinsic timescales are theoretically thought to facilitate processing of external stimuli at multiple stages.
Direct links between resting timescales and sensory processing, as well as translation to the auditory system, have been lacking.
Researchers measured intracranial EEG in 11 human epilepsy patients (4 women) while listening to pure tones.
In the auditory network, intrinsic neural timescales progressively increase from temporal to entorhinal cortex, hippocampus, and amygdala.
The spectral exponent flattens along the same progression.
Within the neocortex, intrinsic timescales exhibit spatial gradients following temporal lobe anatomy.
Intrinsic timescales at baseline can explain the latency of auditory responses.
As intrinsic timescales increase, single-electrode response onset and peak latencies also increase.
The human auditory network exhibits a repertoire of intrinsic neural dynamics.
These dynamics manifest in cortical gradients with millimeter resolution.
The varied intrinsic neural dynamics may provide a variety of temporal windows to support auditory processing.

original_abstract:
Synaptic loss is linked to Alzheimer's disease (AD) neuropathology and symptoms.
The direct impact of synaptic loss on clinical symptoms in AD remains unclear.
Shank3, a postsynaptic protein, is of interest as loss of a single SHANK3 gene allele causes severe cognitive symptoms in children.
Researchers investigated whether SHANK3 deficiency contributes to AD symptoms and neuropathology.
A 30%-50% postmortem loss of SHANK3a was found in the parietal cortex of AD patients, associated with cognitive decline.
3xTg-AD mice (modeling Aβ and tau pathologies) were crossed with Shank3a-deficient mice (Shank3Δex4-9).
Synergistic deleterious effects were observed in hemizygous Shank3Δex4-9-3xTg-AD mice on object recognition memory at 9, 12, and 18 months.
Anxious behavior was affected at 9 and 12 months in hemizygous Shank3Δex4-9-3xTg-AD mice.
Hemizygous Shank3Δex4-9 animals showed a 50% loss of Shank3a in the parietotemporal cortex.
Levels of other synaptic proteins (PSD-95, drebrin, and homer1) remained unchanged in Shank3Δex4-9 animals.
Shank3a deficiency increased levels of soluble Aβ42 and human tau at 18 months compared to 3xTg-AD mice with normal Shank3 expression.
Results from human brain samples and transgenic mice support the hypothesis that Shank3 deficiency contributes to cognitive impairment in AD.

original_abstract:
In vitro models of acute brain injury show neuronal death overwhelming microglial phagocytosis capacity.
A queue of dying neurons awaiting clearance is formed.
Neurons undergoing programmed cell death are the most visible and frequently quantified measure of neuronal death after injury.
The size of the queue is equally sensitive to changes in neuronal death and phagocytosis rate.
Rodent organotypic hippocampal slice cultures were used as a model of acute perinatal brain injury.
Serial imaging showed microglial phagocytosis of dying neurons was overwhelmed for 2 weeks.
Altering phagocytosis rates by changing the number of microglia dramatically changed the number of visibly dying neurons.
Changing the membrane permeability for stains that label dying neurons altered their visibility.
Canonically neuroprotective interventions, such as seizure blockade, were mediated by effects on microglial activity and neuronal membrane permeability.
Neurotoxic maneuvers, like perinatal ethanol exposure, also affected microglial activity and neuronal membrane permeability.
These interventions had either no effect or opposing effects on healthy surviving neurons identified by ongoing expression of transgenic fluorescent proteins.

original_abstract:
Cortical stimulation is emerging as an experimental tool in basic research and a potential therapy for neuropsychiatric conditions.
Multielectrode arrays in clinical practice offer the possibility of using spatiotemporal patterns of electrical stimulation to induce desired physiological patterns.
Current implementation relies on trial-and-error due to a lack of predictive models.
Traveling waves are increasingly recognized as fundamental to cortical information-processing.
There is a lack of understanding on how to control wave properties despite improving technologies.
The study uses a hybrid biophysical-anatomical and neural-computational model to predict and understand how cortical surface stimulation could induce directional traveling waves.
The model focuses on asymmetric activation of inhibitory interneurons.
Pyramidal cells and basket cells are highly activated by the anodal electrode and minimally activated by cathodal electrodes.
Martinotti cells are moderately activated by both electrodes but show a slight preference for cathodal stimulation.
Network model simulations found that asymmetrical activation results in a traveling wave in superficial excitatory cells.
The traveling wave propagates unidirectionally away from the electrode array.
The study reveals how asymmetric electrical stimulation can facilitate traveling waves.
The facilitation of traveling waves relies on two distinct types of inhibitory interneuron activity.
These interneuron activities shape and sustain the spatiotemporal dynamics of endogenous local circuit mechanisms.

original_abstract:
TMEM206 was recently identified as the molecular basis of the extracellular proton-activated Cl− channel (PAC).
PAC plays an essential role in neuronal death during ischemia-reperfusion.
The PAC channel is activated by extracellular acid, but the proton-sensitive mechanism remains unclear.
Different acid-sensitive pockets have been suggested based on the cryo-EM structure of the human PAC (hPAC) channel.
The study identified two acidic amino acid residues that removed the pH-dependent activation of the hPAC channel.
This identification was achieved by neutralizing all conservative negative charged residues in the extracellular domain and some positively charged residues at the hotspot.
Two-electrode voltage-clamp (TEVC) recording in the Xenopus oocytes system was used for the experiments.
Double-mutant cycle analysis and double cysteine mutant of these two residues proved they cooperatively form a proton-sensitive site.
Chloral hydrate was found to activate the hPAC channel depending on its normal pH sensitivity.
PAC channel knock-out (KO) male mice (C57BL/6J) resist chloral hydrate-induced sedation and hypnosis.
The study provides a molecular basis for understanding the proton-dependent activation mechanism of the hPAC channel.
The findings suggest a novel drug target for chloral hydrate.

original_abstract:
The dopaminergic neuromodulator system is fundamental to brain functions.
Abnormal dopamine (DA) pathway is implicated in psychiatric disorders, including schizophrenia (SZ) and autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
Mutations in Cullin 3 (CUL3), a core component of the Cullin-RING ubiquitin E3 ligase complex, have been associated with SZ and ASD.
Little is known about the function and mechanism of CUL3 in the DA system.
CUL3 is critical for the function of DA neurons and DA-relevant behaviors in male mice.
CUL3-deficient mice exhibited hyperactive locomotion, deficits in working memory and sensorimotor gating, and increased sensitivity to psychostimulants.
Enhanced DA signaling and elevated excitability of the VTA DA neurons were observed in CUL3-deficient animals.
Behavioral impairments were attenuated by dopamine D2 receptor antagonist haloperidol and chemogenetic inhibition of DA neurons.
HCN2, a hyperpolarization-activated and cyclic nucleotide-gated channel, was identified as a potential target of CUL3 in DA neurons.
CUL3 controls DA neuronal activity by maintaining ion channel homeostasis.
The study provides insight into the role of CUL3 in the pathogenesis of psychiatric disorders.

original_abstract:
Body ownership and sense of agency are key aspects of bodily self-consciousness.
Few studies have examined the relationship between body ownership and agency during voluntary movement.
The study used the moving rubber hand illusion with active or passive finger movements during fMRI.
The study isolated activations reflecting body ownership, agency, and their interaction.
Perceived hand ownership was associated with activity in premotor, posterior parietal, and cerebellar regions.
Sense of agency over hand movements was related to activity in dorsal premotor cortex and superior temporal cortex.
A section of the dorsal premotor cortex showed overlapping activity for ownership and agency.
Somatosensory cortical activity reflected the interaction of ownership and agency.
Higher somatosensory activity was observed when both agency and ownership were experienced.
Activations in left insular cortex and right temporoparietal junction reflected visuoproprioceptive synchrony/asynchrony rather than agency.
The results reveal the neural bases of agency and ownership during voluntary movement.
Neural representations of agency and ownership are largely distinct.
There are interactions and functional neuroanatomical overlap when agency and ownership combine.
The findings have implications for theories on bodily self-consciousness.

original_abstract:
Brain oscillations are prevalent across species and involved in various perceptual operations.
α oscillations are thought to inhibit task-irrelevant networks, facilitating processing.
β oscillations are linked to the reactivation of content representations.
The study aims to investigate if the functional roles of α and β oscillations extend to higher-level cognitive processes, specifically naturalistic spoken language comprehension.
22 Dutch native speakers (18 female) participated in the study, listening to stories in Dutch and French while MEG was recorded.
Dependency parsing was used to identify three dependency states at each word: newly opened dependencies, dependencies remaining open, and resolved dependencies.
Forward models were constructed to predict α and β power from the dependency features.
Results showed that dependency features predict α and β power in language-related regions beyond low-level linguistic features.
Left temporal, fundamental language regions are involved in language comprehension in the α band.
Frontal and parietal higher-order language regions, and motor regions are involved in the β band.
α- and β-band dynamics appear to support language comprehension by tapping into syntactic structure building and semantic composition.
These oscillations provide low-level mechanistic operations for inhibition and reactivation processes during language comprehension.
The temporal similarity of α-β responses means their potential functional dissociation remains to be elucidated.
The study provides evidence for the generalizability of α and β oscillation dynamics from perceptual to complex linguistic processes.
The research sheds light on the role of α and β oscillations during naturalistic spoken language comprehension.

original_abstract:
Political polarization has shown that individuals with opposing views experience events differently.
The study investigated the neural mechanisms behind this phenomenon.
34 right- and left-wing participants (45% females) underwent fMRI scanning.
Participants watched political videos before elections in Israel.
Significant differences were observed between left- and right-wing participants in their interpretation of video content.
Neuroimaging revealed partisanship-dependent differences in activation and synchronization in higher-order brain regions.
Differences were also found in early sensory, motor, and somatosensory regions.
Political content synchronized responses in primary visual and auditory cortices in a partisanship-dependent manner.
Right-wing individuals' sensorimotor cortex was involved in processing right-wing political content.
Left-wing individuals' sensorimotor cortex did not show similar involvement for left-wing content.
These differences were pronounced enough to predict political orientation from early brain responses alone.
No such differences were found with respect to neutral content.
The results reveal fundamental neural mechanisms underlying political polarization processes.

original_abstract:
Behavioral studies indicate motion perception is basic at birth and develops steadily in early years.
Previous research showed major cortical associative areas (MT+, V6, PIVC) respond selectively to coherent flow in 8-week-old infants.
This study examines BOLD response to motion stimuli in 5-week-old infants (four females, four males).
Comparison of maturation between 5 and 8 weeks of age is conducted.
MT+ and PIVC areas show similar motion response at 5 and 8 weeks.
V6 area shows reduced BOLD response to motion at 5 weeks.
Cuneus associative areas are not identifiable at 5 weeks.
Primary visual cortex (V1) does not show selectivity for coherent motion in infants or adults.
V1 shows rapid development in response to motion stimuli appearance between 5 and 8 weeks.
Resting-state correlations show adult-like functional connectivity between motion-selective associative areas.
Functional connectivity is not observed between primary cortex and temporo-occipital and posterior-insular cortices.
Results suggest differential developmental trajectory of motion areas compared to other occipital regions.
Findings may reflect different development trajectories of central and peripheral visual fields.

original_abstract:
Animal communication sounds have complex temporal structure due to amplitude fluctuations in the sound envelope.
In human speech, envelope modulations synchronize activity in auditory cortex (AC), correlating with comprehension.
Previous studies on envelope coding in single neurons of nonhuman animals focused on periodic amplitude modulation (AM) stimuli.
This study aimed to bridge human and animal research by examining the temporal relationship between stimulus envelope and spiking.
The study assessed whether diversity in neurons' AM responses contributes to population representation of speech-like sound envelopes.
Responses from single neurons to vocoded speech stimuli were gathered and compared to sinusoidal AM responses in AC of alert, freely moving Mongolian gerbils of both sexes.
AC neurons displayed heterogeneous tuning to AM rate but had stereotyped temporal dynamics.
Preferred response phases accumulated near the onsets of sinusoidal AM periods for slower rates (<8 Hz).
An over-representation of amplitude edges was observed in population responses to both sinusoidal AM and vocoded speech envelopes.
This encoding bias provided a decoding benefit for vocoded speech stimuli using summed population activity.
Higher frequency modulations required a more sophisticated decoder tracking spiking responses from individual cells.
Results suggest that envelope structure relevant to parsing an acoustic stream could be read-out from a distributed, redundant population code.

original_abstract:
Episodic memory components (what, where, and when) can be differentiated based on distinct domain-specific neural correlates.
Recent studies propose a common neural mechanism of conceptual mapping for coding cognitive distance across all domains.
This study provides evidence for both domain-specific and domain-general processes occurring simultaneously during memory retrieval.
The study identified distinctive and common neural representations for mapping semantic, spatial, and temporal distance.
The study used scalp EEG data from 47 healthy participants aged 21-30 (26 male, 21 female).
All three memory components showed a positive correlation between cognitive distance and slow theta power (2.5-5 Hz) in parietal channels.
Fast theta power (5-8.5 Hz) specifically represented spatial distance in occipital channels.
Fast theta power (5-8.5 Hz) specifically represented temporal distance in parietal channels.
A unique correlate of temporal distance coding was identified in frontal/parietal slow theta power during the early phase of retrieval.
All identified neural markers of cognitive mapping, both domain-general and specific, were associated with individual differences in what, where, and when memory accuracy.

original_abstract:
Previous research showed that performance in auditory selective attention tasks can be influenced by task-irrelevant visual stimuli.
The effect depends on whether the visual stimulus is temporally coherent with the target auditory stream or a competing distractor.
The neurophysiological interaction between audiovisual (AV) temporal coherence and auditory selective attention remained unclear.
A study was conducted using EEG to measure neural activity in human participants.
Participants performed an auditory selective attention task, detecting deviants in a target audio stream.
The amplitude envelopes of two competing auditory streams changed independently.
A visual disk's radius was manipulated to control AV coherence.

original_abstract:
Numerosity, the set size of a group of items, guides behavior and decisions in humans and animals.
Numerosity perception is considered a precursor to symbolic numerical cognition.
Previous research identified neural populations tuned to numerosities in topographic maps in human association cortex.
This study investigated whether numerosity maps process symbolic numbers.
The research used 7T fMRI and a number-detection task.
Seven participants (3 females) were recruited for the study.
The numerosity map at the temporal-occipital cortex (NTO) was found to respond to symbolic numbers.
Numerosity-tuned neuronal populations in the left hemisphere's NTO map are tuned to symbolic numbers.
Results reveal different functions of numerosity maps.
Findings support a link between numerosity representation and symbolic number processing in the ventral temporal-occipital cortex.

original_abstract:
Executive function (EF) is essential for humans to engage in cognitively demanding tasks.
In adults, EF is supported by frontoparietal regions in the multiple demand (MD) network.
Children initially show poor EF and prolonged development.
The study examines whether children recruit the same network as adults for EF tasks.
The research investigates if the MD network is functionally and connectionally distinct from adjacent language cortex in children, as it is in adults.
The study explores whether activation or connectivity depends on age or ability.
The research uses task-dependent and resting state functional data from 44 adults (18-38 years, 68% female) and 37 children (4-12 years, 35% female).
Subject-specific functional ROIs (ss-fROIs) show bilateral MD network activation in children.
MD ss-fROIs are not recruited for linguistic processing in both children and adults.
MD ss-fROIs are connectionally distinct from language ss-fROIs in both groups.
MD activation was lower in children than in adults, even in motion- and performance-matched groups.
Both children and adults showed increasing MD activation with better performance, especially in right hemisphere ss-fROIs.
The relationship between MD activation and performance persists when controlling for age, both cross-sectionally and in a small longitudinal sample of children.
The MD network is selective to cognitive demand in children.
The MD network is distinct from adjacent language cortex in children.
The MD network increases in selectivity as performance improves.
Neural structures supporting domain-general EF emerge early in development.
These neural structures are sensitive to ability even in children.
The research advances understanding of how high-level human cognition emerges.
The findings could inform interventions targeting cognitive control.

original_abstract:
Behavioral reports of sensory information are biased by stimulus history.
The nature and direction of serial-dependence biases can differ between experimental settings.
Both attractive and repulsive biases toward previous stimuli have been observed.
The origins of these biases in the human brain remain largely unexplored.
Biases could occur via changes in sensory processing or during postperceptual processes.
The study tested 20 participants (11 female).
The study analyzed behavioral and magnetoencephalographic (MEG) data.
Participants completed a working-memory task with two sequentially presented randomly oriented gratings.
One grating was cued for recall at the end of each trial.
Behavioral responses showed evidence for two distinct biases.
The first bias was a within-trial repulsive bias away from the previously encoded orientation.
The second bias was a between-trial attractive bias toward the task-relevant orientation from the previous trial.
Multivariate classification of stimulus orientation revealed neural representations during stimulus encoding were biased away from the previous grating orientation.
This repulsive bias in neural representations occurred for both within-trial and between-trial prior orientations.
The neural repulsive bias contrasted with the behavioral effects.
Results suggest repulsive biases occur at the level of sensory processing.
Repulsive biases can be overridden at postperceptual stages to result in attractive biases in behavior.

original_abstract:
Flexible adaptation to changing circumstances requires memory of past choices, outcomes in similar situations, and a method for selecting actions.
The hippocampus (HPC) is essential for remembering episodes, while the prefrontal cortex (PFC) aids in guiding memory retrieval.
Single-unit activity in both the HPC and PFC correlates with these cognitive functions.
Previous research recorded CA1 and mPFC activity in male rats performing a spatial reversal task in a plus maze.
This task requires both HPC and PFC structures.
Previous findings showed PFC activity helps reactivate HPC representations of pending goal choices.
The current study focuses on frontotemporal interactions after choices.
CA1 activity tracked both current goal location and past starting location of single trials.
PFC activity tracked current goal location better than past start location.
CA1 and PFC reciprocally modulated representations of each other both before and after goal choices.
After choices, CA1 activity predicted changes in PFC activity in subsequent trials.
The magnitude of this prediction correlated with faster learning.
PFC start arm activity more strongly modulated CA1 activity after choices, correlating with slower learning.
Post-choice HPC activity appears to convey retrospective signals to the PFC.
The PFC combines different paths to common goals into rules.
In subsequent trials, prechoice mPFC activity modulates prospective CA1 signals informing goal selection.

original_abstract:
The posterior cerebellum's role in social cognition is well-established.
It remains unclear whether different cerebellar subregions contribute to specific social cognitive processes.
This study used transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) on healthy male and female humans.
The researchers hypothesized a medial-to-lateral gradient in the functional organization of the posterior cerebellum.
They proposed that newer cerebellar hemispheres are involved in higher-level social inferences.
Vermal/medial sectors were hypothesized to be involved in basic perceptual emotional mechanisms.
TMS interference with medial cerebellum activity significantly impaired basic emotional recognition/discrimination.
TMS over the lateral cerebellum only affected tasks requiring emotion recognition in social contexts.
The data supports the existence of a medial-to-lateral gradient in the posterior cerebellum.
Medial sectors support basic emotion recognition.
Lateral sectors are recruited for higher inferential processing/mentalizing.
The cerebellum's contribution to these processes appears to be restricted to negative emotional stimuli.

original_abstract:
NG2 is a unique transmembrane chondroitin sulfate proteoglycan (CSPG).
NG2 has a dual role in damaged spinal cord.
NG2 is considered a key inhibitory factor for axonal growth after spinal injury.
NG2 has been recently discovered to block axonal conduction.
Some studies indicate NG2's importance in forming synaptic contacts.
The researchers hypothesized that neutralizing NG2's inhibitory functions without physical removal would be optimal.
Acute intraspinal injections of anti-NG2 monoclonal antibodies prevented acute axonal conduction block by exogenous NG2.
A novel gene therapy was developed for prolonged delivery of NG2 function neutralizing antibody.
The gene therapy uses an adeno-associated vector (AAV) construct expressing recombinant single-chain variable fragment anti-NG2 antibody (AAV-NG2Ab).
The study examined effects of AAV-NG2Ab alone or combined with neurotrophin NT-3 in adult female rats with thoracic T10 contusion injuries.
Behavioral tests were used to evaluate locomotor function.
In vivo single-cell electrophysiology evaluated synaptic transmission.
Lower urinary tract function was assessed using metabolic chambers.
Terminal cystometry was used to evaluate bladder function.
Both AAV-NG2Ab and AAV-NG2Ab+AAV-NT3 groups showed significant improvements in transmission, locomotion, and bladder function compared to the control group.
Functional improvements were associated with improved remyelination and plasticity of 5-HT fibers.
The best results were observed in the group receiving combinational AAV-NG2Ab+AAV-NT3 treatment.

original_abstract:
Cortical spreading depolarization (CSD) is a key pathophysiological event in migraine, underlying visual and sensory auras.
CSD is believed to drive the headache phase in migraine by activating and mechanically sensitizing trigeminal primary afferent nociceptive neurons innervating the cranial meninges.
Factors underlying meningeal nociception after CSD are poorly understood but may involve parenchymal release of algesic mediators and damage-associated molecular patterns, particularly ATP.
The study explored the role of ATP-P2X purinergic receptor signaling in CSD-evoked meningeal afferent activation and mechanical sensitization.
Male rats were subjected to a single CSD episode.
In vivo extracellular single-unit recording was used to measure meningeal afferent ongoing activity changes.
Quantitative mechanical stimuli using a servomotor force-controlled stimulator assessed changes in afferent mechanosensitivity.
Meningeal P2X receptors were manipulated via local administration of pharmacological agents.
Broad-spectrum P2X receptor inhibition suppressed CSD-evoked afferent mechanical sensitization but did not affect the accompanying afferent activation response.
Selective blockade of the P2X7 receptor and its related Pannexin 1 channel also suppressed CSD-evoked afferent mechanical sensitization without affecting afferent activation.
Inhibition of the pronociceptive P2X2/3 receptor did not affect the activation or sensitization of meningeal afferents post-CSD.
P2X7 signaling underlying afferent mechanosensitization was localized to the meninges and did not affect CSD susceptibility.
The study proposes that meningeal P2X7 and Pannexin 1 signaling, potentially in meningeal macrophages or neutrophils, mediates the mechanical sensitization of meningeal afferents.
This mechanism may contribute to migraine pain by exacerbating headaches during normally innocuous physical activities.

original_abstract:
The study investigated how perception of an object changes after learning its function.
48 participants (31 females, 17 males) were shown pictures of unfamiliar objects.
Objects were presented with either matching or non-matching function keywords.
Event-related potentials were measured to analyze differences in visual processing.
Semantically informed perception showed larger N170 component amplitudes (150-200 ms).
Semantically informed perception showed reduced N400 component amplitudes (400-700 ms).
A late decrease in alpha/beta band power was observed for informed perception.
Objects were presented again without information, and N400 and event-related power effects persisted.
Increased P1 component amplitudes (100-150 ms) were observed for objects with prior informed perception.
Results suggest semantic information alters lower-level visual perception (P1 component).
Higher-level visual perception (N170 component) is also affected by semantic information.
Semantic processing (N400 component, event-related power) is impacted by function knowledge.
This study shows these effects occur immediately after providing semantic information.
No extensive learning is required for these perceptual changes to take place.
This research is the first to demonstrate instant effects of semantic information on object perception.

original_abstract:
Automatic detection of surprising changes in sensory input is crucial for exogenous attentional control.
Stimulus-specific adaptation (SSA) is a potential neuronal mechanism for detecting such changes.
SSA has been observed across sensory modalities and in different parts of ascending sensory pathways.
The relationship between SSA and perception is not well understood.
A behavioral cross-modal paradigm in mice was used to assess how deviating stimuli influence target signal detection.
The study combined the behavioral paradigm with extracellular recordings from the primary somatosensory whisker cortex.
Male mice performed a visual detection task while task-irrelevant whisker stimuli were presented as repetitive "standard" or rare deviant stimuli.
A deviance distraction effect was observed on the animals' performance.
Deviant stimuli led to faster reaction times but worsened target detection.
Multiunit activity and local field potentials showed enhanced neuronal responses to deviant whisker stimuli compared to standard stimuli.
Enhanced neuronal responses were observed across all cortical layers as a result of SSA.
The deviant-triggered behavioral distraction correlated with enhanced neuronal deviant responses only in deeper cortical layers.
The layer-specific effect of SSA on perception decreased with increasing task experience.
The reduction in the layer-specific effect was a result of statistical distractor learning.
The study demonstrates a layer-specific involvement of SSA on perception.
The layer-specific effect of SSA on perception is susceptible to modulation over time.

original_abstract:
Risk/reward decision-making is a dynamic process involving deliberation before action selection and evaluation of outcomes.
Inactivation studies have shown the prelimbic (PL) cortex is important for updating decision biases in changing reward contingencies.
The study used temporally specific optogenetic inhibition to disrupt PL activity during action selection and outcome phases.
Male rats expressing eArchT in PL excitatory neurons were trained on a probabilistic discounting task.
The task involved choosing between small/certain and large/risky rewards, with probabilities varying from 50% to 12.5%.
Brief light pulses were used to suppress PL activity before choice or after different outcomes.
Prechoice suppression reduced bias toward preferred/higher utility options.
Prechoice suppression disrupted how recent outcomes influenced subsequent choices.
Inhibition during risky losses produced similar effects to prechoice suppression.
The impact of reward omissions was either amplified or diminished based on the estimated profitability of the risky option.
Inhibition during large or small reward receipt reduced risky choice when this option was more profitable.
PL signals can reinforce rewarded risky choices and act as a relative value comparator signal.
The study reveals multifaceted contributions of the PL in implementing decisions and integrating action-outcome feedback.
PL activity helps assign context to the decision space.
